description:
This place is so fun. I like taking my nearly 3 year old daughter here. She is treated so kindly by all the staff, they seem truly delighted to have us there. 

And the other guests find it so amusing to see this little girl act like a pro sushi eater. She goes in, sits down, watches the boats go by, points at the food she likes, and then devours it. She absolutely loves the edamame and salmon sashimi, and is starting to get adventurous and pick new things that look yummy to her. Last time she picked the bright orange flying fish roe and, to the surprise of everyone, she ate every bit. They also make her salmon roe (ikura) nigiri on request, which is one of her favorites.

One of the really nice advantages of this place is its price. My daughter can pick 4 different things (which she devours) and it's only about $10 for her. But sometimes she eats more... :)

We've now come here four times and it's become my daughter's favorite. Whenever we talk about going to a restaurant, she says she "wanna go to sushi boats". It's really hard to tell her no, that we're going to do pizza or burritos instead sometimes! She really wishes she could come here every day.
author: Jon E.

description:
Used to come here in high school quite some time ago. Enjoyed being able to select different pieces for a fraction of the cost of a role. However, think about the cost of 2 pieces of mediocre sushi. Standard rolls have 8 pieces, generally. Nigiri is worth it. Totally. To each their own, of course! I can go to HH and get a really yummy roll I enjoy for half price. 

 The women, unless you're friends or know them, are in their own mindset. Good to just get a few pieces and hang out for the experience.
author: Victoria V.

description:
Stumbled upon Sakana Bune while walking back from Bay to Breakers and looking for a spot to eat lunch. It was early on a Sunday (around 11:30 a.m.) but there was a good crowd. 

Food: Super cute rotating sushi boat! The boats had a good mix of rolls, sashimi and apps (like edamame, stir fried veggies, tempura) and all at good prices. You could also order off the menu for additional rolls and hot food items. Husband and I shared an edamame off the boat, he had several different rolls and sashimi but liked the salmon sashimi best), and I enjoyed stir friend veggies and the veggie tempura roll (full roll menu item). The veggie tempura roll had tempura veggies inside and then seaweed salad on top -- different than most vegetarian sushi roll options and really delicious. 

Location: We were walking so I can't speak too much on the parking options, but like most of SF, seems to be street parking in the area, but it's hit or miss how close you'll find something. Inside, there's probably about 20 seats at the rotating boats and 10-15 additional tables in the restaurant. 

Service: Our waitress was quick to refill our water and tea and take my order for an additional roll. We didn't have too much need for additional service, but when we needed it, it was prompt and well done.
author: Alexis T.

description:
They have raised up there prices so high you should go to a better restaurant.  It is now a rip off.  Now $5.00 for two pieces of a roll.  
RIP OFF and not worth it for 2nd rate sushi.  I used to go here all the time but they have gone way over a fair price.  This used to be a great place to take kids because the prices were good for okay sushi.  Do not go any more because they are cheating you for stupid rolls and not the best sushi.  Sorry to see a fair place become a over priced lousy sushi place..
author: Cindy S.

description: I used to come here ever so often. Every now and then I see the prices rising. As a high school student, I couldn't afford coming on my own time, but occasionally, when I wanted to treat myself, I would come here to have a quiet and quick lunch. I would only be able to eat a few plates because the prices were about $3 a plate off the boats. To me, that was a lot. Every one in a while when I visit, my parents would take me here because they knew I liked this place. It's a great family restaurant, shared bar seatings with available table arrangements.
author: Shaeli Z.

description: I come here if I am in the mood for cheap, quick sushi. There is usually a spot when I pop in during lunch hours. I sit at the roundabout sushi boat table as plates of little sushi rotates. Each plate is colored differently to distinguish the price levels of that plate. 3 stars for the food but the service from the ladies are great every single time. Besides the sushi boat, they have a full menu of hot food items that you can order. I almost always order a soft shell crab and some ice cream to top it off. I eat til I am full and the bill is around $20. Not bad.
author: Annie L.

description:
Usually a hit or miss here, but you can usually tell if the fish is going to be fresh by how busy this place is. If there are a lot of empty seats, be prepared to choose from plates that have been revolving for some time. If this place is jam packed, it will be worth your while to put your name down on the list to be seated at the bar.

Sakana Bune is a sushi boat style where you get to pick and choose plates. Each plate is color coated and you can match it to the colors on the table to figure out how much each dish cost. This concept is great if you want to try new things, but you are afraid of committing yourself to a whole dish.

You really can't go wrong with the california rolls here. This is my favorite spot to get cheap yet delicious california rolls. From the creaminess of the imitation crab and sauce to the generous filling inside the rice just makes this an easy dish to always get. The house special roll , which consists of unagi and avocado on top of california roll, is also a must get when you are here.

Surprisingly, the chicken teriyaki and beef teriyaki is really good here. The crispy skin of the chicken yet tender meat makes it a great dish to fill up on. This includes miso soup and a bowl of salad. 

Waitresses are all very nice and it is really easy to flag them down.
author: Timothy C.

description:
Came here with my GF for a late lunch. The sushi boats were AWESOME! Lots and lots and lots of sushi.

The food overall was really good and really cheap.

No wait, since the food is constantly in front of you!

Service for water and extras was super fast too!

Will be back again!
author: Robert R.

description:
Sakana Bune always gets the job done when i'm craving sushi. I get to pick whatever I want from the conveyer belt/menu, and all the items are verrry affordable. I like getting nigiri because you can get so many different types! The individual plates on the sushi boats range from $2-$3.75 I believe.

My favorite items are:
- Oysters: Always fresh and tasty, and the ponzu that comes with it is yummy too. 
- Super white tuna with ponzu & maguro: My favorite nigiri here!!! I will probably get two of these whenever I come here. If it's not on the belt, you can ask a waitress for this item too. (That goes for any item on the menu!)
- Salmon nigiri: The salmon is pretty good quality and buttery. No complaints! 

They also have 2-4 pieces of different rolls floating around on the boats too. It's nice to have smaller portions sometimes so you can try different items!

Waitresses are always very nice and good with refilling waters. The only bad things are that parking around this area is terrible and during weekend dinner, there may be a small wait!
author: Tara A.

description:
I am not not one to root on automation (although it is coming) as it displaces work forces and has all kinds of negative consequences for society in general...but. This place needs a Sushi robot!!!!


Sakana Bune has sunk to a new low. Who hires a guy who cant make sushi...seriously the stuff he was putting on plates was shockingly bad ( clumps of fish with rice). If this was a restaurant in Tokyo there would be someone committing Seppuku ( voluntarily or not!!!!)

Furthermore the Mexican dude ( I kid you not) had the worst BO as we could smell its pungency across the sushi boat station.

I still think my youngest likes this place and yes it is cheap and fast....but I wont be coming back anytime soon.
author: David G.

description:
My son loves this place due to the fun of being able to select his own sushi from the little boat's conveyor belt. 

Five stars for the fun experience.

Three stars for the sushi. 

A few things are decent/good: son enjoys the imitation-crab Ca rolls and the inari (bean curd) sushi. 

I like their salmon nigiri and spicy white tuna. 

Affordable prices.
author: Camille L.

description:
My go to spot for cheap and fast sushi that hits the spot. Keep in mind this place is always a hit or miss when it comes to the freshness of the fishes. This is all depends solely on how many people there are in the sushi bar picking items. I find it best to come when this place is jack packed. 

The servers here are always super friendly and great at remembering faces. Service is always quick and easy to obtain since here are several waitresses standing around the tables at all time. 

If you have never been to sushi boat before, the prices are listed on the mat slightly above where you will be sitting at the sushi bar. Each sushi dish that goes around in plates will be color coded so you know exactlly how much you will be paying. The best rolls that I highly recommend would be the lion king roll (baked salmon with creamy sauce on top of California roll), house special roll (California roll with unagi and avocado on top), and if it seems like a busy day, sunset rolls (spicy California roll with raw salmon and avocado on top). 

I know it is weird but this place has the best chicken teriyaki you can order. My boyfriend and I randomly ordered it and it was amazing. The skin was nice and crisp while the meat was nice and juicy! Holy grail. *bows down* This is always made to order so even when it is slow I think you can't really go wrong with chicken teriyaki.
author: Ada H.

description:
My friends and I were waiting for a table at Dragon Beaux so we decided to swing in here for a couple of bites and some drinks. It's basically what you'd expect from a random rotating sushi joint on the corner of a street. Some items might be a hit, and some might not make the mark. The service was average and overall nothing was really terrible, but nothing was extraordinary either.

Price-wise, you definitely get what you pay for. The plates are all very affordable and nothing on the "belt" is over $4-5 if I recall correctly. You could easily be satisfied spending $20-25 a person here. With that being said, I'd avoid some of the items that look like they've been rotating on the water for a while. Be smart about what you pick, or better yet just order off the menu.

One thing that sort of irked me was when we came in with a group of 5 they sat us all the way in the back corner even though the restaurant was empty and we asked to be sat towards the middle. Their reasoning was that lunchtime was coming up soon and there would be an influx of customers. So....do we not look like customers? With that aside, Sakana Bune is straightforward, reasonably priced sushi. The saying "you get what you pay for" definitely applies to this restaurant.
author: Viet L.

description:
Server was immediately rude when we walked in, even remarked "No splitting the Check" when we said 5 people as if that was The contingent factor in her decision to seat us. 

Luckily we had another server who was friendly. 5 of us split a combination platter which was very filling. Sushi was good, but very average. Nothing special. 

Would come back again because of the price and proximity to our stay in SF
author: Garrett W.

description: My go to sushi when I crave good sashimi (Salmon, Tuna, White Tuna). The only thing about this place is there's not much choices on the boat but that doesn't bother me because I usually just get salmon, tuna and oysters.
author: T N.

description: I enjoy coming to this restaurant because I know what I'm going to get. You get some pretty good options for sushi, and the overall experience is cool. All the items are being made fresh in front of you. And the price is very reasonable. 2 people can get full here for about $25-40. Not bad for how expensive sushi usually is.
author: Manny R.

description:
These people don't know how to work with customers, yelling at people is not your best strategy to get tipped.

Update: they are also charging 18% fee for service for the party of 2, providing zero service.. very strange place.
author: Yulia S.

description:
I came to the restaurant with my baby, he was super hungry and don't eat sushi yet, so I got him food from another place. Before giving the food to him I asked one of the employees if It okay to give him the food i got and she said Yes. 
    I left for a couple minutes and when I comeback my friend who was with the baby told me that another employee had huddle close the box where was the food, since my friend don't speak English she didn't understood what the "manager" said 
I ask the " manager"
And she was extremely rude!! Saying that she was the manager and she didn't told me I.T was ok, I explained that another person who works here told me I.T was ok, she yelled at me saying next time feed the baby outside and then come here. 


One I understand the every place have their rules, but I asked first and they told me I.T was ok, she has no right to be rude to my friend or me, horrible Treatment and I truly hope no one needs to go through this.
DEFINITELY NOT COMING BACK!!!
author: Jessica S.

description: They took there own tip they didn't tell me that they were charging the tip they lady then acted like she didn't know what I was talking about I don't recommend anybody to come here I been a loyal customer for several years I'm very disappointed and they also charged my sister without telling them about the tip and my sister also gave her a cash tip on top of what they had already took from her without letting us know
author: Vanessa H.

description:
Very reasonable prices for the sushi available here. Boyfriend and I came here and were stuffed at a total of $35...didn't even have room for dessert. Also happy that we were able to sample a variety of items whereas normally we'd order 2-3 rolls for a higher price too.

We came in on a Saturday evening and there was no wait, which does not appear to be the norm. We enjoyed pretty much everything that we pulled - no outright terrible sushi - but definitely some prime choices. Really enjoyed the rolls topped with unagi and avocado. Honestly, happy we ended up here over our original dinner choice since we were able to eat immediately and I was starving!
author: Josephine T.

description: My family and I came here for lunch after we arrived in San Francisco. The sushi was a little better than mediocre and I've had better at my local grocery store. WARNING: they use a LOT of rice as a filler. Many of the rolls on the menu and on the conveyor belt had imitation crab. I don't particularly care for crab because when I pay to have sushi I want the good fish. My family and I left five minutes before they were closing for lunch, and we saw them repurposing the fish eggs from the leftover sushi to use for later. I don't think that is up to code with health violations, and after seeing that we all lost our appetites. The only upside to this restaurant is that the prices are cheap, but now we know why.
author: Gabby E.

description: I have a really bad experience at this restaurant. The flies are all over the food at the kitchen, garbage cans are next to the open door where the food is prepared.  The staff is rude. I had to pay for someone's plate that the waiter added to the pile of plates for my daughter, blaming her that she was trying to put it back.
author: Natalie T.

description: Watching the sushi circling around on a boat is quite entertaining. The items they have aren't so special though. I wish they had more options to pick from the boat because they even lacked on serving the basic sushi rolls such as California roll or spicy tuna roll. Instead I saw a lot of fried items being served and edamame lol. Anyways I ordered the Caterpillar roll and it was really good. The raw oysters were soooo good because they had this spicy sauce on it! This place is good for a light lunch. Just be aware it's hard to find parking !
author: Kristi A.

description: OMG!  Excellent sushi boat place with nothing over $4 floating on the sushi moat?  In SF?  If I didn't experience it, I wouldn't have believed it!  It's the unicorn....  no it's the Sasquatch of sushi joints!  You hear rumors, but it's not until you see it that u nearly shat your pants.  Ok, lets move past the price point, what about food quality?  BROoooooo, they had sashimi floating around and let me tell u, besides the fact that there were 3 large cuts of fish on my dish, the fish was clean and fresh.  Had a great clean cut bite and not fishy at all.  Delish!  They remove trays that have been sitting around often and replace with something fresh.  Great variety from dragon rolls, unagi nigiri and clean cut sashimi.  Oh yeah, you can get a generous portion of sea bass tempura for like $5!  It's not a bougie, hipster joint, but it's comfortable, clean and the food is great.
author: Ricardo C.

description:
We sat down, enjoyed the sushi boat experience and thought the sushi was fine. Pricey, but like I said I enjoyed the experience until it was time to pay. 

My friends split the check and we all pitched in for the tip on one of the checks with cash. Then we thanked the waiters and were about to leave and I noticed one woman was checking out our bill and said something to her friend, then stopped us and said "uhm, excuse me! Somethings wrong here." With tons of attitude and we looked at her shocked, she said "Was there something wrong with service?" 
And I told her really annoyed, "No.. check the other bill" because she only checked one of them. 

I get people are crappy and don't leave a tip, but she didn't have to be so rude! Especially since she jumped to conclusions.
author: Katelyn C.

description: I was here last 2 weeks ago with my son and my bf  used to eat here because we like sushi. I won't complain about the food it was good that's why I invited one of my family to come while eating during the night I was there and I told to the waitress  in a head of time  that I have to wait for one more person that on the way from work to try the sushi too. but then after that I had a bad experienced with the lady. She  said she is the manager and owner telling me that I only can stay for one hour even though it's only 9pm and they were close at 11pm and I was upset when she said that even I ordered a lot and she made me feel I'm not appreciated and I asked her why I can't stay little bit longer if I'm waiting for one more person to come and giving her more business and it's not right to say that can only stay for 1 hour what kind of restaurant is that and she's started talking shit with her co-waitress using their language. She's rude.
author: Maria Jocelyn K.

description: First time had been here. It tastes fresh and the prices are very good but there not that much sushi in the convoyed machine unless u order it.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Sometimes you want omakase, but the struggle is real, so you go to sushi boat instead. 

Shawn C. and I always joke about coming here, we've passed by it 9473627364 times and counting. We finally made it here the other day, because who can resist a pair of salmon nigiri for $2?!

We came at 6pm on Friday and this place was poppin'. Thankfully, the wait wasn't too bad as people go in and out fairly quickly. 

+ Pleasantly surprised to see some unique nigiris floating around. We tried one with lemon and another with mango and they definitely have some good flavor to them. There was a really good seared one as well. Kinda sucks we didn't know exactly what we were eating but I'm sure you could ask..?

+ Salmon nigiri for $2!!! But you can't really mess up salmon

- Only tried one roll, the fried soft shell crab one and it was no bueno 

- bright pink maguros floating around.. EEK. Is it supposed to be that color..?

I'd come back for a quick, cheap sushi fix. Although watch what you get because the $3 plates will creep on you..
author: Laverne N.

description:
Decent boat place when you want a boat place and want the convenience of sushi at your fingertips.

Really 3.5 stars rounded down due to the small selection and crowded tables and hard to get refills of tea.

The food itself was decent and if you can wave down the sushi chef you can request things. The thing is he pretended not to see me at times, and other times he was ready to help me.

A passive aggressive sushi chef LOL.
author: Jack R.

description:
Wow, what happened to the sushi here?! We have been ordering sushi from here for the last 10 years. But on the last several occasions, their quality of sushi has really gone downhill. We ordered 4 orders of rainbow roll, salmon lovers roll, and couple of Cali rolls. Take out order over $50 for dinner.
The sushi was dry hard clumps of rice with no flavor and there were hardly any stuffing of crabmeat wrapped in the sushi. The tuna, Salmon,and sake were not fresh on top of the rainbow rolls. Really dried looking, you can tell it wasn't fresh. The avocado slices had dark spots all over it. More than half of our order was left uneaten. We were disappointed. Don't think we will be returning anytime soon.
author: Grace P.

description:
Great sushi boat place in the heart of Richmond. It's a small place but very cute. Many people come here for the sushi boat instead of sitting at the tables. The service is quick and waitresses are very nice. 

When you sit down you get a tray of ginger and wasabi and you choice of beverage. Then have at the sushi!! They have the prices of each colored tray posted in front of you along with other sushi you can order from the kitchen. The sushi going by you are very fresh! you can see them prepare them right in front of you. They also have many options to choose from! I always get the salmon sashimi which comes with 3 thick cuts of salmon. However, sometimes you'll just sit there until something new pops up, so you'll have the same plate of sushi floating around a few times before it's taken. 

Overall, great prices for fresh sushi boat that has a various selection!
author: Sharon L.

description: More like a 2.5, but I rounded up. Went on a Friday night at 9:30 pm. Restaurant was half empty, so we were able to get seats right away at the bar with the boats. The food looked pretty good as it was passing by, but once we ate it, we found it to be pretty mediocre. Maybe even a little less than average. The thing that turned us off was the temperature of the sushi. It was definitely warmer than room temp and the texture was pretty off putting. We decided to order rolls instead because we thought maybe we can try a fresh one out to see how it was.. our expectations were a bit high though; once we got the roll, the raw fish tasted pretty warm too and I was pretty disappointed. Personally, I won't be going back. Overall, the place definitely will fill your stomach up for cheap-ish, but the taste leaves a lot to be desired.
author: Gloria N.

description: The taste of this sushi is truly amazing. The quality of sushi restaurants varies a lot but this one is definitely towards the good ones. It's also very reasonably priced two people can easily feel full for 40-50$.
author: Norbert N.

description:
Been coming here for 10 years, I like the sushi boat you can eat as much or as little as you want.  The people who work here are nice.  Last night I came here and my friend and I were talking and one of the people interupted us asking us if the bill was together. She didn't ask us or say excuse me are you ready for the check.  

I like the catepiller roll, california roll with salmon, eel and crab roll and the deep fried ice cream.  The prices are inexpensive for 2 people it was 30 dollars.
author: Alix J.

description:
3.5 Stars sushi boat, rolls, and rice bowls. 

A San Francisco staple, my bro took me and the bf here. He used to come here over a decade ago as an SFSU student, back when the sushi boat prices started at $1. Now they start at $1.75 and go up to $3.25 for the sashimi plates.

We had the unagi lunch bowl which was a generous portion of rice and unagi. It was served with simple lettuce with ranch and miso soup. We also got 19 plates of sushi boat, with my favorites being the white tuna sashimi, maguro tuna sashimi, and salmon sashimi (seeing a theme here?). The modified California rolls (with crab, salmon, and/or tuna on top) were also delicious and more filling. The tempura rolls came 3 to a plate and were not that warm, but still good.

In all, for all three of us, with tea, the bill came to under $61 and we were stuffed. Not bad at all for random afternoon sushi for three on a budget.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
The Bune Roll was terrible. It was very dry and haphazardly constructed. For something incredibly simple (shrimp, egg, cucumber, topped with some bonito flakes and furakake), it took over 20 minutes to make with two total customers in the restaurant.

Some of the rotating boat sushi was decent but had definitely been sitting there for hours.
author: Jerry L.

description:
Very cheap for sushi boat! Most of the dishes I got were $1.25-$2.25 and that was about it. Compared to other sushi boats, this was definitely was decent quality for a low price. I'm not very adventurous when it comes to sushi so most of the things I ordered were mainly different versions of California rolls. For example, I got a California roll which appeared to have a ton of spicy crab right on top of it. I got a dragon roll and some roll w/ walnuts that was alright. Oh, I also got some edamame and tried this thing that tasted like a potato ball from Porto's!

It's great that they had tons of options moving around the boat. They were constantly refilling the boats when there very few customers so some of the sushi which were prolly sitting there for a while didn't seem too fresh. I'm not that picky though when it comes to sushi. If I'm hungry, I'll eat it. If you don't like anything they're serving, they do offer rolls on their menu (you can ask for small portions to try just like on the sushi boat)! These will definitely be more fresh!

We had about maybe 10-12 sushi plates and our total was about $28, not including tip. 

3 1/2 stars for this one! Wish they had more options though - they had nothing on their menu with baked salmon :'(
author: Sydney C.

description: Looking for a quick sushi meal that is quick and mediocre quality. Then this place would not disappoint. For the quality and price I would go somewhere else but we were hungry and this place was fast and no wait.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
I love sakana bune!
The service is great and the sushi tastes good!!
author: Candice L.

description: I was skeptical at first because this place was not my first choice, but went anyway because other restaurants was packed. The  lady waitress is very attentive and sweet! Food was amazing and the food was more than worth it for the price! Will come back again!
author: Princess C.

description: If I could leave 0 stars, I would. Extremely hostile service, very unclean, not fresh fish. Almost every sushi roll is with crab meat to mask the taste of over-frozen sushi. In addition, waiters will give you such attitude you have not even thought of! Extremely unwelcoming and mean. Good luck keeping up your sh**y business.
author: Valerie B.

description: Just so disappointing experience. I actually love the food, but attitude... We've were company of 9 people. 5 of us came while other 4 were parking. So waitress didn't allow  the fist part to seat while second part is absent. That would be fine, but she really was yelling, raised her voice, like we were some teenagers. But we are adult people with kids, who saw their parents being humiliated. Ok, once we sat, we asked for a high chair for baby. We waited for it for 20 minutes, so my husband couldn't eat as he was holding baby all that time. And than they gave us a check, where they counted cheaper plates like more expensive ones. And with all of that 18% tips were already included. So they just can include tips and behave with you like with s...t.
author: Olesya P.

description:
We were the first people in on a Tuesday right at 5:00pm for dinner, sat at the bar and started gorging on delicious little plates of reasonably priced sashimi, nigiri, and appetizers. The rolls are easy on the rice (one of my important factors)  and everything was super fresh and delicious (keep in mind, 5pm on a tuesday) and the variety kept everyone happy.
The soft shelled crab in the spider roll was especially delicious! 
If you're looking for a good, cheap place to get some decent sushi- this is@ definitely your spot.
Plates range from $1.75 (4pc california roll-$3.25 2pc fresh oyster)
author: Momo C.

description: I've been to this place for a couple of times, it's inexpensive and convenient. But I fell really sick after I had lunch there today. I have in upset stomach and I'm in pain. They clearly have to pay more attention to the quality of their food. This place just isn't safe.
author: Oleg K.

description: THE WORST CUSTOMER SERVICE I HAVE EVER EXPERIENCED IN MY LIFE. Do not come here unless you expect to be treated like you don't matter. Came in and put our name on the list. We were next up and lady continues to yell at me and ask if I was next. When I told her she was being somewhat disrespectful she told me she didn't care. I asked to speak with her manager and she said it was her. I was extremely disappointed and left after. Disappointed to say the least.
author: Skyler G.

description:
My family came in first and I arrived later. I asked the waitress if we could sit at the bar. She didn't understand my question and interpreted it as a demand. She came to us later and said, "Ok just wait and then don't have to annoy me about where to sit." 

In what world, is it appropriate to tell the customers to not annoy them when the customer had only asked ONCE?

I left and am not coming back. Food is good but your experience will be markedly tainted because of their customer service.
author: Leni T.

description: Beware-bad salmon at this place-I got sick after eating here.   Sushi has always been ok quality but serving bad fish hidden in a roll is not ok. Picture attached.
author: C H.

description: Cheap prices. Great food and no wait !!! Loved it and left in about 30 mins satisfied
author: Shalom M.

description:
Customer service was excellent and prices were cheap enough. The food was decent but nothing drool-worthy. I took my husband here as he had never eaten at a sushi restaurant where the food were served on little rotating sushi boats...it was more for the experience. Some of the food were cold and looked like it had been sitting there for days so it didn't make the experience any better. 

Don't think we'd be back as there other sushi places around our area. If the food were better, perhaps we will.
author: V M.

description:
Cheap, filling sushi at it's finest. I've been coming to this spot for a few months now, but held off on a review until I really knew what my true opinion was about the place. You all know that if you want top quality fish, you're going to pay top quality dollar. It's just a fact. That's exactly why you have to take this spot with a grain of salt and take it for what it is: a casual sushi boat with average quality sushi for a damn good price. Not only that, but I've never had a bad experience here before. I'm always treated well by the staff, and walk out satisfied. 

On my recent visit, I went out with a party of 5 for a Mother's Day meal. It was pretty crowded, which is how it usually is around lunch time. If you have a larger party, be prepared to wait 10-15 minutes to be seated, unless you're ok with table seating (but that's no fun in a sushi boat). The fish selection was less limited than it usually is, which was great. They had salmon, yellowtail, eel, hamachi (all in Nigiri) which was awesome. Sometimes it's a bit hit or miss depedning on if the fish has been circling the sushi boat for a while, and it may not be as fresh as when it's first put out. All in all, you'll always have something yummy circling around, so your tummy will be satisfied.

As you can tell, there's definitely drawbacks here, but the most important thing to remember is that this place is meant as a hangout spot, and you aren't coming here for a michelin star quality food. Pro top: the Sake here is really cheap and very good! Highy recommended on any occasion. Enjoy :)
author: Alex B.

description:
A couple of my friends and I (4 total) went to Sakana Bune hoping for an authentic sushi boat experience but the restaurant came up short. Upon arrival, we waited to be seated. The sushi bar was packed but we were seated within a reasonable wait time. We could have chosen to sit at the tables but decided not to. Thus, this review is based on my experience at the sushi boat bar. If you choose to order from the menu, your experiences might be different from mine.

After seated, we started to survey the different delectable items that we could choose from. However, it was when we started picking stuff from the conveyor belt to eat that i realized how deficient Sakana Bune was. The selection was sub-par at best and was severely limited by the inclusion of super weird sushi creations such as the "honey walnut prawn sushi". The unagi was, and my friend agreed, not the freshest and it was apparent when each of us took a plate to try. The sashimi was great but was sadly eclipsed by the inferior quality of the other items. The rest of the items that we took were the run of the mill typical sushi items.

At the end of the meal and after paying, the hostess informed us that she forgot to include in the bill my friend's order of softshell crab and my order of hot sake. The fact that the hostess went to each of us and counted each items that we had  ordered should have meant that our bill was accurate but it was sadly not.This is, of course, a minor mistake but I believe it is a strong indication of the attentiveness and the overall service that Sakana Bune has to offer. 

Though Sakana Bune is the only sushi boat on my strip of Geary Blvd, i have decided that I won't be coming here again.
author: Wing C.

description: The sushi here is affordable but me and my two friends had food poisoning the day after eating here. The overall cleanliness of this place is terrible - it feels dim and dirty when you walk in. Would honestly recommend paying more for better quality food and dining experience.
author: Vivian L.

description:
We went here for the first time last week and it was pretty great!
They had a decent selection of vegetarian sushi which I enjoyed, and lots of great rolls from the sushi boats! We got sat in the corner, which wasn't ideal, but otherwise we liked it!
My avocado in my rolls was a bit soft, but still tasty. 

They do have a limit on a card charge though, $20, and you cannot split a bill, so plan ahead!
We'll be back!
author: Larissa S.

description: Worth it. Just be prepared to wait for the sushi bar!! Staff is nice and helpful. Their oysters were spicy. The raw fish was on point. For the price, you can't go wrong!!  Enjoy!
author: Cee H.

description: Love the fresh food!  Servers are attentive and friendly. I will definitely come back and recommend this place.
author: Emelyn P.

description:
Do yourself a favor and DO NOT EAT HERE. The worst sushi and service ever. I don't usually write a review but this place deserves the truth. The nigiri rolls here is like eating a room temperature fish on top of tasteless plain rice. The sashimi were frozen when I took a bite. The maki rolls and speciality rolls were super bland. They kept bringing out the same kind of rolls and it was nothing new or exciting. Some of the maki rolls were out in the sushi boat for so long that you can see the seaweed turning brown and old. 

Aside from that, I was drinking my water and found out there was a dead bug in there. I quickly brought this attention to the waitress and she asked rudely, "so do you want me to give you a new one?" I replied, "no, but please let management know that this is unsanitary" She goes and tell her manager and her manager starts to laugh. I thought it was hilarious too because I see why this restaurant is the way it is. The manager then comes up to me and says, "look that's not the restaurant or the kitchen's fault". 

Amazing, ladies and gentlemen! 

Definitely will not be coming back for bad sushi and more bugs!
author: Angela Z.

description: Never coming back to this place, We have a baby and been here many times because we love the sushi but after today we are never coming back. My baby was sleeping we had him in his stroller and I signed in as usual I put for 2 people because Obviously my baby was gonna keep on sleeping, so we waited there for like 15 mins and when it was finally the time to sit down she said to take the baby out his stroller or we couldnt eat there she was being extremely rude and I said we couldnt take the baby out because he was still sleeping so she just said to leave and that we couldnt eat there !. I was shocked  because nobody have ever treated us like that at any restaurant so if ur planning on having sushi with youre family go somewhere else.
author: Karla M.

description:
A cozy corner staple of the Richmond district that offers sushi boats at reasonable prices.

The wait times can start getting pretty long during prime time but on any other night, expect to wait 5 minutes tops.

The seating is arranged around the ovular river that carries the boats of sushi trays that customers simply snag and eat.

The sushi here is not of the highest quality but is nonetheless really decent. The sushi you get is very enjoyable for the price you pay. There are tiers of dishes, with basic rolls costing $2 ranging to the more expensive dishes weighing in at $5. You can eat as much or as little as you like, which is the really enjoyable part; you can see how much you're eating and paying. Never ate anything here that was outwardly bad, only a few lackluster dishes. I would recommend any of the boats that come with avocado, always delicious. If you insist on eating fresh sushi, simply watch and wait for the chef to place more dishes on boats.

Great place to come with friends for lunch or dinner. Parking available along Geary Street or down the adjacent avenues.
author: George K.

description: Don't bother coming here. The fish is bad and old and stale and the service is probably the worst I've had in a long time.
author: Megan M.

description:
I'll just say right now... What the HELL PEOPLE?? Putting perfectly good fish on some rickety undercooked/ dry old rice! The sashimi were thickly sliced and good tasting, it deserves better than to be laid on a ball of shit rice. Have some pride, people!
The fried octopus was chewy and there's some weird plates like the reconstituted dried squid that tasted fishy, watery and yakkkk. I thought it was mushroom at first, that's why I snatched it. 

Next to finally, there were those damn girl waitresses that stood around yapping, paying no mind to customer service. Initially when we came in and there was a short wait for bar seating, I had asked one of them bimbos where the restroom was and she just waved her hand in a general direction. I said Excuse You? She said Over there. Fucking rude.  Unbelievable. Well, that ONE unisex restroom was occupied so I waited after the meal to use it..... Boyyyy, I would've walked right the fuck out had I seen what awaited me..........

That nasty restroom was a moldy, graffitied mess that looks like it's from some bad horror film. If I had my phone with me, it woulda been game over. No one will be able to stomach this place after seeing that damn restroom. GROSS.

Anyway, the sushi boat concept is actually great when executed properly. These people are going at your wallet without presenting quality. Geary Street has got no shortage of great restaurants, so don't go here. It's Japanese cuisine done by the Chinese. Probably. Very probably.
author: Helen D.

description: RIPOFF!!! I took my niece  there for lunch. The last time I was there it was good not great. But this time they pulled a switcheroo on me. I grabbed two different plates which looked like unagi with teriyaki drizzled on it. I bit into it CRUNCH it WASN'T unagi but walnuts with avocado and some bonito flakes for $2.50 not cool!!! My 11 year old niece thankfully did not have a nut allergy pointed out what if someone who did took the plate not knowing it was walnuts. Very irresponsible of the chef & owner to rip off customers. The sushi on the plates looked old not appetizing. I will not returning b/c of the bad quality & deception of their food.
author: Jo K.

description:
This place has always been childhood sushi boat spot in the city. I have seen the prices dramatically increase of the years but it all makes sense. Prices are still affordable compared to other restaurants. Something that i like about this specific sushi boat is that the sushi is consistently fresh and good.

Applogize for not knowing the actual name of the rolls but Some dishes i like getting are the potato hash brown, walnut shrimp filled sushi room, seaweed salad filled roll, anything pretty much with raw salmon, spicy tuna and imitation crab. Somethings i ordered the entree as well such as chicken/ beef teriyaki rice plates or even the udon noodle soup. 

Theres usually small to no wait but when it does, you'll be sat at the table instead of the sushi boat bar which is lameeeeeeeeeeeeee.

 Love it for variety, cute experience and the affordable price!
author: Auden W.

description:
Yes, most of the sushi here are California rolls in disguise, but I'll be damned if staring at a sushi carousel isn't one of the most entertaining things you can do while eating. 

I'm also a big fan of the fact that they do put out nigiri and sashimi, usually in quite generous portions, all at very affordable prices. I'm not enough of an expert to critique freshness, but the salmon nigiri I had was absolutely delicious. A few fried things were rotating around, too, but they didn't seem nearly as cost-effective to me as the sushi. 

I wish they took reservations, but oh well. Even though you may have to wait a while, I feel it's worth it to come during peak hours - that's when they put out the biggest variety of sushi/sashimi/nigiri! I know I'm definitely going to be back soon :)
author: Delia Z.

description:
Love going here! Where else can you find decent quality nigiris for less than $2?! Most of their plates are less than $2 in general though, so... that's a winner in my book!  

Whenever I'm craving sushi, this is one of my favorite places to go! Fish always tastes fresh and tasty to me (I'm not a sushi snob connoisseur though)! Variety is limited, but there's quite enough to satisfy my craving. (I find that it's actually common for sushi boats to not have that great of a variety, so it's not that big of a complaint there). Don't forget - if you don't see what you want on the conveyer belt, you can also just ask a waitress for them, and she'll tell the chef to make 'em! And if sitting in the sometimes-congested sushi boat isn't your thing, you can also sit at the regular tables and order/grab from the boat, too.

We have also ordered hot food (beef teriyaki, chicken teriyaki, tempura, etc) and my family loves it as well. 

I never had a problem with the service - they continue to refill your cup of tea, and if it's really busy, you may have to flag them down. No biggie.  

Inexpensive, fun, quick, and delicious!
author: Kris C.

description: Quite comfy went in alone and the server welcome me in. The food was good along with the plating. I was curious about a orange plate since the whole time I didn't even see one orange plate. The deep fried ice cream was a good treat just wish it was a bit more crunchy
author: Ricky L.

description:
If you're looking for cheap, decent quality sushi, Sakana Bune is the place to go. I've been coming here with my family since...high school and it hasn't changed one bit. Never got a stomachache eating here!

The pros: The ability to try a bunch of things! See something you like? Just grab it off the belt! The downside to rolls is that you're usually limited to just a few and then each roll comes with 4-8 pieces of the same thing. Here, you just pick up a plate that has 2 pieces on it and if you want more, just pick up another one. 

Also, you can't complain about the prices. The cheapest plate starts at around $1.75 and the most expensive isn't more than $3.25 (I think, don't quote me on this). There's nigiri, rolls (think Cali rolls and that sort of stuff), salads, grilled octopus, takoyaki, edamame, etc. 

The cons: While there's usually a good variety of things going around, it's always the same rolls. Recently they've put some new things out, but other than that it's still all the same things since high school. You can order a la carte, but some of the stuff they have on the belt isn't on the menu.

Things that no one wants kind of just sits out there and goes around and around and around. 

Bottom line: Cheap sushi that won't give you a stomachache. Why not?
author: Doris K.

description:
Service: 
Good! 
The lady who welcomed us on this cold Thanksgiving afternoon was so helpful since it was my sister and I's first time there. We asked to see the menu first before we decided to eat there, because we had walked into 2 other restaurants before then on the same block.The lady glady explained how the sushi rotator thing worked so we wouldn't be confused.

Food: (Price/ Quality/ Quantity)
OK.
My sister's ultimate favorite food is nigiri and she said the fish wasn't THAT fresh, and it was more like QUANTITY over quality because the pieces of fish were huge.
On the other hand, I am in love with unagi and this has to be one of my new favorite places to get it. foreals. Maybe they it was a good day, but every dish I got: from the UNAGI ROLL (I personally suggest getting it without cucumber if you want the roll to just literally melt in your mouth lol) to the unagi nigiri, I was pleased that everything combined so well in my mouth and that there weren't any traces of bones that I usually find in my eel. 
But I also got some baked salmon and that was MEH, probably been on the rotator for too long, and it lacked much flavor.


Also, the average size of each sushi piece on the boat rotator is MASSIVE and between the 2 of us we didn't spend more than $30 dollars together but I was so full to the point where I kept saying "If i eat one more I'll hate myself", but you know what, I still ate another one LOL. The actual rolls weren't expensive at all and comparable to other places (but definitely cheaper than a certain other Japanese restaurant on the same block).
author: Maiko I.

description: I love sushi restaurants that have the boats! I've been going here for many many years and although they're not the best and the parking kinda sucks, I just keep coming back. Whenever I'm in the city and I'm craving for sushi I always want to come here but I really don't know why. Selection is not too bad, if you go there close to opening time, you don't see the fried stuff till about 12:30. All in all, place is not bad. I know I'll be coming back.
author: Ada H.

description: Good sushi at a good price. I have been going here for years. My favorite sushi bar in SF.
author: Peridot G.

description: Dingy with somewhat questionable storage practices for fresh food (cooked edamame uncovered& unrefrigerated in a massive bowl out near the patrons for the staff to scoop out), sticky tables/sushi bar, and not really enough coverage by the sneeze guard...but it is really, really inexpensive so there's that.
author: M M.

description:
This is my go to place when I'm craving the sushi boat experience. 
The last few times I came here was on a Friday night, and waited about 20-30ish minutes each time to get seated at the bar. 

I like watching the sushi items go around on the boats and getting to select whichever one I feel like eating. If there is something that you want that isn't coming around on the boat you can always order it through a waitress.
author: Michelle C.

description: I love this place. Good, cheap, it's best to go as soon as they open. Regular customer
author: Genaro O.

description: the sushi boat idea makes this dining experience so much fun! there are a lot of options to choose from. you really appreciate each plate that is displayed beautifully as you watch the sushi masters hand make each roll. the sashimi is so fresh and just melts in your mouth! also got the chicken katsu; good price and very tasty!
author: Jamie C.

description: This place is ok if you are looking for Japanese food that isn't too authentic. They don't have any of the more special sushi items that other restaurants have. In addition, their fish is not the most fresh. I'm used to eating a lot of raw fish when i go to sushi restaurants and as a result of the fish not being too fresh, i didn't have any, just to be safe.
author: James Z.

description:
Just a quick rundown of this place:

-Service sucked. The girl basically just made rude comments like "not my problem" or snapped at me whenever I politely requested something.
-Not too busy on a Sunday around 2P.M., but if you're shoved in the corner of the boat rotator, you might not get too much service.
-Food was decent, too much rice (made it more filling in my opinion! 
-Very rude looks coming from the chefs. Felt uncomfortable for a long time. One chef was basically eyefucking my boyfriend for a long minute. 
-Gratuity service charge. Normally I wouldn't mind this, but in a restaurant where there is little to no service required... Pretty lame.
-Cheap food! Hence, the three stars. 

I would come back if I'm in the mood for cheap sushi and entertaining myself with the boats, but with the service (or lack of), I wouldn't recommend the tables away from the revolving boats.
author: Fiona H.

description:
This restaurant works on an awesome boat system. You sit on the Sushi Bar, grab the plate that you want, and then they compute your check by the dishes you have on your part of the counter. The cheapest is $1.5, the most expensive is $2.95.

It is quite cheap and the food is really good. Staff is very polite.

So, get inside the restaurant, write your name on the list to the right of the door, and wait for the wonderful feast.
author: Andréia S.

description:
If you want to get a quick and cheap sushi fix, go here. Sushi boat prices are the same as the other reviews here. Godzilla roll was decent. Nothing was life changing except the salmon sashimi and eel nigiri being really fresh. 

Workers don't speak much English so you have to point to what you want. 

I left feeling disappointed but you get what you pay for.
author: Linda N.

description: Sakana Bune is one of my favorite places to get sushi in SF! I've been coming here for years, and I've never had a bad experience. The sushi is obviously very Americanized, and might not be the highest quality due to the low prices, but frankly, it tastes amazing. I love the sushi boats, which are great, because I often find myself over or under-ordering when I go to other sushi restaurants. My brother who hates sushi loves their chicken teriyaki, and tempura! The honey walnut roll is delicious-I prefer simple types of sushi, so I'm a big fan of their California roll, sashimi, basic veggie rolls, and crab rolls. They make fried California rolls (not the most authentic and quite the indulgence) but they are surprisingly delicious. Their fried ice cream is also an old favorite-essentially green tea ice cream inside a deep fried cake, topped with whipped cream! Sakana Bune's prices can't be beat. My Japanese aunt, who is quite the sushi snob, wasn't a big fan of this place, but to my American taste buds, it's truly the best!
author: Carina C.

description: Good sushi at affordable price. After long days of work I like to come here by myself. There is something therapeutic about sushi rolling by in front of you on a boat.
author: Shane W.

description:
Not a good sushi place, unless you don't know what sushi is or what it should taste like. It's never a good sign when the entire restaurant is only eating variations of California rolls. I'm not knocking those totally...but come on. 

I tried some of the other stuff, but it was only just this side of terrible.

Oh, and the fish? It's sitting in standing water in its containers. You can see it through the glass on the left side (facing away from the door) of the convener belt.
author: Cori N.

description:
With the great Kitaro next door, Sakana Bune (Geary @ 21st) has only the conveyor-belt sushi rolls as attraction - the food is OK, prices fair-to-middling, but service is terrible: slow, unfriendly, diffident. I tried the place three times and had the same experience, especially tonight. 

I am service people's best friend because I know how hard they work and how badly they are compensated. I tried my usual friendly approach with the Sakana Bune waitress - who said her name is Rachel - even after she rebuked me for sitting down without the proper escort. Unpleasantness continued until I asked about the minimum-purchase rule for credit cards (not obvious until you're ready to pay, a small sign  posted under the cashier's desk). 

It's $20 although the 2010 Dodd-Frank Consumer Protection Act  (about to be demolished by Trump) set it at $10. I wanted to ask the manager about it, but "Rachel" said she is off. Anybody in charge? No, she said. As I left, I asked another waitress "who is the boss?", and she pointed at Rachel. 

If this was a one-off incident, I'd ignore it, but so far this has been the consistent "ambiance." At Kitaro - and other restaurants in the area - most service people are excellent.
author: Janos G.

description: I will not come back again, this restaurant is so so do dirty，the chef keep talking when they are making the food, I think they should wear masks. I found out there are some bones from salmon sashimi ,that is so terrible!
author: Sarah B.

description:
Turtle Tower was closed, so we walked in here on a whim. The best thing about this place is that it's cheap. The worst thing about this places is that it's cheap. 

The Sashimi Soba was decent, simply because it's simple to make-the knife work on the fish is bad. The worst offense was the sushi rice-just plain terrible. It surprised me at first bite how bad it was, because it actually made me recoil in disgust as it was mushy and flavorless. The second bite on a different roll yielded the same result. Not coming back, but they seem to have regulars here-good for them. They don't know what decent sushi should be like.

The service was pretty good, no complaints there.
author: Bor C.

description:
Another family favorite. We used to go the sushi boat place in Burlingame but they've gone down hill.

Sakana's prices are just right for us. Sometimes they don't always have what you want circling the boats, but you can always ask one of the waitresses and she can get it for you.

Veggie croquette is my super favorite. The girls love the tempura shrimp plate. My son loves the honey walnut shrimp roll. All very reasonably priced and delicious.

There are seats for off the menu order, but what's the fun in that. Watching your food circle in front of you and hope that the group sitting next to you doesn't grab your desired plate is so much fun, sometimes.
author: Dina V.

description: I'd some made it to the age of 51 without having had boat sushi. That said, my first experience with boat Sushi was at Sakana Buna, and it was wonderful! No, it isn't as upscale as a place where they're hand rolling and making everything right in front of you, but if you pay attention to what's going by on the boats and figure out what has been freshly made and put out then this sort of boat sushi is lovely. Also if you don't like what is floating past, you can simply order off their menu, especially if you want a whole roll of sushi to yourself rather than two slices on a boat.  My honey and I totally chowed down and got away for $53 including tip.  Definitely going back!
author: John G.

description:
Fresh, affordable, sushi boat! My favorite place hands down for sushi on Geary. The sushi boat is fun and leaves me stuffed every time. I can always count on fresh sashimi and other delicious sushi whether I come during lunch or an hour before closing. 

It gets busy on Friday evenings  and weekend evenings but the sushi boat is worth the wait. If you want, there's usually open dining tables with a full menu. They have classic rolls and be to boxes that are yummy too.
author: Mariajose A.

description:
This place has great quality food for a reasonable price! You can get simple nigiri, classic rolls, and some unique rolls like the honey walnut. 

I didn't know what to expect when I first visited with its unassuming exterior. But when I stepped inside, I was impressed. The sushi boat is pretty cool and makes for easy "ordering"...just grab whatever looks tasty to you. 

It isn't as trendy as some of the other sushi places in the city, but I don't mind. The fancier places are often pricier because you're paying for the ambience. 

At least with this secret gem, I leave full from fresh sashimi and without going broke!
author: Mel C.

description:
I figure I'll write another review because I notice I've only done 5 star and 1 star reviews, and this restaurant I truly feel is a 3 star experience.

To be honest, I didn't sit down and eat here, instead I picked up some salmon nigiri.

I'm going to sound a little snobby here, but its my honest opinion and I hope you can appreciate that. That said, I'm going to mention that I am Japanese and somehow that gives me a little more credibility on how sushi is 'supposed' to taste. I go to Japan often and eat at popular sushi places over there.

This sushi is wack...as another reviewer mentioned, if you know what sushi is supposed to taste like, you'll know first bite that this sushi is definitely not what a sushi connoisseur would consider good... At the same time, to be fair, its not disgusting. Its edible, and you have to remember that the prices here are very, very competitive. Even so, I feel like no matter how cheap, restaurant food has to be good, because if I wanted cheap mediocre food, I can make it myself or buy easy to make meals from the grocery store.

To go into just a hint of detail, the rice is really bad, not how sushi rice is supposed to taste at all. You would definitely fail a credible sushi rice making test if this rice was your result. However I disagree with some reviews saying the actual fish is good, the actual fish is wack too, not of any quality at all, but again, edible. If you don't know what better sushi tastes like, you could probably enjoy this.

I personally can guarantee you I'll never be back. Not because the place is terrible, which it is not. I think it has its appeal to the restaurant goer that can appreciate value priced sushi that is at least edible and even enjoyable in a pinch.

Service, from what I've experienced, is fine. I did not feel it was either good or bad. Don't expect great service and you won't exactly be disappointed.
author: Ken S.

description: Terrible service ladies are making weird faces to us and bad food and our food came crumpled up also we saw one of the ladies eat some of our beef teriyaki
author: Fontine D.

description:
I use to love this place. Actually the first time I came I really liked it. 
They told me to have all the sushis I like and the different ones I needed to go there very early. 
I could finally go back early last time and I wasn't impressed anymore. Idk if I just got too excited the first time I went or if they actually hanged something there. I went there already 4/5 times and I took it off my list.
Also they don't use real crab. Or at least most of their crab is fake which isn't good for you.
author: Bruna R.

description: Budget friendly, kid friendly, family friendly sushi restaurant. One of my family's favorite spots to hit up. In expensive sushi that fills you up. My kids love coming here all the time. A great variety of sushi comes on a boat floating in a little moat.
author: Tina L.

description:
My friend from Washington state came here for dinner on a Sunday night. It was very tasty and filling, all at an amazing price! Would recommend to anyone, and will definitely be back!

Service is also not bad at all. No complaints here.
author: Rosie O.

description: This sushi boat place has been around forever and was fine for the price, but lately it's been going down hill fast! The air conditioner has now been broken for over two months and it seems that they aren't planning on fixing it. Nothing like a place with no air conditioner to have raw fish sitting out. The better chefs are all gone and the sushi is now made by the sous-chefs, so it's really basic and poorly made. In a culinary Mecca like San Francisco, you need to either shape up or ship out. Pun intended ;)
author: Tasha B.

description:
*meow!* I exclaimed as I eyed the yummy looking sushi travel about in front of me. I had been to sushi boat restaurants before, but I had never been to this particular place despite it being right in my backyard! Decided to give a try! 

Quick service and nicely presented, very good prices compared to other sushi boat places I have been to! 

In terms of the quality and freshness of the fish, I felt it was hit or miss. Some of the rolls were superb, while other we're just so so. nothing was bad though! Everything was at least pretty good, and I know good seafood being a cat and all. :)

I'd say the big positive point of this place is indeed the price! I was stuffed by the time I finished and the end price was much lower than I thought it might be. 

Overall, pretty good sushi for a great value! 

*chirp!*
author: Jei C.

description:
10/10 phenomenal

You can see the food made fresh. They charge by plates, so it could get expensive. If you watch your orders, you should be all right. Service is awesome and the atmosphere and cleanliness is superb
author: Brian P.

description: I found this place on yelp I tried it last night and went back today for lunch. Everything is fresh more choices for lunch I now have a new favorite sushi place when I'm in San Francisco..
author: Sherisa W.

description: Sushi was decent and not overpriced, but I was annoyed that they have a $20 credit card minimum. Seems unreasonably high and I think is also illegal. They said they would grant an exception and allow my $18 charge this one time. LOL.
author: Geoffrey U.

description:
It's not quite the cleanest place, but it's cheaper than most sushi boat places in the city. The highest plate that you'll ever pay is under $5, which I think is a great deal. Most places would charge a lot more than that. I've only eaten at the sushi bar and I'm willing to wait because I heard it's not the same experience sitting at one of the tables. The bar does get crowded and sometimes there is a wait, but I never had to wait more than 20 minutes for a spot.

The quality of the sushi is there, you just have to look out for the freshest dishes the chefs place on the boats. It's a bit of a waiting game, but the payoff is there. Of course if dishes are out for a while, the fish is not as great and the rice becomes hard - so don't get it. If you like what the chefs are placing on the boats, you can ask right before and they will hand it to you. The only downside is that the rotation of the rolls is limited and they won't place out a new dish until the previous one is done. However, it doesn't hurt to request what you want if they have the ingredients available.
author: Ruthie D.

description:
Now that my kid has fully weaned herself from bento boxes and is a die-hard sushi fan, she and I have made it our mission to try every bune-style (is that a term?) restaurant we can. We enjoy the instant gratification of being able to grab whatever catches our fancy as it floats by on the tiny boats.

So far the various places we've tried have been almost neck-and-neck, but Sakana Bune pulls out slightly ahead in MY race (I'll let the kid write the review for HER favorite). The boats were loaded with a good variety of dishes and lots of nigiri, which saved us from having to ask for our favorites over and over. Most importantly, we found that the fish is fresher overall.

I also noticed that there's a much more communal feeling at Sakana than at the other places we've tried. It was easy to strike up conversations to the left and right. It was especially festive the night we were there because we got to witness a marriage proposal...unfortunately, I think I was the only person who didn't get to see the ring go by on its boat!

If you show up and there's a crowd ahead of you, be patient...we found that the wait time was much shorter than we anticipated.

In summary, we will be back for the freshness, the fun ambiance, and the reasonable prices. It's great to fill up on sushi without emptying the wallet!
author: Valeria R.

description:
Decided to check this place out because I was already in the area. So, I came in on a Friday night, 10 minutes after they opened and was able to sit at the sushi boat. 

I was disappointed at the lack of variety. It was the same rolls over and over again. The shrimp nigiri was alright. The salmon nigiri didn't taste fresh. Then I had some sort of roll with shrimp, but there was too much mayo in it. The best thing I ate were the baked mussels. 

Service wasn't the best. My tea was only refilled once and you really had to flag someone down to get their attention. 

Overall, I didn't enjoy my experience here because the sushi wasn't that great and the service was mediocre. I also didn't like the fact that they had a $20 minimum for debit/credit cards. It made me feel that I had to eat more than I wanted to. Don't think I'd come back.
author: Fallon P.

description: My favorite sushi boat spot in the city! Parking is always difficult, but if you time it right you can usually get a seat right away. I came around 7:00 on a Monday evening and was sat immediately. Service was subpar, took forever just to order a couple waters. However, the sushi was delicious. Tasted very fresh and not like it had been sitting out all night. It gets busy enough in there that the sushi is rotated often. They also have a very good selection to choose from.
author: Amanda M.

description:
I come here ALL the time because it's near my house. Here's the breakdown:

I come because it's convenient, fast food with medium quality.  The waitresses never smile and could use an attitude check. The variety is limited but their nigiri is top notch, and prices are VERY reasonable. Their rolls average $8-11. They have mochi as well- yum!

Come for a quick sushi fix without breaking the bank but don't expect amazing service. Cash only if the meal is below $20. They're adamant about that...
author: Stephanie T.

description:
The fish is good compare to the price but the roll's presentation from the Mexican chef ( he shouldn't be a chef if he doesn't learn the right way to make a sushi...) is not the way sushi should be looking. The rice is not japanese! It sucks! But overall it is good because it is Chinese sushi not Japanese sushi. 

Come back for another review: they should change the water that floating the boat every single day!! It's getting dirtier and Idk when was the last time they changed the water??
author: Jerry D.

description:
This was such a great date spot - you walk right in, grab whatever you want from the passing boats of sushi... Yes, boats... And you and your date each get to try one, then grab another one next time you see it. If it was good.

So fun. So much flavor and variety.  Go here.
author: Tom W.

description: A pretty decent sushi place, not especially authentic, but had a good selection for a decent price. I love their dragon rolls! Their sashimi is pretty fresh, but I greatly disliked their tuna sashimi. It tasted too fishy.
author: Ke C.

description: This is my favorite sushi boat!! I live thirty minutes south of SF but I'll drive there over a closer sushi boat any day. The sushi is always fresh and the staff is great.
author: Regina J.

description:
The boats on water go around and around.... Around and around....

Space is small. There can be a slight wait. Get ready to be somewhat cramped in like sardines! The ambiance is great! Clean, a little loud at times but chill. 

Pick a tray off the boat coming around. Depending in the color of the tray is the amount of it. How much can you rack up?! On average I spend about $15. 

At times what you're waiting for can take eternity for the chefs to get to or to make. At times it feels that the girls attending you are trying to rush you out. The little ice cream balls are $5 for two! Sheesh. 

Parking can be a pain around the area. I would have given this 5 stars but there are things that drop it down to 4. Who doesn't like boats that carry sushi going around in circles waiting to be claimed?! I come every once so often. I plan on coming with my friend to spend some quality time together. Get ready and get eating!
author: Ernesto D.

description:
Salmon, eel, shrimp, squid sushi, they're under $3 per pair!

I came here at least twice a month. I love how I feel informally at this place. There are a lot of Japanese sushi and sashimi on the boat, or you can ask the waitress for your menu also. The service is not perfect, but it's acceptable. For the GREAT price, I give it 4 stars!
author: Nakmuay K.

description: My husband and I love this place. We are fan of sashimi, nigiri and rainbow rolls and they are all made fresh and delicious. Couple of dishes like Edamame and the soy sauce itself are a bit salty to me, that is the downside. The ambient and the price are ok, staff is nice. The big trouble would be the parking there (or like anywhere else in SF). You'll need to arrive a lot earlier to find a spot which is close by. We were lucky to find a spot 2 blocks away after driving around for 30'. Anyway, we left satisfied and gonna come back when visiting SF again :).
author: Huong B.

description:
I LOVE this restaurant!!!  You cannot get better quality sushi for the price (or even a bit more!) anywhere in San Francisco...I defy you to try!!!

When you're paying $1.99 for a tray of two pieces of delicious, fresh, fatty salmon nigiri, or $2.49 for a tray of two pieces of hamachi toro (*drool*), you cannot complain!  With most restaurants charging 2-3 times that much for the size/quantity/quality, it is one of the few totally-worth-it sushi bargains in all of San Francisco!!

They also make a delicious Honey Walnut Prawn roll:  it's like the Chinese dish, Prawns with Walnuts, but turned into an inside-out roll, with seaweed, rice, avocado on top, and tiny dollop of that sweet mayonaisey sauce on top...mmmmmm!!!  My friends and I agree that it's the best roll on the menu!!!

The staff are friendly, immensely helpful, and your water glass or tea cup will never go empty!  We go there so often that they've made a point of knowing our names, our sushi preferences, and the sushi chefs know to put out the freshest, fattiest salmon when we arrive...very cool treatment, considering how incredibly affordable the prices are!!!

They are open until 10 pm Monday-Thursday, and until 11 pm on Friday or Saturday night.  It's not uncommon for there to be a wait on a nightly basis during peak dinner hours, but later in the evening, it's relatively easy to get seated right away!  And if you don't see something you love on the boats floating past, it's totally okay to order something off the menu, too!  If you arrive within a half hour of closing, there probably won't be much variety on the boat, so the servers will probably tell you to just order fresh what you want!

If you are planning on spending less than $20, BRING CASH, because they have a $20 minimum for using a credit card.  If this helps keep their costs down, I'm totally for it, but it's probably pretty helpful to know in advance!

This restaurant is fully WHEELCHAIR-ACCESSIBLE, including the bathroom, which is really nice!
author: Amy L.

description:
This place was really really good couple years ago. 
Went there for lunch with my friend today. 

Not a big variety of foods.  Thats okay - it was end if lunch time. 

But now I have diarrhea!! Never had it before after sushi.  Not clean place at all. 

Also waitress was unhappy with tip amount... What? Be happy what you got! 
She even went outside and asked what was the amount on check...

Never be back again! Thanks for bi***y waitress
author: Marianna P.

description:
It's a hit or miss...

I like how you get to pick the variety and get to "fish". but sometimes the sushi doesn't taste fresh.

Service is also a hit or miss...sometimes super attentive and sometimes you have to wave them down. Depending on the server, they might give you attitude too.

But it is decent and I like seeing what I'm going to put in my mouth, before I put it in.
author: Tammy F.

description: My friends and I just love this place. The boats are fun and the prices are just the right for their rolls. We've been visiting for years and have never been let down. Great staff that recognize us will greet us upon arrival. Our go to sushi place in the neighborhood.
author: Susan L.

description: This was my first sushi boat experience in SF, so I am a bit biased. I enjoy the concept of sushi boats, it's fun to choose from a never ending flow of sushi. I liked all the rolls here and different selections. The honey walnut shrimp was my favorite as well as anything with avocado. The rolls are delicious and obviously fresh because they make it right in front of you. They do get very busy, so my tip is that you come right at opening time to avoid the lines. The servers are friendly so make sure you ask for tea or anything else and they give it to you instantly.
author: Jaime F.

description:
I came here for the sushi boats! This kind of restaurant is a little harder to find, so I was happy to find one in my neighborhood. 

I came for lunch, and unfortunately it wasn't too busy, so I kept seeing the same foods come by. There wasn't too much variety (I ended up getting the same thing three times because I wasn't filled up yet.) But the price was great!!
author: Rachel H.

description:
I was searching sushi places where they had the conveyor belt sushi boats. First I couldn't find a parking in SF since it was Sunday Night (Good this is that SUNDAY IS FREE PARKING ON THE STREET) :) So even though we had hard time getting a parking space, it was worth it since it was free. 

When we went in there was a waiting list, like 5 people in front of wanting to seat in front of the boat. But I realized that even though people are sitting on the table, you can still get the dishes and eat on the table. But then what's the fun of it :) 

So we waited but not that long because the waitresses clean the tables really fast and efficiently. Furthermore, we sat at the best place which I think seating in front of the sushi men because then you can ask for the freshly made sushi right in front of you. Also, the freshly and just made sushi will be places in front of the moving boat first. Also, you can see how they are making and fun :) 

Cons: If you don't come on the right time, you will see the same food or sushi all the times over and over again, which I was keep watching the sushi men to eat the fresh ones. 

Furthermore, the waitresses were waiting behind you all the time so that if we need sometime, you will get it right away. I see a lot of people complain about them standing there, but I don't get it. Seriously, if you haven't been there, the place is very small and busy. They have to stand there to work fast and efficiently! 

Also, at the end the price was wow! I was surprised it was so cheap that's why I came here. But compare to the price, it is so better than going to other Japanese Restaurant and order two rolls. It is AWESOME and worth it try. I will definitely come back here no matter what!
author: Alice C.

description:
Not great, not bad.

Some of the sushi just sits there forever and they never take it away (I am afraid of eating 3hr old sushi)... They don't do a big variety on the belt, which is annoying.

As far as food quality goes, nothing was great.
author: Ninja R.

description: The best sushi roll I have ever tasted was at Sushi Boat Restaurant. This memorable roll was stuffed with a delightful umami walnut mixture. It was unlike any sushi I have ever tasted. Doused with seaweed/bonito sprinkles and avocado, this delicious roll was an umami explosion in my mouth.  Left me so satisfied and craving more!
author: Birdie M.

description:
This restaurant has a nice environment, sitting around the sushi bar and picking up whichever boat you please. People eating here aren't super noisy or rowdy which is nice. 

There are enough waiters to flag one down in case you want to order something off the menu. The waiter noticed that I was looking at the menu taped to the glass and asked if I wanted an actual menu which shows that they are attentive. 

There are plenty of seats so not everyone is squished together and tables if you want to sit at a table and order off the menu. 

Prices are cheap for sushi, but a lot of the boats that came around were full of imitation crab meat in it. You get tired of that after a couple of boats. Maybe it was due to the fact that I came between lunch and dinner so there wasn't enough variety. 

Overall, it's a good place to eat and I would come again.
author: Maybo L.

description: Great tasting sushi with lots of variety!! My favorite place to eat sushi in SF. Atmosphere is fun too.
author: Sam N.

description:
Kaiten Sushi is QSR type of food in Japanese.  Suppose to be very inexpensive.

This place fits the model.  Very inexpensive.  

The selection around the boats were limited.  Seem like the same few items on every boat.  After a while I asked to order Albacore Toro and Hamachi Toro.  And Unagi and Tomago at the end.

Overall, cheap to get full.  Not much umami.
author: Kevin L.

description: It's an okay place, always busy to sit by the boats - could use more variety and pay more attention to making the sushi more flavorful.
author: Sarah A.

description: This is one of my favorite sushi places...  The sushi (at least the sushi they put on the boats) isn't the best or most creative sushi in the city, but it's decent and you can literally be eating it within seconds of sitting down, and the prices are reasonable.  I also like how, with the boat approach, you can eat as much as you feel like without having to worry about over or under ordering.
author: Brendan B.

description:
Sakana Bune translates to fish boat in English and it fits the theme to the restaurant by having floating boats with sushi platters served in a round-about bar!  It is pretty entertaining to see what sushi dishes are floating and coming along your way!
