You would have to make a quick decision to snatch that platter up if you want it - just in case the people you are sitting next to, wanted it as well and there was only one of that dish left!  ...Well, of course you can offer it to them and order it from the waiter, which may take awhile longer to get.  I leave that choice all up to you!

They also have some dining tables on the side of the restaurant, but I do recommend to sit at the boat bar!  It's just more entertaining and special that way!  Do go during lunch or dinner peak hours even though that may require a bit of wait to be seated because there are more sushi and sashimi platters made fresh and more variety on the boat bar!

There is like one waiter taking the orders if you don't see what you want at the boat bar just because it is basically self-serve!

They generally make most of their sushi dishes on an average scale in terms of Japanese cuisine, but the upside is that it's relatively inexpensive compared to other Japanese restaurants I have been to!  

It's the cheapness and picking of sushi platters at the boat bar, that makes me continue to go back here again!
author: Tiffany D.

description: I love this place as it is quick, easy with decent sushi for the price. This is definitely not your best high end sushi place but a fun and reasonably priced place to enjoy a quick bite.
author: Emily C.

description: Great value! I love this sushi boat restaurant- they are constantly making new rolls to place on the boats and everything is fresh and tasty! I've been here a few times at odd, slow hours (a late lunch at 3pm, for instance) and the sushi boat rolls were still varied and fresh.  I am always stuffed and it is very reasonably priced. My husband loves this place also, and he is usually picky about sushi.  There is mochi ice cream for dessert, also.
author: Kari L.

description: AYCE quality of sushi but price is cheap, too! Not that many variety of sushi, tea tasted funny? I guess the Japanese rice tea was in the pot for very long time....cuz it has a taste of overnight rice. The good thing:  I did not have diarrhea from that!! Service was SOSO , no one bother me so I can play with my phone!! Even though price is very cheap for a sushi boat restaurant but I would rather go to AYCE if I want cheap sushi cuz AYCE cost me less money and usually more varieties of food, too!!
author: Katherine L.

description:
This is the only sushi boat place I will consistently come to in SF. The price is reasonable. Its not super expensive but that quality of the fish isn't top notch. I prefer this place because I can try pieces of different rolls instead of being stuck with just one. 

I'm not really sure how fresh the sushi is because it is sitting on the boat and you don't know how long it's been out. But I usually order the pieces I want and they'll usually make it. Rachael is my favorite waitress. She's super nice and always fills my water/tea without me having to ask. There are a few rolls you can't order on the little plates, but she always makes an exception for me. She's the homie (: Oh and this place has made me love oysters. LOL I've never liked any oyster until I tried it here. I guess they serve blue point oysters and they're perfect. They arent too fishy and are pretty big. 

I'd recommend this place if you want to try a variety of different rolls without having to actually eat the whole roll!
author: Kelly S.

description: It's a friendly, busy, crazy cheap place, with perhaps the lowest grade "sushi" in the city. Prepare for large amounts of fake crab meat and questionable cuts of not-so-fresh looking fish.  Didn't eat much, and wouldn't come back.
author: Nick C.

description: I love this place. It's a nice place to go and wind down and eat sushi. I love watching the boats go by until I get dizzy. Their selection of sushis are good. Prices are affordable
author: Paulo R.

description: I was excited to try this sushi boat restaurant with my boyfriend. We were lucky enough to get parking right next to the restaurant and got seated immediately. It was during the weekend and the place didn't seem too packed. The overall sushi was just okay. Although, you can tell that some of the plates have been out for awhile, especially when some of the fishes started to change color. The quality of the wasabi isn't too great, and I noticed that some of the wasabi and ginger have been out for awhile on the table. The variety of sushi and sashimi plates that were offered weren't much either. The waiters were attentive and the prices were fairly cheap, though. You pretty much get what you paid for.
author: Victoria K.

description: Service not that great. Food seems like it has been spinning around that river thing in those little boats for hours, not very fresh but I don't expect much more from a revolving sushi bar restaurant. Some of the rice on their sushi was dry, I assume because they left the items out for too long. Sashimi isn't fresh. I had to keep asking for them to refill my tea when it really should be their job to make sure my cup is full. I waited a long time to get my check. The positive thing about this restaurant is that it is cheap.
author: Melody L.

description:
I love this place , have been coming her for years, as a young child and now later as an adult. Love the variety of sushi offered on the boats and also the rolls that you can order if you don't see something you love. 

4 Starts because sometimes when it is not busy the variety on the sushi boats does not change much, but I guess you have to come when it is busy but then you risk of waiting to be seated.

The Staff is very friendly. 

Sushi is very affordable. Love the idea of boats and that you can get as many as you want depending on your hunger level. 

I would definitely recommend this place!
author: Anya L.

description: I love this place! Not only is the price reasonable but the sushi isn't half bad either. The service is decent and you just walk in, and the waitresses will get you a table or they'll sit you where the sushi boat is. Only thing I have to say is the fish isn't that fresh and you can tell because most of the fish that spin around the boat are dry. But if you're lucky you can get a fresh piece but all in all, it's a good affordable place to get sushi boat.
author: Celine C.

description: I recently stumbled upon this place and am so glad I did. They have a wide array of sushi and other goodies. Decently priced, good service, and delicious food.
author: Victoria A.

description:
Sakana bune translates to fish boat in Japanese. 

This sushi boat experience is fun, cute, and cheap. The sushi isn't out of this world, but it's not at all bad. 

My friend and I have been here too many times to count now and we haven't had even one bad time. Every experience was different though depending on where we were sat. When you arrive, put your name down on the wait list and check whether you prefer the bar, table, or no preference. We always go for the bar because that's where the sushi boats are! You can also choose tables and order off of the menu (if you don't like fun and cute boats bringing you food). The better experiences are when we get sat near the top of the U because we are able to grab the freshest plates! You can tell which plates have been sitting a while if they aren't as shiny or wet looking (lol duh). But the chefs do notice dry or unpopular plates and replace them with something new (yes I have witnessed it myself!) also if you don't see what you want, you can obvs still order it! Sushi boat plates range from $1.25-$4.25? No more than $5 for plates on boats. Appetizers and other menu items I'm unsure. 

Minimum $20 charge for cards.

It's on Geary so you know parking's a b*tch. I usually hop out of car and put our names down while my friend parks. The wait for a seat at the bar can be upwards of 20 mins so it works out. We usually go on Friday or Saturday. If you're turnin up on a weekday (daaang ok) then you have little to worry about.
author: Sheena W.

description:
So I've been to Isobune and Warakabune many times, which probably means I'm somewhat of an expert on SF's sushi boats. (Have not been to the eponymous Sushi Boat near Union Square, as I try to stay well away from that consumer-oriented Abercrombie hell - all signs point to "expensive"!)

So, my expert opinion on the matter: THIS PLACE IS %&^#@ AWESOME. 

The cheapest of the boats I've been to in the city, this place is located in the Russia-Pacific region of ethnic food joints. Usually, this stretch of the Richmond district is the place where I go to stock up on pelmeni and honey pepper vodka, but that's just because I can't find those items anywhere else, and the thawing pelmeni don't leave me with a lot of time for exploration. But this time, I decided to let those pelmeni thaw. And boy was I glad I did.

Here's the deal with your average sushi boat: it's either a kids thing, or it's an all-you-can-eat thing. This isn't a date thing or a "impress someone with fancy dinner" thing or even a "family visiting on vacation" thing. 

So first and foremost, it must be cheap! Because kids aren't gonna finish everything, especially not the crab/mayo-filled rolls. So if you don't want to feel like you're wasting money, that boat plate shouldn't be $5-6. Alas, that's sort of the ceiling plate price for the other boats. This place, on the other hand? $3 tops. That's right - all your delicious food is gonna be $1-3 a plate. I stuffed myself silly for $20 - in fact, I really had to try extra hard to fit $20 worth of food in me, as that's the card minimum. However, the deep-fried oysters, potato pancakes, and the promise of deep fried crab claws gave me a second gastro-wind (heh), and all was consumed. Sushi itself was alright, nothing fancy of course, but pleasantly "aight", which is to be expected for such a low price.

Atmosphere? It's a %$(&#* sushi boat. The waitresses were nice. The Russian ladies chatting next to me were boring. Not an overwhelming amount of kids at 5:30 pm on a Saturday. 

But yeah - all stars a go for the cheapest sushi boat experience in SF, which still retains enough of its quality and variety to satisfy all but the most seasoned sushi snobs.

PS: This place got grilled with two stars for a "wet pants no discount" complaint? Get real, scumwads. How is a discount going to dry your friend's pants any quicker? One of the more idiotic traits that defines "Americanism" is this amazing ability to turn any grievance into an excuse to leech money. Someone wrongs you? Surely their cash will make it all better! Oh, the cops shot your child in cold blood because his skin happens to be of an alarming hue...hmmm, maybe if you win the lawsuit, the big pile of money you and your lawyers divvy up will totally wipe away the memory of a terrible injustice - and the institutional willingness to cover up, lie, protect the ranks, avoid all responsibility... Gah... /rant.
author: Manfred D.

description: If you want authentic Japanese sushi. this may not be the place, but for fun it is the best. The servers will go out of the way to help. The boats are fun to watch. Mingle with the people next to you. Go early when everything is just put on the boats. Have some sake. It's a ball and inexpensive.
author: Me M.

description:
Pretty good sushi for the price you pay.  20$ minimum for cards, so heads up.  
Great variety too. 

I don't know what it is about this place but I always come back. 
The wait staff don't breathe down your necks, the sushi boats have ALWAYS been full, there are reasonable prices, the variety is great and the service is quick.  

Wouldn't recommend the deep friend ice cream, go for the Mochi ice cream instead. 

But it would be a good place to go on a date!
author: Laura D.

description: I love the concept of their sushi boat idea, it gives so many different options of sushi, and I like that they are small plates so I wont over eat or take too much to the point where i dont finish my food... I have that bad habit! They are pretty fairly priced and sushi is good, I love sitting at the sushi bar, seeing food makes me fall in love! LOL I just wished that this place wasnt so far away from my house, or i would come here once a week, you guys need to open on in the excelsior! =D
author: Jessica C.

description: Love this place. Rachel is the greatest! Yummy sushi. Reasonably priced! Could use more selection in the roll choices - but otherwise the coolest!
author: Brooke W.

description: Okay sushi. It's super cheap. Definitely better sushi boat places in the city. Not a lot of high quality stuff but good for a quick drop in for a cheap sushi meal. Stuff is mediocre at best but again at $1.50 to $3.00 a plate. You get to eat as much as you want. Good for lunch I guess. Don't ever make this a first date.
author: Elton F.

description:
Went here with a friend on Saturday night - didn't realize it was a place with floating sushi! everything was delicious and fresh and I love to be able to try a little bit of everything. the staff was friendly and the service was very efficient.  Our table had some of the floating sushi, tempura veggies, special rolls, and chicken and rice. Everything was great!

Note - you do have to sign in and wait to be seated. so be patient and enjoy!
author: nital p.

description:
Plates of sushi goes around on boats in a big table. Grab whatever sushi you want to eat. The cost is calculated according to the different types of plate. I think there were around 5 or 6 kinds of plate ranging from $1.25 to $2.65. The sushi was just ok. I had better ones. You get what you pay for so don't expect it to be very authentic. Little variety of plate unless you order a roll.

Service was ok. Water was kept filled throughout the meal. 
Unfortunately, 2 cups of water was accidentally spilled by a waitress and got my friend's pants wet. She was apologetic about it and offered napkins. Since it was a hot day, my friend just shrugged it to not cause a scene. Though I thought they would at least offer a discount for inconvenience. Also, I heard you can ONLY use credit cards if your meal was $20 or more.. really? Luckily, I had enough cash.
author: Tony C.

description: Super cheap but not fresh. Stuff was obviously left out since lunch and we got here at 8pm. When they switched it up and put fresh things out, they looked good. Staff was attentive and nice. Not the best variety. I'm not sure if I'll come back or not.
author: Lauren A.

description: I go once every three weeks. Best place in SF to eat sushi for a cheap price but very good quality rolls. I eat for less then $10 every time I go. My favorite rolls are the Walnut Roll , California Roll and Tempura Roll. The miso soup is delicious there. The best dessert they have is the deep fried green tea ice cream. The place isn't so big nor small. It can be perfect for a couple to 16 people maximum to dine.
author: Fatima A.

description:
my simple review:  funky old sushi goes round and round...  cheap?  yes--you get what you pay for.  Most importantly, the rice is AWFUL and the TEA tastes of soap.  Bathroom is nasty and the table/chairs dirty.  Major attitude from the "waitresses".  Avoid.

my artistic review:

We are all a mess. At the sushi restaurant. The chubby woman with her clung on son. He, embarrassed by his mother talking on her speakered cell phone, embarrassed yet defensive. 

The indescribable, indestructible gnats. Or, whatever they are. Disgusting little creatures.  Clinging to dirt, and food one after the other. My food.

The almost over the hill unmarried cacklers. The new Californians. Asian with a thick Californian valley girls accents. Unable to control their coughs dangerously close to the conveyor belt of culinary sushi creativity gone bad.

The waitresses trying to keep their dignity even though they have to use the same dirty bathroom I had to.   Wiseness in their necessity to get you out as soon as thought of.

Food that fills,  sans nutrition, albeit something that satisfaction runs from.
author: Max L.

description: My sister treated my son and I because he loves tekka maki and I love sushi.  He was fascinated by the boats so it was really cool to see him look at all of the sushi dishes passing him by in boats on the water. I would give a 5 star rating for the beyond reasonable price for each dish.  A 6 pc roll of tekka maki for $2??? For a mother who's kids can eat about 40 pieces of tekka maki for dinner this place is a bargain! The sushi rice isn't the best- i would rate it a 3 at best but the value is just too good to pass up. Salmon Nigiri for less than $3... the list goes on and on. If you are on a budget but want to get your fill of sushi go here. Our bill came to about $20 per person and we were full.
author: Tami M.

description: Alright, here's the deal. It isn't fancy and it isn't even that great sushi. Most nights, the seats by the conveyor belt are full and the wait time totally depends on whether college students and familes are done trying to eat more and more-- But the sushi is a good price if you keep track and it's a fun experience just watching the sushi go by. The parking is street only so it can be a pain sometimes but its on geary so its a good area. This place is great for first-timers but if you want something nicer, I would go to one of the sushi places in JTown!
author: Stephanie R.

description: I love this place, nigiri's are super cheap here. Some go from $1.50 to $3.00 a plate! I think the more expensive ones might go up to $4.95? but hey, that's like original price at most places. Anywho, whenever i'm craving for some take out and in the richmond neighborhood, I always order my fav nigiri: crab salad, masago, saba, salmon, tamago, unigi, hamachi. NOM. Oh, recent find, CA Roll, 4 pieces for only $1.50. ummmm can't beat that!! one of my favorite rolls here is the Salmon Lover Roll- it has of course salmon inside out, and... it has green onions and salmon roe topped over it. GAWWWWWLEEEEE :) definitely my weakness.
author: Cindy C.

description:
this place is pretty great.

It's not my favorite, but it's my most frequented due to the price/quality ratio. 
 
We always sit at the boat counter and pick what we want as it goes by. Efficient, cheap, decent.
author: Ash S.

description:
I'm not sure why I have this liking for sushi boat restaurants but I do because clearly the fish isn't as fresh but I do. I think its because then I can pick and choose what i want to eat  and how much of each cut aka my control freakish ways. I went here after seeing it pop up on my instagram and had a good experience. I went with a friend of mine this past Sunday around 12 and I got about 12 different little plates. They have a guide in front of you to show the price and each plate usually has 2-3 things on it ranging from $1.50 to $3. For the both of us, we only spent like $32 which isn't bad at all I thought. i got a nice variety of salmon, unagi, white fish tuna, and tuna nigiri along with a couple of oysters and masago. I thought the size of cuts were pretty good for the price paid. They refill the boats as they go along. There are rolls, cucumber salad, seaweed salad, sashimi cuts to pick from along with the nigiri. However, i did notice that they put out more of a variety as the lunch crowd gets bigger aorund 1. There were more fried options if you like the fried stuff. 

Service isn't bad either. The wait staff is pretty attentive and you get free hot tea. I also got a side salad but it was really just lettuce. It's faster too of course cause of no wait. They do offer a menu as well if you or your guests prefer that.
author: Tao Tao W.

description: Seriously tasty and surprisingly inexpensive.  I go here a lot.
author: J V.

description:
Guys, guys, guys. BOATS! There are literally boats on water here! It's not a sushi conveyer belt restaurant that calls itself a sushi boat restaurant to be chic. 

My review is biased because I've been going to this restaurant since I was a little girl. It's good for some things: sushi beginners, fake-crab+mayo lovers (they put it on almost everything here), kids, people on a budget. It's got two dollar signs, but that depends on your appetite and tastes. I can usually eat very well for under $10/person. I don't get the fancy sashimi because who knows how many times that's gone around and around.

Well worth a try, if you're around, but don't make a special trip of it. Also, Friday/Saturday nights can be a bit crowded. I'd recommend a different time if you'd like to avoid a wait and also sit at the counter where the action happens.
author: Diane Y.

description: Cheap sushi boat!!!!! Price was good, boats were full the whole time. We got stuffed for only $35. Legendary! Fairly sure it's our new sushi place. -One star for the bathroom that needs a deep for sure.
author: Ryan C.

description:
Pros: The price is reasonable, food is tasty (quality of fishes, wasabi, ginger are not top notch, we can see, but still tastes good), the Lion King Roll is something out of this world, wonderful. Staff is polite enough.

Con: I have been going to this restaurant for several years now, but I think they could improve drastically in their cleaning standards. Once, the tea cup was smelling of soap and clorox. Floor, shelves, all are not clean, nice to look. Ice box is not fine at all. Must improve on this asap!!!!!
author: Valeria S.

description: The sushi was ok, scale from 1-10 (10 being the best) I would have to say it was a 3. The cuts were decent, but the quality was just not there. It could have been that the fish on the revolving boats could have been going around and around. I ordered off the menu after my first for or so pieces. And still the quality was low. Surprisingly the waitress was great! If it was not for that, I would have put it at 2. I don't the we will be coming back to this place soon, lessons learned!
author: Stan C.

description:
This is more of a review for the service rather than the food. The food is Okay. Nothing memorable. I think the boats are what draw people in.

Anyway... the waitress was extremely rude. She is the sole reason I would never step foot in this place again.
author: Nona T.

description:
I'm always satisfied coming to Sakana Bune. There's not too many sushi boat spots, outside of Japan town, so that's a huge plus. This spot is perfect for a quick bite to eat. In and out. 

Yes, this place could use a makeover but it's not bad to look at. I come here for cheap fast sushi. The wait staff has been good lately too. 

I always order spicy tuna hand rolls. They never have them on the boat. The rolls off the menu are ok. I usually don't order them unless my friends want them. I'm content on the sushi boat selection.
author: Andrew V.

description:
It's like fast-food sushi (I mean that in a good way): eat as much as you want, as fast as you want, off of the ever-circling boats. This is one of my favorite spots for a quick meal.

Heavy on the "krab" and mayo, but it's good, and so quick. Sometimes the plates get a bit fancier, depending on which chefs are working. There are a few tempura pieces on the boats too, for variety.  Also edamame and cucumber things. This is the place for cheap sushi and sampling a little bit of everything.

I enjoy watching the green plate full of mini octopi float by, but have yet to actually try that one...
author: Kelly T.

description:
Every time I'm craving sushi and I don't want to try new places I go here. This is my favorite sushi boat restaurant in SF. It's pretty far from home, all the way across the city but it's worth the drive and parking can be a biatch but somehow we always get lucky.

Each boat ranges from $1.50-$2.95. Not too bad. Me and my bf eat up about $35-$45 worth of food on average. 

The food isn't 5 star quality, more like a 3.5, but I like coming here simply because there's always a spot for me to sit at the bar, the waitresses are super friendly, they always refill my drinks and give as much ginger whenever we ask, and they have a good selection of sushi.

I am not too fond of their sushi roll selections. I've tried maybe 4 or 5 different rolls. I'm more of a raw salmon type of gal but on their menu there isn't so much to choose from. :( They offer a salmon lover roll (I'm not sure what its called but it's shaped like a heart) I thought it would be great because it's salmon on salmon on salmon and its super cute, but it was just lacking something. I also tried their other salmon roll (i also forgot what it's called) expecting it to be raw salmon but it was cooked! Don't get me wrong, it tasted great but I was so sad when I saw that it wasn't raw. It didn't say anywhere on the menu where it would be cooked. o well. :/

I wish I knew the names of all of my fav. sushi from the boats so I could recommend them to you but I don't. So instead I'll just describe them. :)

There's one with salmon, avocado, and orange sauce on top, the inside of the roll has spicy tuna. It is NOMS. :)

There's one with a light colored fish, a leafy green vegetable underneath, and a lemon on top with i think it's unagi sauce drizzled? NOMS :)

There's the Walnut Prawn Shrimp roll! (OOOOH ^_^ I know this one!) this is great! & I don't even like avocado. NOMS :)

The Spider roll looks nice and tastes NOMS :)

The Tamago is always my FAV. My bf always makes fun of me for eating eggs. :D NOMS.

& if you are wondering, the oysters are on point! They drizzle it with i think, unagi sauce, sirracha, and a juicy lemon to squeeze onto it. (Well worth the $2.95? a bit pricey but i'll pay for one tray. NOMS :)

The only down side to this is that the tea is a bit flavorless. :( reminds me of cardboard but it's okay, i'll just choose to pass.

3.5 for food
3.8 for service
1.5 for presentation (they have gotten really sloppy over the years)
3.0 for cleanliness (the bathroom is floor soaked with water at times? gross.)
3.0 for prices

Which equals out to be an almost 3 solid stars. I still love this place but it could be a lot better..
author: April D.

description:
We came at 9pm on a Friday night and the place was rather empty. The sushi seemed to have been sitting on the boats for a while and didn't look that fresh. They tasted alright but not at the level that you would expect with respect to their price. I would like to come back again to give this place another try when the food is fresh. I had a minor stomach ache afterwards but I'm gonna assume that it's not from the sushi.

I did enjoy the overall experience though. I haven't been to a kaiten-zushi (conveyor belt sushi) place since I left Japan and it was exciting to enjoy such experience again. It's a nice place to hang out and chat with a small group of friends.
author: Aron Y.

description:
I wish I could give this place 4 stars but when your enjoying your meal the last thing you want to see is employees (especially the ones preparing the sushi) being unsanitary. 

The positives: good selection on the boat with good prices 

The negatives: it's a nice thing to keep the area you work in clean but it's disgusting when you clean an area with a sponge and soap then use a toothbrush to clean the same area.. THEN touch the food and fix the boat without changing your gloves or washing your hands.. 

Yeah won't be returning to this place..
author: Maybelle Z.

description:
This is a place to get a cheap sushi fix. Each plate ranges from $1.50-$2.95, which is the cheapest sushi boat I've been to. Recently went to the one inside Japan Town and nothing was lower than $3.00.

Don't expect world class sushi here. Salmon sashimi was very fishy and chewy. Not good. Not sure how long each plate was out there but the tuna was hard and dry. Best bet is to wait until you see the chefs put down fresh plates on the boat to avoid eating the stale ones. 

I'd go back if I wanted to eat cheap and quickly, other than that, way better sushi boats in the city.
author: Mark G.

description: There is great quality sushi here for the price. Sometimes after a long day of work I prefer the "no-interaction" luxury the revolving bar provides. It's grab and go at this place and usually I am never disappointed.
author: Paul G.

description:
This type of restaurant is difficult to review. Sakana Bune is a relatively small neighborhood restaurant that's been open for years. It's distinguishing feature is the sushi moat that dominates the space which is otherwise filled with a few tables and Japanese decorations made in China.

For anyone who doesn't know what a sushi moat is, a quick internet image search will rectify that and is easier than me writing a 1000 word description. Anyway, I came here with a colleague for lunch on 2/6/15. We sat at the moat since no one was sitting at the tables, even though we were more likely to order off the menu than pick up the little floating plates.

We ordered a Sashimi Combo with white rice, miso soup, mixed tempura appetizer, and yes, we pulled a couple plates off the moat. The Sashimi Combo had about 25 pieces (I can't remember the exact number) and came with the standard variety, i.e. salmon, tuna, hamachi, etc. Nothing spectacular. 

The miso soup was standard, as was the mixed tempura. Everything tasted OK with little innovation or creativity, except perhaps for one or two of the creations I saw on the sushi moat, though that was pretty much just making regular rolls spicy. And hence the difficulty of reviewing a restaurant like this. 

Everything here was edible. The fish was relatively fresh, the miso soup was decent, the tempura was decent, and the sushi was decent. The only real complaint was that they gave me an expired can of diet coke...twice. For those of you that don't believe it, yes, soda's do expire. It tastes like copper.

This is a neighborhood restaurant that serves the purpose of giving you decent food at reasonable prices when you're hungry. The check totaled about $65 before tip, but that incudes the 2 large sakes my colleague downed. The servers were nice and responsive, if unable to read expiration dates. And they literally kept the moat going for just the 2 of us, even though the restaurant had cleared out.

What else can I say? This place was decent.
author: N. C. L.

description: The worst service ever! As soon as I step in to joint my friend that were eating there for 10 mins already.  The waitress came up to me and said, if you are not eating, you can't sit there.  Omg did I not dress up right?  Since it was Chinese New Year I didn't want to start an argument, I politely replied to her, yes we are eating here with my friends.  No service at all, no napkins was provide.  This is the worst service I ever receive from any Japanese restaurant, ever!!!! Would not go there again, never!
author: Red Bean B.

description:
Came here with my family (5 people) on a weekend night at around 7pm. It wasn't super crowded. We had to wait about 10 min but it wasn't that bad. 

It's a decent place for sushi (boat). The prices are really reasonable and the food is alright. Not a lot of variety because the chefs only add new items when people take items from the floating boats. 

Nice place: not very loud, nice ambiance, parking can be a pain because it's on Geary.

Overall, a good place for sushi boat if I'm ever craving it. Don't come here if you're craving legit, delish sushi.
author: Michelle D.

description:
I like the sushi being delivered by boat and the service. I didn't like that most of the susi came with crab meat. The selections are less than desired.

I would've given 4 stars but deducted a star because there's a $20 min to use a credit card.
author: John M.

description: Just had some bad white tuna nigiri. 30 minutes bubble guts.  I've eaten here 50+ times. I called and she said nobody else has complained. Click.
author: Rob L.

description: Love this place! Cheap and nice service. I do wish they had more varieties. My daughter love choosing her own sushi instead of getting a whole roll. And it won't be wasted.
author: Maddeline D.

description: Always love this place. This is where I could find the cheapest nigiri LOL I honestly think unless it is a legit Japanese sushi place, you will NOT find a fine quality sushi in San Francisco. And Im talking about like $30 person quality, which means every other places in SF is pretty much the same.....(they all just buy fish at restaurant depot or something)  so why not ? I love this place for the price and the varieties.
author: Yumi K.

description: Cheapest sushi in San Francisco. Great if you want to eat a lot of okay quality sushi. I usually just eat a ton of salmon nigiri.
author: Tamara D.

description: I asked for spicy mayo when we first sat down but didn't receive it until I asked again a little while before we left. Sushi was OK. Cleanliness was OK.. I don't know if I will be coming back here for sushi any time soon due to the fact that the customer service was just terrible! :( My bf & I were having a date that day & he decided to take me here. We were considering getting Thai food instead but since we were already nearby.. We decided to try this place instead. A bit disappointed :/
author: Michelle T.

description: Fish quality is just okay, but for being relatively cheap and kaiten, I'll keep it at 3. Their yellowtail nigiri rarely comes out, but it's actually good. The rest of the seared/cooked fish sushi are pretty bland or tough, and the maguro is grocery store quality. Staff is very nice, though, and there are other random plates on the kaiten like gyoza which keep it varied, but if you sit there longer than 30 minutes you will rarely see anything new..
author: Ryan D.

description:
My fave sushi place in SF! And that green tea they have.. Mmm

That's the only place I found that adds walnuts and I'm in love. My friend took me there right after I got to San Francisco and oh my thank God she did. 
Can't wait till I'm back I the city - it'll probably be the first place I go to :)
author: Patricia M.

description:
* This is a review of the middle aged Chinese woman sushi "chef" inside the boat mechanism * 

It was a quiet Thursday night at the restaurant and my boyfriend and I sat at the bar on the right side by the bathroom. As usual, the waitresses were attentive and great! 

We were about done with our meal. I just wanted on last tuna nigiri, but the one that has been on the boat has been there for about 20 mins. It didn't look fresh. So I asked the Chinese woman if I can get a freshly made tuna nigiri. She nodded her head. When she was done, she gave it to me and it was a salmon nigiri. I told her nicely "I asked for a tuna, not salmon." Then she gave me this pissed off look and turn around the slammed the salmon down on her work table.

She turned around and started to make something else. Since then, she has avoided eye contact with me and having her back towards me. I was watching her closely to see what she does. Then she screamed to the guy to make my tuna nigiri. I sat there waiting for my tuna nigiri for at least 5 mins. All the "chefs" were making other stuff. Then out of no where, the Chinese woman said loudly in Chinese to the other Chinese guy chef, "EVEN THOUGHT SHE IS LOOKING AT ME, I'M STILL NOT MAKING HER SUSHI!!" Then 3 mins later, the guy responded in Chinese "Who wants the tuna?" The middle aged Chinese woman said "The one behind me." 

Yes, you read correctly, she just smacked talked in Chinese to a paying customer! How did I know about what she said? BECAUSE I CAN UNDERSTAND CHINESE!! You wouldn't believe how mad I was. I come to this place frequently and usually have a great time. 

When we got our check, I walked over to the cashier table and told the manager on duty about what happened. She apologized and told me that she will make sure that she will tell the boss. I sincerely hope that she will. 

Unfortunately, I will have to think twice about coming back to this restaurant. It just goes to show, one person/ "chef"/worker can ruin it for the whole restaurant.
author: Selina L.

description: Just found this place.  Price is very reasonable & food is good.  I like to come here & treat myself to sushi.  Basically stuff myself until I cant eat anymore .  I have not tried anything but sushi  here.  I like the fact that I can sit & chose my sushi.  If its really good, then I order a roll.....
author: Serg L.

description:
I used to come here every Wednesday with my parents to have lunch. Now I usually come in with my boyfriend when he wants sushi boat.

Recently they upped their prices what used to be a $1 dish is now about $1.25 or $1.50. They have a small selection of the special foods like oysters and things like that.

I enjoy having the california rolls, seaweed roll, and the california roll with the cream and seafood on top (I have no idea what its called).

The service here isn't that great, the staff there aren't very friendly and don't smile. (I like people that smile, lol)
author: Mabel Y.

description: I love this place.... my favorite place... I cannot stop to eat...funny to eat...fresh oyster... fresh sushi...Very fresh shrimp... so so so good...yummy
author: Nusala A.

description:
As far as sushi boat places go this place is not bad. 

Rather shamelessly owned by Chinese people so it's cheaper than other places including Japantown. 

Sushi is good for a sushi boat place and they don't frown on you for asking for more wasabi...in fact they give you enough for 2 more people when you ask! That's good service!

Only negative here is that parking is really hit or miss, especially on weekends.
author: Alfred D.

description:
I love this place. For a good, cheap, quick sushi, with great service...
it's my go to place!
author: Diana M.

description: Probably the best place in San Francisco for affordable sushi. I've been dining out at this place for years. I can recall when the California rolls were only $1.25!! It's not the finest sushi you can get, but it's the most decent sushi you can afford. If your looking for a sushi boat experience, then this is the place.
author: Mike C.

description:
First off, do not come here a few hours before they close. They'll be serving sushi that's been riding around the restaurant all day. It gave me a small spot of food poisoning.

The quality is what you would expect from the price. The selection is great. It's easy to get a quiet spot for a date or what-have-you. The staff is nice. I /did/ see the chefs taking the sushi off the boats before they closed and wrap them up, as if to preserve them for when they re-open. That's a bit disconcerting considering the pain I was in from my evening meal.

But hey, that's why I'm giving it 3 stars!
author: Sterling D.

description: For a place in the city this place is pretty cheap when it comes to sushi. my girlfriends and I come here all the time when we crave sushi and don't want to end up spending hundreds of dollars for it. Its basically an all you can eat sushi boat house, you sit down they ask you want you want to drink and you can just start grabbing things off the boats that you like. I love sushimi so I had a lot of red plates which are the most expensive and I still only paid about $20-$30 for 8-10 plates. So if you want to have sushi but don't want to spend a lot I recommend this place.
author: Svetlana T.

description: If you are short on time and need something in a hurry, this place is great. Sushi boats goes around and you pick which you would like to try. Great way to try a variety of sushi. If you don't see something you can have them make it and add it to the sushi boat sometimes. Prices are great. I have a teenager that can put down 2-3 roll at a time which can get expensive but with the sushi boat, it was less that the cost of 2 rolls. My husband does not eat sushi so he tried the teriyaki chicken. It was delicious however the portion size could have been bigger. We would definitely come back.
author: Sabrina M.

description: This review is for the sushi boat! Now there aren't much selection but for a quick meal, this place is not too shabby. The price is not too high but for about $20, you might be able to fill your belly! Remember to keep track of the plates you grabbed and ate, don't get too caught up or else you'll be in for a real surprise when the bill comes.
author: Keith L.

description:
Fun sushi-boat place in the Outer Richmond. The seating is %90 at the bar (obviously to get the sushi from the boats). We were packed in pretty tight, make friends with your neighbors because you WILL be rubbing elbows. The wait staff was attentive and due to the round shape of the restaurant and small size it is very easy to flag them down.

I liked that you could pick some from the sushi boat or order from the menu. Receiving out food that we ordered from the menu definitely took some time but was worth it if you want specific full sized rolls with more ingredients than seen on the sushi boats. 

The price was great for the quantity of sushi. Very casual and low key.
author: Erika B.

description: Great place! We are going to that restourant every week! Best prices and everything very very tasty.
author: David V.

description:
My friends and I actually wanted Thai food.. but when the nearby place was packed, we headed over to Sakana Bune.  The plates on the sushi boats were only $1.95 per plate.  My friend and I did some serious sushi eating, but ended up with 20+ plates. If you do the math, you'll find that a dinner for two won't hurt your wallet.  As far as the variety on the boats, there's not much (we were there at around 10pm).  They do have their specialty rolls, which are more expensive than the ones on the boat.

What I found kinda funny was that the sushi makers weren't Japanese.  We had question about a particular roll, and my friend spoke Spanish to find out what the fish was.  At least I was spared the embarrassment of attempting to speak Japanese.. college was a long time ago for me.
author: Vira P.

description:
I come here because it's fun to eat at a sushi boat restaurant. Besides, the kids love it!

Most their food is average, they have days where some ingredients are fresher than other days. It's not horrible tasting, but eating it once in a while is ok.

Overall, not an authentic Japanese restaurant, but it gets the job done.
author: Philip K.

description:
Disclaimers:
+Honestly, for arbitrary authenticity points, I mentally deduct a few when I realize a japanese restaurant is run by Chinese people.  
+I also have different expectations for service. In general, chinese restaurants tend to have a different style of blunt and non-sacchraine service.
+Whether Chinese or Japanese, it's going to be relatively pricey for small portions (as in compare to other types of food).

HOWEVER, this is the first Chinese-run restaurant where I walked out thinking "DAMN that was great service for an inexpensive delicious meal". 

+Food Price: Each plate ranged from $1.5-2.95 ish. They also had larger size rolls ($5-$10) and other slightly more expensive a la carte sushi that were not available on the boats ( less than $2 more), such as sea urchin and salmon roe. 

+Food Quality: We came on a busy Friday night, so it wasn't the same ol plates rotating around. I think as a general rule, if you are going to a sushi boat place, go at a busy time, so you constantly have fresh options. Also, I would also recommend ordering off the rest of the a la carte menu, they make it right then so it's for sure fresh.

+Service: Very attentive. Since we ordered from the menu, they came back to check if we wanted to order more and again to ask if we received everything that we ordered. (In case you were wondering, we def weren't high spenders or anything so it wasn't because of that we received extra service). Our hot teas were also constantly being refilled.
author: Jessica T.

description: Went in for a dinner with a friend and was amazed how rude and unprofessional the service was. The food is ok, this review is purely based on the customer service. I understand that sometimes when the restaurant gets busy you need to keep turning tables to accommodate other people, but what me and my friend experienced on a Sunday evening with restaurant half empty, was just beyond words. We were seated at the bar, and that's usually the most desirable place for a sushi boat place, after about 25 minutes we got approached by the manager Rachel, who was super RUDE and basically asked us to pay and leave because we were chatting with a lovely lady next to us and not ordering more food. In my opinion, whenever you work in the industry that is customer oriented, you can at least say that there are other people waiting to get seated and ask nicely if we are ready to pay or order more. And again, the restaurant bar was half empty! Very disappointed going through such an experience. Maybe when someone has such a bad attitude towards people in general, they should not work in a hospitality industry.
author: Yulia K.

description:
I am a big fan of Sakana Bune.  The sushi is really good if you are a fan of rolls.  Most of the plates are a variety of rolls.  The crab mix is good, and the sashimi is solid.

When it is not busy, some of the items can ride around for awhile, so it is good to go during standard times and wait for a seat.
author: Jay H.

description: Taste and freshness great for the price. I always go alone so I hate their $20-minimum credit card policy. Other than that it's great.
author: Shia L.

description: The  honey walnut roll is wonderfully different.  The whole baby octopus were hands down my favorite though.
author: Song H.

description: Decently priced sushi that is tasty and filling. A great option for budget-conscious sushi fans such as myself. I enjoyed it so much that I'm going back tomorrow.
author: Michael P.

description:
If you like an exciting variety of delicious pieces of sushi riding around on boats in front of you then this place is for you! What's cool about this place is that you can try so many different types of sushi unlike other places where you are locked into whatever roll you order. 
Here there are about 2 or 3 pieces of sushi per plate and they charge about 2.75 per plate so it's pretty inexpensive. They do accept credit cards but the minimum charge is $20 dollars; if it's under that they won't take the card, so its useful to know that. 
They also have a full menu (complete with pictures) so you can order any type of roll or whatever you want.
 I really enjoyed this place I can't wait to come back!
author: Courtney T.

description:
I accidentally deleted my old review here. But this place is awesome. All the employees are so kind and the food is fresh with a good variety. The thing I love best are the prices! The most inexpensive and tasty sushi I've found in San Francisco yet! I come here all the time.
P.S. my favorite server is Win! (sp?) She's the best!
author: Melanie P.

description:
3.5 stars, but I'll round up because I come here for sake (salmon), and so far they've done fairly well.

I love sushi boats. I love watching boats float round and round with different options to try a lot of different things in small portions rather than get stuck with one huge roll.
Their plates range from $1.95 to $2.95, depending on the pattern of the plate so take notice.

Here, I stick to the salmon, whether as nigiri rolls(2) or sashimi (3), I switch to whichever becomes available first or looks fresher. I've tried several others, but have been less impressed-- so I stick to what I know = SALMON.

BEWARE:
1. Their Crab Claw has ZERO crab in it. I took a bite and looked  into a huge white fish ball. The only crab in it was the tiny claw(with zero meat) which they stuck into a fish ball and fried. It didn't taste bad, but If I'm paying for crab and expecting crab, I better see SOME crab meat.

2. Personally I wouldn't order TO-GO. As I was dining, I watched a server take multiple plates from the sushi boats and begin packaging a plastic container with the already made sushi. I don't know if this was a one time thing or how it's usually done, but if you ask me TO-GO orders should be made fresh and packaged directly into the box from the sushi preparers. Just my two cents.

Overall, I'll still come here for a light meal if I want some salmon sashimi without paying an arm and leg at more upscale restaurants.
author: Jenna H.

description: I love the option of picking up what you like& seeing how fresh it is! This is def my go to spot when Im craving sushi boat! The prices are good and the portions arw reasonable. Todays selection was very limited though.
author: Nancy W.

description:
I have eaten here many times and have nothing but good things to say.  The seating along the boats is always on the fuller side, which is what I am looking for when going to a conveyor style sushi place - The food stays fresh and the dishes are continually changing.  The fish is quality, and the sushi and rolls are nicely prepared, and the value is excellent.  The dishes that come around are diverse - nigiri, rolls, katsu, calamari, edamame, and various other items.  If we stick to green tea for drinks, my fiance and I are able to get very comfortably full for around $25-30.  The service is polite, friendly, and quick to refill beverages, take any special orders, and bring the check when you are ready to go.  

If you're looking for a tasty, fun meal, or if you want to sit down and dig right it, head here instead of Japantown.
author: Virginia B.

description: I came here with my friend at 5:20 and sat inside before opening. And once it was open all the seats were filled. The sushi started to roll out and I was super satisfied with cheap sushi. They were very generous with certain types of fish like tuna. I enjoyed the quick service of the sushi boat. I definitely recommend this place for people who want some quick sushi.
author: Jason L.

description: This is probably my favorite sushi boat house I've ever eaten at! It's amazing and the staff are unbelievably kind; overall, it's such an amazing restaurant!
author: Angela T.

description: Took my sister and boyfriend here for dinner. Im very disappointed to say that our experience here was not satisfying. We sat down and they asked us what we would wanted to drink and i replied with three waters. She brought out one water and two teas. The first plate my sister picked up there was a long piece of hair on top of the sashimi. She put it back and we were going to tell a manager but one of the workers told her "dont do that again, your not allowed to grab a plate then put it back." For the rest of our experience, we felt uneasy because they were standing behind us watching over our shoulders.
author: Sandy N.

description:
This is my sushi to go place whenever I visit SF. SF sushi = better than SJ sushi. Sorry, folks!

It's fresh and inexpensive for the price you pay. Plus, it's a sushi boat so what's not to like? It is run by Chinese people, but service is pretty good. Sad part is that they had raised their "minimum" charge on credit card to $20 when it used to be only $15. 

Just come here on a super hungry day and you'll make your money worth of this place. Honey walnut roll is a must. Nearly every time I grab sushi from here, I go all out. x3
author: Josephine C.

description: Very good sushi.   They have a pretty good assortment that floats by you at the bar.   The best part is the very low price.   I always enjoy coming here.
author: Stevie A.

description:
Come when it's busy and you can see that they try really hard to make the sushi floating around fairly quick. People just need to eat faster. Grandma likes the chicken katsu (she's easy to please). So what if it's a bunch if Chinese people working in a Japanese restaurant. Welcome to San Francisco. 

Oh, and if it's on a boat and looks like walnut, don't eat it. Super sweet. Not my cup o' tea. So surprising I yelled in the middle if the restaurant how gross it was. Whoops.
author: Denise H.

description: I have to give this place a solid 5. Sushi is FRESH and price is SO cheap. Fried Ice Cream under $3 and service is A+. I love the fresh Oyster's and they replace anything that has been on for 20 min. if it ever makes it that long. This place is better than any Mikunis or Argiatos. I suggest going and saying goodbye to any other sushi place you go to ;)  You can thank me later!
author: Jess C.

description: I effing love this place.  It's super-yummy, affordable, inviting, fun, my favorite sushi boat place in the city.  I've been to others that are fancier, but they still don't offer the selection and tastiness factor that this place offers.  You can get full and have sake all for $10, or for $20 you can walk out of there hammered and so full of sushi you might explode.
author: Jonathan S.

description: I really wanted to give this place 5 starts because the food is absolutely good. However because of the poor quality service I gave 4 stars. Prices are reasonable.
author: Simge B.

description: My all time favorite sushi boat restaurant. I always leave happily full :D I have fairly simple tastes, and Sakana Bune delivers that and so much more :)
author: Fanny T.

description:
I like this place and so do my parents as we go there fairly often when we eat dinner together. For a sushi place it's really affordable and because it's "boat sushi" where you get to pick what you want when you want, you can eat as much or as little as you wish for for a really affordable price. I mean, when your regular nigiri tops out at around $2 you can't really complain. 

For a boat sushi place Sakana Bune's selection can seem a little limited at times, but what they do have is delicious. Their salmon (both nigiri and sashimi) and oyster ceviche are really fresh; their fried oysters (which you can get from the boat or order a full meal of) are flavorful, crispy, and juicy; and they have a fried soft-shelled crab that's quite good too. I tend to experience the small selection days on Wednesdays. I don't know what that means, but one can try going on other days. If you're going for dinner you want to try to get there before 7 pm 'cause after that time you may have to wait awhile but if you like affordable sushi that's good and fresh Sakana Bune might just be worth the wait.
author: Cass L.

description: The sushi is alright, service is not the most helpful or friendliest, and the bathroom is GROSS. When the food is all out in the open like that and the facilities are so poorly maintained, it makes me a little nervous about the food. I go here frequently for the quick and inexpensive food but I almost always walk away crossing my fingers I don't get sick.
author: K P.

description:
This is one of my favorite places for getting sushi. It's odd because the quality isn't the best and the prices are decent though not substantially better/worse then their competitors.

Maybe it's the parking and service? There's street parking all over and though the area can get crowded, it's not too bad. I've had a bad experience once or twice in terms of service but for the most part they're usually quick, polite, and friendly.

Some thing keeps me coming back here though and even though it may just be due to comfort, I enjoy it. Ideally this place would earn a 3.5 but unfortunately I can't do halves.

Could be the quick refills on the tea and ginger! That definitely deserves credit. Come here for unlimited tea and ginger.
author: James D.

description:
With the price you pay at Sakana Bune, the quality and portion of the sushi is worth it! I've been coming here for almost 10 years, and there was a few times when I came here at least once or twice a week for lunch or dinner. Addictive! The food is fresh, and the staff is very friendly. I'd highly recommend this place to anyone who wants to pick out sushi plates from the boat. If the sushi looks like its been sitting out there for a while, you can always put in a new order with the servers. The average amount of time I spend here is about 20-25 minutes -- in and out -- if there is no wait. Awesome place for kids and family dinners. 

Tip: They only accept credit cards with a minimum charge of $20.
author: Anna Z.

description:
Seriously? When was walnut wrapped in rice considered sushi!??! 

Bad quality fish and a joke of a sushi place.
author: Lily S.

description:
My friends and I always have the best time here! You just need to know what to expect. First of all it's not fancy in any sense of the word. It's basically a cheap "lunchy" place to go. Second of all, don't expect awesome service. Although the servers are always nice, they tend to hang out in the corner and often "forget" about you.

That said, I'm still a die-hard Sakana fan. It's a great place to bring larger groups. I rarely have had to wait for a table, and there's typically a few spots open at the bar. I usually just pick my sushi from the floating bar, but I've also had the tempura and mochi from the menu, and it's delicious. 

I went there last night for dinner and at the end of our meal they handed us roll-out Sakana calendars. Hilarious.
author: Blake Y.

description:
I have been coming here for years so I have a pretty large sample size from which to base my rating. The fact that I keep coming back says something about this place, and I wholeheartedly recommend it if you are going for the right reasons.

Sakana Bune is a low cost, high volume sushi boat bar. No more, no less. The sushi is good enough to satisfy that sushi craving and some, but don't come here expecting to be blown away with top notch fish. If you come here with that in mind, you will have a wonderful experience. 

My only complaint is that they seem to have a limited selection on the boats. Over the years it never seems to change. This may not be an issue to a new customer, but the same selection gets old after a while.
author: Derek H.

description:
So I'm working my way through my neighborhood joints that I'd written off years ago. This is another that I remember being pretty bad, but has a lot of good reviews.  Decided to give it a go again today.  Suspect may be a masochist.  Not sure why I didn't just eat someplace pleasant.

First impressions - cleaner than I recalled. I remember going here years ago and walking out because there was a dead cockroach floating among the boats. (... At least it wasn't a live one?)  They'd just opened for lunch, and even though it was early, there were several patrons. Seemed like a good sign.

The service was very quick, the hostess/server was extremely helpful and friendly.  I wanted something custom made, and it was clear the chef was not happy about it, but she made it happen.  The prices were very cheap -- I got 4 rolls for about $20, and the portions were generous.

Unfortunately the food was appalling.  Sake dishes were not edible (after a bite, I worried: is this going to make me ill?)   I had a couple of vegetarian rolls which are normally a very safe bet, but they were incredibly dry and not fresh.  The nori was really weird... brittle, smelly.  Even the ginger had no taste (and was extremely heavily colored with food coloring).  

No redeeming qualities... I don't care if a roll is a few dollars here, it's not worth supporting this business.
author: Heidi M.

description: I love the pricing, there fish comes in frozen from a major food supplier so therefor you are getting consistent defrosted affordable fish. The best time to come is during busy hours because they are refreshing the boats with new orders if its slow well then the items on the boats might be on a longer then preffered rotation. Great for lunch during peak hours. You can keep eating and eating and it wont break the bank.
author: Andrey P.

description: Came here tonight with my friend for dinner. The food is significantly better then it used to be which was a pleasant surprise. The price is great if you are looking for a cheap sushi meal. I'll be back.
author: Erica S.

description:
3 reasons why I would not recommend this place.

1. The sushi maker who was right in front of us, in 40 mins. NEVER washed his hands. He was handling the dirty towels from the other employees, wiping and refilling bottles. When one of the other workers asked him to make something, he just put down what he was doing and went straight for the seaweed and rice. YUCK.

2. He touched a dish of the raw tuna with his hands for no apparent reason, I think he was trying to take it off the boat? I'm not sure...

3. There are fruit flies flying around the boat and have seen some land on the sushi.

Needless to say, I was disgusted.
The only good thing about this place is that it is cheap. I had about 6 plates off the boat and fried ice-cream for a grand total of $20. BLAH!
author: Teresa C.

description: Came here because my bf and I were craving sushi one night. Our overall experience was great. The wait wasn't bad (10 mins) & the food was good. Since it was quite busy, the sushi was pretty fresh. Left paying only $40 with full stomachs ! :)
author: Sara L.

description: My daughter took us here. I have been to two sushi boat restaurants before and was not impressed. Sakana Bune changed my mind! We sat at the sushi boat bar and were quickly brought water, and dishes with ginger and wasabi. The offerings on the boats were numerous and varied. I was especially impressed with the honey walnut roll. It was a roll I had never had and it was delicious. I had a second of that one. The prices were quite reasonable. The waitress even offered to have them make anything we did not see. We saw everything we needed!
author: cathy s.

description:
[M]ona: 3 Stars
[W]ayne: 3.5 Stars
Average: 3.25 Stars

+ inexpensive
+ wide variety of sushi
+ good for large groups

- taste is so so

[W] If you're looking for a budget sushi boat, this is the spot to go. They offer a wide variety of sushi and if you have larger parties, they have separate tables away from the bar as well.  I like the one with the imitation crab meat and sweet mayonnaise on top while Mona goes for their Nigiri sushi.
author: Mona C.

description: I love this place! I've been eating here for the past 4 years and have never been disappointed. Service is great, sushi is good and cheap! Plates of sushi that cost about $5 a plate at other sushi boat restaurants is, at most, $3 here. And it tastes as good. I highly recommend this restuarant for good, affordable sushi!
author: Grace L.

description:
Sushi trains are fun. They are! I'm a little bit against it just  because it feels like I'm not sure the stuff up there is fresh, but at this place it is. And if you're still not sure you can ask the nicely to make a new piece for you. 

Besides sushi they also have some other small things moving around on the conveyer belt. I had some kind of fish souffle which was way to salty, so definitely stick with the sushi
author: Linn L.

description:
I come here with my family every now and then since we live quite close. The prices are fair for the quality that they serve, although you shouldn't expect anything fancy or exceptional - this IS one of those typical SF Chinese-operated sushi places. 

The waitresses all act like best buddies with each other.. It's pretty annoying to have to flag them down repeatedly to get them to do SOMETHING, because they're just huddled in one corner and whispering to each other... 

I wish that they would add more of a variety to the sushi boat! I see the same few variations of California roll over and over again, and what's the point of having the sushi boat if customers  have to order from the menu anyway?

But anyway, this is a decent place to go to if you're in a hurry and just want cheap sushi. Shimo a few blocks away on Clement (http://www.yelp.com/biz/shimo-san-francisco) is also decent and it's another go-to place of mine, although it's slightly more pricey, and their sashimi quality sometimes is a hit-or-miss (probably due to varying customer demands throughout different seasons of the year).
author: Charmian W.

description: Came here with a friend at 2pm on Sunday. Super empty, but the service was good. The sushi itself (from the sushi boat) was not inordinately expensive, but it also wasn't great. The sashimi tasted fresh, but there's not a lot of variety. Very meh, but I wouldn't mind coming back to just have a quiet conversation with someone and watch the sushi boats run around.
author: Danny C.

description: Felt unwelcomed and rushed. This place got busy yesterday and while we were still eating the waitress kept coming and asking  "is everything ok?" Onother word they were trying to kick us out to clear some area for a bigger party. My word of advice to this establishment is to treat paying customers equally and please stop asking that lame "is everything ok?"
author: Mark O.

description:
I go here pretty often with my housemate who is also a fan of this place.  We've actually been going here since at least 2004.  Yes we've been housemates that long.  You can't have your bar set too high when going into a place that serves sushi off of a boat.  So go into this place with an appropriate expectation.  If you do, you will find yourself surprised.  I think the sushi is good for the prices.  It's not the best I've had, but for the $1.50-$2.XX per sushi plate, it's freakin great!  I love that you can just go in, grab a seat at the bar, and start grabbing food as you will.  No need to wait, and the variety and cheap prices will let you open your mind up a bit and try some new things.  

Selection is good, and you can always order off their menu, which also has good prices.  Staff is friendly and is always on top of drinks and whatever other needs you may have.  Overall, I've been to a lot of other sushi places, and based on my satisfaction/cost, this places tops them all.
author: Evan A.

description: What not to like about this place? Plate of food on a boat goof around until it get picked up by hungry people staring at it. Well the food here is okay. They price is really good for those who like to eat nigiri. You can't be wrong here with their salmon nigiri for $2.25 (2 pieces). You have to watch for what they put out. If they are not putting anything, then it mean that the plate is old and it's just going around. Some if the plate is so dried up that you wonder why they just let it seat there. They need to take out the old plates and fill it with new one, so just get the fresh one that they put out. My favorite is the bake mussels even those it's covered with a spicy mayo sauce. This sushi boat is decent for the price you pay. The service us usually really good. They always fill your tea and water.
author: LZ T.

description:
This place has ranged from okay to good for me. I've been here A LOT and the sushi is never really consistent. Honestly, it's worst around lunch time. When it's bad, the fish is mushy and sometimes you can feel the texture of it been frozen. When it's good, though, you get decently fresh fish for dirt cheap. Again, the service is also on and off for me. The regular workers know what they're doing, but some of the other girls are completely clueless and ignore me if I'm trying to get their attention. Also, it sucks that there is a $15 minimum for credit card. 

Overall, if you know when to go in (dinner time), and know what to pick from the sushi boats, it's a good place to eat. Other than that, it can be more on the average to bad side.
author: Marlene C.

description:
This is, by far, the cheapest Sushi that I've found in the city that is looks (and smells) clean! As an added bonus, the sushi was pretty good. Now, don't get me wrong, you won't walk out of Sakana Bune saying,

"Hot damn, that was the best sushi I've had in my whole life!"

But, for 1.50 a roll, I hope you weren't expecting to. No, instead you'll walk out saying to yourself,

"Damn, self, you ate way too much sushi AND you've still got enough money to buy some other stuff that I like!"

The service was VERY nice and friendly (even when we waiting till after our meal to ask for a split check...I know, we're jerks). We waiting a while for some of our rolls, but they were pretty slammed and everything came out eventually.

I will definitely be back.
author: Max F.

description: BEST SUSHI EVER!!!!! BORN and raised in san francisco.... I LOVE THIS PLACE!!!! polite people and nice environment.. Recommend to go at night or lunch..
author: Matthew W.

description:
Another StokedCity staple introduced to me by my Dad. This is quite possibly the best bang-for-the-buck sushi in the country. The fish isn't spectacular, but it is wonderful, and the prices are absurd... $1 nigiri is absolutely ridiculous. By far the #1 place I know of to get my sushi fix, which begs to be remedied way more often than my wallet will allow.

Their yellowtail is great, and the white tuna and super white tuna I also find to be exquisite. I honestly do not enjoy their salmon, but there is quite enough selection to fill in the gap. In addition, their fried oysters are off the charts, be careful though, they explode with some scalding oyster-goodness when first delivered.

I have limited experience with their rolls only b/c their nigiri is so freakin' inexpensive... this is not a bad thing. Also what is great is that they put some very fun and interesting things on the boats that you or your guests have never tried, so it is a phenomenal place to freak people out or diversify your palette =)

I only ask that if you attend this jewel upon my review that you give up your seat at the bar to me if it is slammed, thanks for being cool.
author: Jordan Reis C.

description:
So first off I'm not hard to please... But when a couple of friends and i came here for an easy dinner a couple of weeks a go we received the WORST service I've ever had in any place that I have ever eaten in, the service here was so bad that it inspired me to write my first full yelp review.

The first time that we ate here we just ate off the sushi boats and the sushi was like most places on Geary, tasty but nothing special. So the only thing the waitress had/would be getting us was drinks. My friend picked out something from the boats that she had never tried before and it turned out to be really spicy so she asked our waitress for a refill of her drink and the waitress literally told her I just asked you if if wanted a refill rolled her eyes and grabbed the glass off of the table. Come on now totally uncalled for. Keep in mind that we hadn't even been asking for anything else! After that she wouldn't take card for one of us because it was less than $15 even though we asked when we walked in and we weren't informed of the minimum nor was it posted anywhere.

I tried coming here again with another friend and we had a different waitress and were still treated rudely and as if we were a burden instead of a customer, needless to say we won't be coming back here.
author: Dominique D.

description: Sushi Boat. You sit down and the sushi bar and boats are floating around in a circle in front of you. Just pick up a dish you want to eat and eat it. All the dishes are different price depending on the color of the dish and quality of food item or ingredients. Rolls, sashimi, appetizers, etc. A great place to grab a quick lunch for some instant gratification. We got a seated right away on a Saturday afternoon. Food is always available so just grab what you want. Not the highest quality but its instant, so there is a trade off. For what this place is, it's one of the best I've had in a while. A cheap, quick lunch. The bar is a little small but if you can get over that this place is the bomb.
author: Jeromy G.

description:
Like a lot of other Yelpers have mentioned, you definitely don't come here to get quality sushi.  Actually, I wouldn't even consider their sushi good and it's definitely not fresh.  However, this is a good place have sushi if you are hesitant to commit to one roll or if you are a broke college student (you can get little plates of sushi ranges from $1.50 to $2.95 a plate, with most priced at $1.95 each).  I used to come here a lot more often when I was still in high school but have gradually moved on to better quality sushi.

To sum it up, come to Sakana Bune for cheap sushi.  They also have some pretty unique rolls like the Honey Walnut Roll (tempura shrimp with candied walnuts) and the Fruit Roll (has tomago, pineapple, mango and cucumber) that are must tries!
author: Katelynn L.

description:
I've come to classify sushi restaurants into two categories: Sit Down, and Boats. Sit Down restaurants feature higher quality sushi, while Boats are more of an on-the-go option. This restaurant falls into the Boats category.

I've been here a total of about 10 times, but I won't be going back after my last experience. In my last visit I saw the kitchen staff snacking with their gloves on while preparing food... not okay. 

The quality of the fish is hit or miss. Sometimes it's tough, chewy, and looks like it's been making the rounds all day, sometimes it's fresh and soft. 

Consistency in quality and service is what makes a restaurant great. This place is just okay. They forgot to charge me for my $2.00 can of coke one time, and after already paying for our meal with my card they insisted I still pay for the can on my way out... Really, guys?

There's better out there.
author: Jan P.

description: The sushi was SO good (especially the Geary roll) and came to the table almost immediately after we had ordered. As we finished each roll the next would arrive, perfect timing. The only issue we had was when one roll never arrived and the server insisted that it had. She did ended up (reluctantly) bringing us the roll but kept insisting that we had already had it, which made all of us pretty uncomfortable. But since she did bring the roll in the end and (most importantly) the sushi was awesome and the speed was impressive, I decided not to dock a star.
author: Sophie K.

description: The restaurant is clean, service was ok but the sushi was horrible. We sat at the boat and also ordered and both were equally bad. Watching the way they prep also made us scared to eat. They leave the raw fish out! Most of the sushi we pulled off the boat taste like it had been sitting out for a while. I will not be coming back and dont recommend anyone else eating here. Also, dont get the 49er roll! It's dry, cooked way too much and the salmon looked old.
author: Jane P.

description:
I hate sushi boat places and I have no idea why I agreed to accompany a friend here,  maybe because I felt guilty for always choosing where we go and thought I would give him a chance.  Bad decision! 
the stuff on the boat looked old, tasted awful and the things i ordered off the menu to avoid eating nasty boast things didnt arrive until I asked several times...and was not good when it did. Definitely a "never again" experience.
author: Nilu r.

description:
One of my favorite sushi boat places to go to in SF!! They have a good selection and the prices are reasonable. Sometimes they will have the same kind of sushi floating around but thats why I order straight from the waitress what I want. 

My favorites are 
-Seared tuna nigiri
-Seaweed california roll
-Honey walnut prawn roll
-and the special roll (basically lion king) that they have.
author: Rosalyn T.

description:
Ugh...would not come back here again.  A few of us came here to eat some cheap Japanese food, so it's not like we had high expectations for the quality.  But even then, it was pretty disappointing.  It seemed that you had the choice of eating nigiri, or some sort of mayonnaise filled roll...and neither option was all that great.  I really don't think crab salad can/should go with everything, and I'm sure they can come up with some rolls that aren't variations of a California roll.  

But what really brought the rating down for me was the sheer number of little gnats/baby flies that were swarming around the boats.  I'm realistic about flies in a restaurant, especially Asian joints, so it's not shocking to see them.  However, to sit down and see that some fly is already sampling the goods before I have even snapped my chopsticks in half is just terrible.  And we aren't talking about one little guy now...we're talking about his twin brother, his crazy uncle, his wife, and that mother in law he can just never appease.  We ended up just ordering nigiri as we went, which wasn't all that great, but was admittedly cold and fresh.  Then again, it probably should, considering some of the pieces still had ice in them.

Okay, granted, maybe we came on a bad night, when the selection of rolls was poor and that swarm of locusts...i mean, flies, had just arrived.  I'm just not willing to pay to find out though...I'd rather just go over to Kitaro for cheap sushi (even if they aren't that cheap anymore), or Isobune if I want to pick them off a boat.
author: Mike L.

description: The best sushi boat spot I have been to!  It's such a diamond in the rough and a total gem.  Great service and cheap food.  Quality of the fish is great.  My first sushi boat experience was at Isobune in Japantown....too pricey and I hardly like anything there.  When I discovered this place, I was in heaven!! It's always our go to spot for sushi in the city and for an affordable price.  :)
author: Sheena C.

description: I just love this place. There are 3 sushi restaurants on this block and this is my go-to. First, $4 glass of wine, heavy pour :) The salmon and white tuna are always awesome and it's soooo affordable. Four pieces of California roll for $1.50. I eat lunch here at least once a week and can be full and happy for around $10. And since it's all ready and in front of you, no waiting means you can get in and get out. Yay, sushi boat!
author: Jenny W.

description:
This place is just average, nothing to rave about. I've definitely had sushi far better than this place. For those who say this is the best sushi place ever, you either don't get out much or have really lower standards for food. 

The prices are alright, not super cheap. And it's a sushi boat basically going around, so you can expect that some dishes might have been floating around for a while. I found myself only having to lookout for certain things, because I was avoiding everything that didn't look that great (which was probably a safe choice).

Overall, it's okay place I guess. I wouldn't mind coming back here, but not as first choice or second. Maybe not even third, there are plenty of better restaurants out there.
author: Harriet W.

description:
Disappointed...

Same price, smaller portions. What took 8 plates to fill me, now takes 10 -11

Service what great though!

Sayonara
author: Dan P.

description:
Eh... not crazy about this place at all. I took a friend from out of town here for lunch. What a bad idea. I thought the service could have been better.. they told my friend she only gets one refill for her diet coke. And It doesn't matter even if we spent over $40 for lunch here. The sushi on the boat looks like it had taken a few laps around on the boats. I end up settling for two sushi rolls ordered from the kitchen. The hostess kept asking if we needed anything else everytime we stopped eating and took breaks to chat. I'm not sure if she was trying to get us to leave, so she can fill our seats with the short line by the door.

Never again for me.
author: Tiffany E.

description:
I was very pleasantly surprised by this place :) I have another favorite sushi place in the Castro that I usually go to, but I was driving by Sakana Bune on the way home and figured I'd see how another SF sushi boat joint measured up. 

I liked that there was a lot of variety (I was so happy to see tempura, inari, nigiri, maki, AND sashimi, not to mention the specialty rolls).
