This is a great place for those who don't like the overly fishy flavors of eel, squid, or oysters and want a large variety of sweet, savory, or spicy flavors. There were many different variations of the California roll, which was perfect for my less adventurous roommate who went with me.

Best dishes were -

-Shiromaguro nigiri  (White tuna over rice with lemon zest. A must try!)
-Spica tuna roll with spicy mayonnaise
-California roll with crab topping and a small dollop of mayo
-Seared tuna with green onion
-Inari (tofu skin stuffed with rice)
-Tempura roll
-Cooked shrimp roll

I also highly recommend the plum wine (it was a nice golden color and very sweet) and the mochi ice cream for dessert - green tea, mango, and red bean!

We came on a Saturday night and were seated right away, which I was very happy about. It was also nice to see that, for how late it was, there was still a good selection. The server was very nice and attentive, but not overly so. And yes, it's true what they say, the pricing is what makes the place - even though I got 7 plates, a $4.00 glass of wine, and dessert, I only ended up spending $23.00 which is a STEAL for sushi boat.

My only real complaints would be that a) The menu didn't accurately reflect what everything was, so you had to either know or ask the server and b) it is IMPOSSIBLE to find parking by this place. I recommend taking transit unless you live close.

Overall, nothing profound about this place, but I will definitely be returning if I feel like I want to fill myself up on sushi boat without having to take out a loan. Good food, good service, and a great price. Give this place a try!
author: Casey G.

description:
I used to work up the street and people would come in asking where the "dollar sushi" place is.  Yah this place is okay.  You have $10 bucks.  You want 5 full rolls of sushi.  Or, you want to take a cheap non-japanese date.  Or, you're drunk and hungry and poor.

Honestly, you get what you pay for.  If you think that this is delicious, authentic, fresh sushi making establishment, I must say you are sadly mistaken and must have never eaten at a real japanese restaurant.

Extra star because when I ordered for take-out with my credit card the girl ran it even though I didn't order enough food to cover the minimum.
author: Kimiko Q.

description:
I've been hesitant to write a review on this place only for the fact this is one of weekly haunts - one that I wanted to keep for myself. I'm stingy that way, what can I say, I'm a fucker. It just so happens that other people are saying the same thing. 

So here's how it goes. Is it the best? Not really. But what's good about it is that it's consistant. I know what I want and it's usually floating in front of me. (I'm also a fan of boat sushi places, because I know what I want).  Another good thing are the prices, but that could get you at the end, next thing you know you'll have a stack of plates in front of you and you're gorged...and your bill comes and you ask yourself if you really ate that much. And you did of course because you're a glutton. And you're proud of that. Damn proud.
author: Ted P.

description: Sakana Bune is one of the sushi boat house establishment I venture to occasionally when that sushi bug inside of me itches. Their sushi r quite fresh and delicate. But I did come across a couple time some spoil dish. The reasonable price just make me stop having the hassle of complaining to management. Besides that and the zombie like wait staff. I did enjoy the food there very much especially their fat cut Toro sashimi and fresh Miyaki oysters.
author: Cam T.

description:
I stumbled on Sakana Bune as a wandering traveller in search of the way back to the freeway and battling an empty stomach. Sometimes, the best meals you can have are the ones you stumble on and don't overthink. 

The atmosphere is fun. The place was packed at noon on a Thursday. I have never experienced a sushi boat before and I'm completely enthralled - I almost don't think I can go back to traditional sit-down in the midwest anymore. What I love about the boat is that it got me to try things that I might not normally want to try in a restaurant and pay $9 per roll. It's almost like sushi tapas.

Prices are based on the plate you pick up (check the menu on the boat bar for a guide to prices). We stuffed ourselves and spent $15 each. Amazing price for the fun and the quality of the meal. If you don't feel like taming the boat, rolls can be bought a la carte. I fell in love with the honey walnut shrimp roll. You'll almost certainly find something you'll fall in love with too.
author: Jessica T.

description:
05.17.13 with 1 other

One of the few sushi boat places that is reasonable in the city.  It has decent sushi and great service.
 
they charge by the color of the plate that you take off the boats.  Overall an inexpensive sushi dinner.

You can also order by roll or off the regular dinner menu.  I stick eating from the items on the boats because you can eat a variety of different kinds. my favorite is the walnut shrimp roll.
author: Jay R.

description:
It was here at Sakana Bune that I developed my love for sushi. I know it's weird because their sushi is not award winning or anything, but for a former sushi hater like me it allowed me to slowly get accustomed to everything sushi (unagi, sashimi that melts in your mouth, that lovely burning sensation of wasabi) without burning a hole in my wallet. A good friend introduced me to this place and i remember the first visit being mediocre because i hadn't developed a palette for sushi yet. But those subsequent visits were what really made me a sushi die hard fan. 

Sashimi was (and still is) fresh, cali rolls are small but at $1 a tray i wasn't going to complain, good variety of specialty rolls and i liked the self service. The food was always consistent and prices were excellent. That was 5 years ago though. I still like the place but prices have gone up and the quality has been a bit lacking. The same friend and I used to frequent this place at least once a month or more, but we haven't come back here for a while. The prices are still reasonable compared to other sushi boat joints but I miss the days when cali rolls were $1 a tray. 

Long story short: sushi is consistent, fresh sashimi, good prices, good service!
author: Queena T.

description:
I love this place!  I've been coming here for about 10 years and I drive clear across town to eat here when I'm craving sushi.  

Reason #1: Sushi boats!  Apparently, I'm easily entertained but I love watching the boats go around.  Plus I love being able to try a variety of things or satisfy whatever sushi whim I happen to be having at that moment.  

Reason #2: Price!   I can stuff myself silly for less than $20 .  Where else can you do that with sushi?  And I've always found the fish here to be fresh and tasty.

It's also a great place to bring friends if you can sit at the bar.  Oh, and the waitresses have never been anything but friendly and prompt, I don't know what these other folks are talking about.

If you come on a Thursday or Friday night, you will have to put your name on the list and wait.
author: Ginger L.

description: I have been here numerous amounts of time. Each time we come here its just to fix our sushi cravings and not necessarily because the sushi is amazing or anything. Its cheap, its fast (comes out on boats), and curbs your craving. There isn't exactly anything to write home about here but you get what you pay for. The greatest part is watching the boats go round and round and you hope to see a collision with pieces of sushi fall overboard...I have yet to see it happen. But those who are patient are rewarded! Anyway, sushi is OK and the price point cannot be beaten. Try it out if you arent a sushi snob and need a quick fix.
author: Michelle I.

description:
As someone who has a hard time committing to any one dish, Bune and I were meant to be long-lasting friends.

Thus, my love for bune (sushi boat) places began here. That was back when the Cali roll orders (4) were just a dollar. Prices have gone up a bit, but they're still cheaper than alot of the other bune places I've gone to. That's probably because Sakana Bune offers more affordable and somewhat less adventurous options than other places, but it works for days when I only want to spend $10. It can get pretty full, but I've never had to wait more than 5 minutes for a seat. It's like fast food sushi :)

The worst thing about this place is parking. MY GOODNESS. I once spent 25 minutes circling a 5 block radius before I gave up and went to Sushi Raw. There's a metered parking lot across the street - if you're lucky, you might find a spot there.

But that's okay though Sakana, you're still my Bu(ne).
author: Mariela D.

description: I come to this place at least once a month with my family. They are great. I like to wait until the chef puts down the plates on the boat, that way the rolls and fish are super fresh and haven't been floating.  Nigiri is really good and the price is so worth it. The service is good too. It's super casual, and a great place to get lunch and dinner.
author: Luba R.

description:
It's not my favorite place to go to. I am a great fan of sushi and I decided to try this place out. I've been here several times, but one time I found a dead fly in my salmon sashimi. It was disgusting. So my rating went down. Plus, the bathroom is not what you would call, clean. 

 But still, like I said, I love sushi and I really love sushi boat restaurants.
author: Alexandra A.

description:
The service, food and atmosphere of this place used to be wonderful. I would come here often for lunch with my friends/family; now, all I want to do is completely avoid this place. 

The food was poorly made as if the chefs didn't have a passion for cooking anymore. The same plats of sushi and baskets of edamame on the boats floated past me a good 15-20 times.

The last two times that I did decide to come to this place (I can't even remember the reason why I went a 2nd time!) to grab a quick lunch all I could remember was the terrible sushi & nonchalant attitudes of the waitresses. One of the waitresses even said, "Oh, you didn't put enough tip down for me." REALLY?! Completely outrageous.

If you want sushi, please go elsewhere. Sakana isn't worth your salt.
author: Carol L.

description:
Don't you hate it when you're waiting for a particular dish and after what seems like eons and 20 rotations, it doesn't appear so you settle for something else... ONLY to see it sail in front of you by the time you've set down your other plate. 

Happens every time....

It's not the best but I like the sushi boats because I'm the type that prefers to have a little bit of everything.
author: Annie L.

description:
The good part is the price, you can't really get sushi for any cheaper. Unfortunately, the quality is predictably poor, and the service is even worse. 

After going in a half hour before closing to get in a quick dinner, they immediately announced last call upon seating. Not only that, they took all the plates off of the buffet track (before closing, mind you), and began eating it themselves on a table! During this odd and incredibly unprofessional behavior, I asked a worker if I could have one of the plates to eat because I had meant to grab it before getting intercepted by a worker, and she gave me an attitude as if I was eating her food! Needless to say, no tip and no return back.
author: Barrett I.

description:
Everytime I go to Sakana Bune, it's with my sister. When I want good sushi, I come here. Sushi Raw by my house does NOT compare. 

The set up is exactly like the sushi house in Japantown but they have high chairs. And Japantown's sushi house is a ripoff and isn't as good.

I'm not sure of all the names of their sushi but my favorite has to be the Honey Walnut Roll.. so amazing! I could eat these for, ever. You HAVE to just remember the name of, lol it's that good. Maybe because I'm already a fan of honey walnut shrimp, but it's exactly the same but in a roll (including the rice and seaweed wrap) with avocado added to it. Sadly, during the endless boat roundabouts, I was only able to see two Honey Walnut rolls, so we had to order two more.. haha.

I'm craving it right now just talking about it!
author: Jessica R.

description:
YOU'RE WASTING YOUR MONEY IF YOU WANT A MEAL HERE!!!

I've been here a few times over the years from friend suggestions and some of my team mates... Sakabune charges you by the plate depending on which nigiri tray you take from their floating boats. The only food I ate there was the salmon sashimi or the salmon nigiri and that would be it. 

You don't really get what you pay for. I'm a big eater, so coming here for me would just run up the f*cking bill. The food isn't always the freshest either. 

Service..oh man..

When I ran out of wasabi or ginger all those times, I would ask a waitress and they never refilled it. So shady..It was the same with my tea. The tea was always so bland..

Just to screw with them one time, I brought my own genmai cha tea bag and dumped it in there. Problem solved. They never refilled my tea cup after I did that..ugh..

By the way, the dudes handling the food in the center of the merry go round of boats never washed their hands.Here we were, group of 10 people piling up on plates and then noticed one of the sushi chefs scratch his head and didnt bother washing his hands.  I felt sick when I saw that. Looked at my empty plates, then my team mates and back at my plates. Not a good feeling..


Sorry Sakabune, ya just couldn't cut it for me..
A least next time, wash yo hands, get some fresher fish, and swat those flies if you can!
author: Jason C. J.

description:
Sakana Bune is one of those few and rare restaurants that do sushi on floating rotating boat. The sushi rolls or nigiri pieces are on different plates that are on floating boats, which goes around the table. The plates each have their own category of prices that can range from 1.50 to 4.50. The service doesn't really do anything except get drinks and desserts for you since it's mostly a self serve kind of place. Grab the plate from the boat, eat the sushi, and leave the plate on the table. Don't put it back! That will be such a new person kind of fail to do. It's really funny when it happens but it does happen once in a while with new people. After you're finished, the waitress totals up what you've eaten by the stack of plates on your table.

The tricky part of sushi boating is what to pick. There are some things that are not worth it such as scrambled egg nigiri or the kappa roll, which isn't worth getting. Then there's the question of how long has this been sitting here and going around. There are some unpopular dishes that never gets picked and may have been sitting there for an hour or so.  I find the best places to sit for these thing are at the end of the table where the sushi chef will place new sushi plates onto the boats. That means you'll get first picks and they'll be fresh for sure. The most awful place to be stuck sitting at is the middle of the table which is the bottom of the U part. This area gets last picks after everyone.

The sushi quality is is decent and choices are pretty large. Don't except mouth watering good sushi here. It's more of the cheap sushi that tastes okay. There's mostly traditional sushi that's on the boats so there will be tuna nigiri, salmon nigiri, eel nigiri, etc. There's a separate menu they have for dinner meals such as teriyaki beef and another menu for special sushi rolls like dragon roll. 

Overall, it's a cheap sushi place that has a nice boat thing going on that makes it more fun.
author: Steven B.

description: For a long time Isobune in jtown was the only sushi boat place I've been to.  I think this place is going to be my new go-to place for sushi boat.  The portions are smaller than Isobune's which is good because you can try more variety and if you happen to choose a bad plate you're not stuck having to eat a large portion of it.  But even better is that it is much CHEAPER!  Not only do the plates range from $1.50 to $2.95, but you can find plenty of good decent plates in the lower end of that range.  At Isobune it's hard to find anything good under $4.  The bad thing was there wasn't any sashimi only plates on the boats.  I was getting tired of eating all the rice from the rolls and stuff.  I guess you can probably order it but it's not even on the display menu - I don't like having to ask "how much" before ordering.  Also I had quite a long wait (though it was a Friday night).  I saw two seats were empty but the staff was obviously waiting for the people next to those empty seats to leave so they can seat a party of five.  Not a good idea for big groups to dine at a sushi boat place.  I wish they set limits on party size.  All in all, it was worth the wait.
author: Nelson W.

description: I am a big fan of california rolls. This place makes different variaties of california roll so you don't get bored with the same one. I ain't hating it! It is a pretty cheap sushi place because it just cost about $40 for my boyfriend and I for dinner. When it gets packed you can either sit on the tables but people prefer the bar since the sushi just rotates in front of you. When you get the table you just walk up to the bar and grab whatever you like on the boats, or you can just order it. If I don't see the sushi I like, I can just order it with one of the waitresses.
author: Jade L.

description:
I went here for the first time last night with a friend. It was around 730pm and we had about a 10-15 min wait. The sushi bar was packed like a can of sardines. We were seated first before a part of 3. Pays to be a party of 2. The boats were filled with all sorts of different types of sushi. Sushi rolls, hand rolls, pots of lord knows what inside. Impressive really, but I wanted the unusual rolls that you had to order. 

My friend ordered a bunch of CA rolls that were the size of a dime (I guess you get what you pay for). I placed an order for the Honey Walnut Roll, and it took about 15 mins for me to ask where the hell it was. Apparently there was some mix up (yeah right) and I told them to just forget it. 

All in all, the sushi boat was probably the best highlight of the night, although i couldnt eat half of the plates off of it. Service was slow, but it was busy, so that was okay. They werent really attentive which can make a big difference. But you get cheap sushi.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
I never knew what this place was called. As I walked in here, I had realized I've been here before. I remember sitting on the left side of the sushi boat. This time, we sat on the right side, near the restroom. Not a great place if you want to talk to people that aren't sitting next to you. I guess you could yell, which isn't exactly the best option. I wouldn't say it's a group kind of place to eat at, just because you wont have the chance to talk to anyone, other than the people that you are sitting next to. Hopefully you're close enough to them, so you can talk to them for the entire time you're there, or else it would be SUPER AWKWARDDD. If you want to talk to the others that you brought along, there are regular tables that seat 4, but they suck since you're not able to sit in front of the conveyor belt of food floating by.

Each plate ranges from $1.50-$2.95, I believe. Plates can consist of fried oysters, fresh oysters, fried potato, fried sushi, calamari, mussels, all sorted sushi...

There are other rolls you can order that aren't floating by. 

Since I wasn't really hungry, I had about 7 plates, which ended up costing around $16.60 with tax. One unusual item I had was this thing in a container similar a ramekin used for creme brulee, it had...mayo, tuna?, imitation crab, whatever the sauce they use to top the mussels (cheese?)...I'm not sure what it was, but it was good.

I was really really thirsty, I'm not sure if it was from the fried foods or whatnot, but I felt like the waitresses didn't come around enough to pour me some tea. I had about 3 cups, while I was there, ok...I guess that is sort of a lot, BUT I WAS REALLY REALLY THIRSTY.

Good prices, but not exactly the freshest fish I've seen around. Restaurants with sushi boat are always fun to eat at.
author: Kylie L.

description: pretty good place. the boats were cool except for the fact that you pile up plates and they turned out to be more money in the end than you expected. sushi was pretty fresh, not much new rolls came out but that is probably because no one was really there on Tuesday at lunch...good service too
author: Janne Y.

description: Coworker took me here and said it's his favorite sushi place. Errrrr..... well I am turned off.  The service was lame, the lady was being very passive.  We came before closing.  Though there were a couple customers eating, the waitress was obviously trying to get us out of there as soon as possible, which was very rude.  I got about thirty seconds to look at the menu before she approached us and asked if we were ready to order.  I just told my friend to order for me.  May come back for honey walnut roll, TO GO, but not dealing with anything else.  Pretty average.  Unagi bowl was OK.
author: Alyssa Z.

description: Me, my family and friends like this place. It always has fresh sushi because people coming here non stop. I also like their pricing. Unlike a lot of sushi restaurants, that place is not expensive with still tasty and fresh sushi. You can easily have lunch for 2 people for about $20 which is unusual for sushi places. :)
author: Irina V.

description:
I come here pretty often because my bf loves the ease of it and the lack of waiting. 

I always get the same stuff I like: spicy california roll, fried oysters, spicy tuna roll with seaweed on top, and random other rolls. Quality is ok, decent for what it is. Not that many choices without having to pull out the menu for more variety. 

You come into a sushi boat place and you can't really expect too much. It's food floating around and circulating around a bunch of people. I like to grab the stuff when they place it on the plates right away, that way the people around can't breathe on my food. 

I also like to order rolls that aren't floating around so I know it's fresh. 

I do like the service. There's this one lady who knows us and brings us our drink orders right when we sit down. She's nice and attentive and she knows I like to order fresh rolls. (There is this other lady who kinda hovers around and waits for your bill -- to check out the tips I assume -- very annoying). 

Otherwise, I'll keep coming back because my bf will make me and I do have a fondness for their spicy california rolls.
author: Jeannie L.

description:
I love coming here because of the sushi boat experience, BUT let me tell you that it DOES and WILL add  up!

The sushi is good and fresh as the chefs prepare it. I really like sitting right in front of the sushi because then you can grab and pick what's in front of you and eat it. The only down fall is, sometime I feel like the chefs are looking at me to see if I'm eating and/or see what I've eaten so they make more of what I've had. I really really really like the honey walnut roll, that one is my favorite. I also like the salmon and the rolls that come on the boat with shrimp tempura.

The customer service could use some work. Not going to lie, I can understand mandarin, and let's just say it's rude to talk about someone in front of them. ALSO it's rude to ignore them and talk about your personal issues, like "hellllllo, can I get a glass of water? or a refill please?" 

But nonetheless, if I am a customer and I feel satisfied with my meal, I will tip. But trust me, if you've just been chattering the night away without any good service, don't expect me to leave you a tip and look at me through the window as I'm walking away. THANKS!

happy eating!
author: Liberty C.

description:
I'm very picky when it comes to chicken. Some places make it too dry or too greasy. 

Luckily, my "pimp daddy" (bestie) dragged me here when we had our Chicken Teriyaki crave. I was surprised to see the place had a sushi boat, and then on the  other side of the room there were tables (maybe for those who choose not to sushi boat, or can't get a seat at the sushi boat).  I've never seen that before, and I thought it was cool.  

( + )  I constantly saw the rolls I like come on the sushi boat (which is RARE because my sushi boat places hardly ever put the stuff I like, I always have to request it)

( + ) The sushi was delicious! And tasted fresh. 

( + )  The chicken teriyaki is delicious, not too chewy, and I liked how everything looked so neat on the plate.

( + ) Quiet setting. 

---- 

( - ) I was sitting at the sushi boat place, and I felt the distance between the wall and the chair was kinda slim. It felt a little crowded and a little difficult to get in and out when there were a lot of people sitting next to me.

I would definitely come back! But maybe sit somewhere thats not too close to the wall.
author: Sophia G.

description:
The sushi is cheap, but they have raisin the price a bit. The sushi is okay, but they're not that fresh. You notice as you sit around on the table of the sushi boat that the sushi looks like it's been sitting there for a while. 

I just hate the customer service. They are rude and they expect to get tipped when they haven't done anything.A friend of mine ordered sushi to go and they asked her if she wanted her change back.
author: Mandy D.

description: This place is Not super expensive and really good, the waitresses are very nice and attentive. I liked sushi on the boat with walnuts, and the octopus plate was good as well. Deep fried ice cream was so creamy:)
author: Katie K.

description: I went back today, the platter trays are also a legit option.  They're big and the sushi is good.
author: Jensen L.

description: Yummy!  Good food, large selection, friendly and quick service. Best of all sushi boats. Been coming here for years! I just love this place. Don't want whats on the boats ask for a menu.
author: J K.

description:
Have been passing by this place for so long and never eat here before.
Went there today and i can only say this is a-okay.  I only tried the tempura udon which was 7 bucks.  The bowl, to me, is pretty small.  But is was okay, only okay.  I really wanted to try the sushi on the floating boats but didn't.  I will definitely go back again to try those.

Will come back for some sushi.
author: Lily L.

description:
I go there a lot. It's pretty affordable compared with other sushi places. I usually spend less than $30 for two with taxes and tip included and I eat a lot of sushi. I think it's worth trying. 
My hubby always gets beef teriyaki and he really likes it. I always get sushi and love it.

I noticed that most of the people go there for the sushi boat and the tables remain empty most of the time. I am always served pretty quickly, and never had to wait in line, since I seat on the table.

If you want cheap sushi, here's the place.
author: alice a.

description:
Recently tried their sushi boat and overall, it was disappointing. There was very little variety of sushi when i came for lunch and the prices seemed too high for the quality of food. This place isn't run by Japanese people, so that shows in the food. 

There's nothing unusual on the menu and pretty much everything can be made at home from udon to tonkatsu for much less than what you would be charged here. The fish seemed relatively fresh, but since there isn't much involved in preparing sushi, I'd rather buy some sashimi quality fish at a japanese market and prepare it myself.

Although i used to think this place was ok, it's taken a turn for the worse.
author: Iknowasianfood C.

description: This has become my favorite Sushi place. I love the boats. The prices are great. The fish is fresh. I have never gotten sick, so that is a plus. I can walk there from my place, and it is open on Christmas!
author: Jewli J.

description:
Ok I don't go to these places for the sushi (the only sushi I eat are the ones from Trader Joe's or Costco, sue me if I'm not a sushi connoisseur).  I've only tried their teriyaki & katsu.  Food was ok.  I guess if you don't eat raw, it's ok.

Side note:  What's up w/ the chinese owned stores saying some kind of japanese gibberish when you come in.  People, I know you're chinese because the next minute you're talking amongst yourselves in Chinese and I can understand every word you say!  Soooo annoying!
author: Wendy H.

description:
I like this restaurant. I like sushi. I tried almost all sushi restaurants in Richmond. For this price and quality this place of one of the best.  

The only thing I don't like is that they open for dinner too late - at 5:30. Plus, it takes them about 30 - 45 minutes to refresh sushi on the boats. So, the best time to come is 6:00, which is pretty late for many to start dinner.

Try it, you won't be sorry!
author: Boris L.

description:
It's cheap, it's fast. The sushi is decent (much better than Kitaro's next door!) and the sushi boat plates are uber cheap too. 

Service has always been good whenever i've gone.. 

It's strange but I remember one time I went, I had the best hamachi sashimi ever at this place. I'm not a sushi snob but I know when sashimi is bad and when it's good but geez, it was so fresh!
Okay they also have a really cheap unagi don. I think it was $5 when I was there.. 
They have this "deep fried ice cream" dessert but it's not worth ordering. One of the waitresses told me it's just pound cake filled with ice cream and deep fried. Sounds like a bad heart attack to me.

Anyways.. The last time I went was a sentimental one for me. I was about to leave on a roadtrip and my friends and I gathered up to eat lunch here before I left. One of my closest friend's aunt had passed away and he was real down. Sakana Bune was about to close but they took us in anyway and made fresh stuff on the boats just for us. I like to think that it helped make my friend feel a bit better in during that dark  time...
author: Susy C.

description:
I only have good memories of this place. Raining outside; cheap, scrumptious sushi inside. I don't know why people bother to come to here and then sit at the tables (unless it's overly crowded) because the boat is where it's at. The variety is average but every piece is satisfying and just yummy. The comparatively ok freshness of the fish is compensated by the richness of the accompanying sauces (this place makes a killer spicy mayo). 

The service is alright. More smiles/courtesy from the staff are always appreciated, but in any case they're pretty fast and get your order/request right, so I can't complain too much. You get what you pay for.

I've been told by a friend that on a separate visit here (I wasn't with him), he got food poisoning from their sushi and was thus turned off from them forever, scarred for life, etc. I haven't been back here since hearing this story from him, so fair warning.
author: Nami T.

description: My friend brought me here once and I took my family here. I like that they have a variety of sushi on the boat circling around to choose from. The foods taste good and they would pour tea for you every time you run out.
author: Serena Z.

description: Not bad place for sushi.  If you're in the Richmond and in a hurry, you can check this place out.  I just wish there were more options.  Watch out though, the plates really add up. I ate $40 worth just by myself.
author: Alex G.

description: This Sushi was horrible...I came here for lunch and all the sushi on the boat bar looked like it was at least a day old. This is the first time I ever left uneaten sushi on my plate. This place is like the "mystery meat" of sushi.
author: Eugene Z.

description:
If you're looking for an affordable place to fill that sushi craving Sakana Bune would be the place to go! Sakana Bune is a kaiten sushi restaurant, except instead of a rotating conveyor boat your sushi gets a ride on a floating boat. 

Food: 
They have a wide variety of nigiri sushi, maki sushi, sashimi, and deep fried goodies available. If you love traditional choices I'd recommend the amai ebi (raw sweet shrimp), ikura (salmon roe),  and ika (raw squid), which were my favorites! I tried their saba nigiri (raw mackerel marinated in a combo of vinegar and sugar), and it wasn't very tasty... it turned out be too dry and overly marinated, I've definitely had better tasting saba nigiri before. I also had their tuna nigiri and salmon nigiri, which were OK, but not that great, the tuna was a bit dry and the salmon tasted fishier than it usually does. Their baked mussel were also really yummy, I had two servings of those! I was wanting to top it all of with a koroke (deep fried mashed potato), but I've been eying the only one on the sushi boat since I got there (30-45mins ago) so I ordered a fresh one! It turns out that they're delicious too. My only complaint is that they didn't use tonkatsu sauce, I honestly don't know what was used... it tasted like sweetened soy sauce -_-. 

Service: 
The staff were friendly, but not very attentive to taking extra orders from the menu, especially when sitting at the bar. A lot of the items I ordered weren't available on the boats so I had to call on waitresses multiple times. It's strange because they do come to check for refills, but they don't ask you if you'd like to order anything off the menu, so I had to let them know quickly before they run off. 

Price: 
This place is extremely affordable! Honestly, I'd come here again to eat amai ebi nigiri and ikura nigiri for $2.85 any time! I've never had those two choices at that price, so it's definitely a steal! Between my friend and I we ate 21 plates of sushi all together, and I paid $50 total (not including tip). Out of those 21 plates, I had 3 of the most expensive plates, and 3 of the medium priced ones. Everything else were $1.85 plates. 

Overall, the quality of the food isn't high grade sushi, but what can you expect from the prices that they're offering them for?  I'd definitely be returning here to fill my sushi craving.
author: Lina E.

description:
When I'm craving sushi, this is usually where I go. My favorite rolls are the salmon on top roll ("fresh" salmon on top of a California Roll) and House Roll (avocado & unagi on top of a California Roll). You can also get an unagi bowl that comes with miso soup and a side salad for $4.95 (lunch) and $5.96 (dinner). It's hard to beat those prices. 

Good prices, good food.
author: Kathy L.

description:
Ive been coming to this restaurant for many years now and it hasn't changed too much except for the increase in prices over time. It just kind of bothers me how the prices went up, but not the quality. Sakana Bune has never been my number one choice for sushi, primarily because the food isn't all that great, but their pricing was, at one time, stellar. 

Still, the sushi boat is fun and I can get pretty full for a somewhat decent amount of money. This may be a personal pet peeve, but I really detest the way the waitresses are practically staring at you when you re eating like you're going to smuggle some sushi beneath your jacket. Gets super annoying after awhile. LET ME BREATH! 

I'd recommend this as a place to maybe bring a couple friends to and catch up, but if you want to take your first date to a nice sushi restaurant... look elsewhere.
author: Brandon D.

description:
Four of us went to Sakana Bune last Saturday. My cousin chose this place because we wanted to get dinner, but not have to wait hours that you would probably have to wait at other restaurants on a Saturday night. We got to Sakana Bune around 9pm, and we didn't have to wait at all.

When my cousin first said we were going to have sushi boat, I was a little skeptical. My usual sushi boat experiences aren't that great, but I was pleasantly surprised with Sakana Bune.

I am giving four stars for this place for what it offers. People might rate places like this based on the quality of food, but you really have to look at everything as a whole. For the setting, pricing, and freshness of the sushi, this place is pretty good.

If i remember correctly, the sushi ranges from $1-$3. (around) I didn't realize it was so cheap till halfway through our meal. This is cheap considering other sushi boat places can range up to $5 a roll.

The sushi here is also fresh - the super white tuna and salmon were both really good - very fresh and "melt-in-your-mouth" consistency. As far as other rolls, I liked their unagi, spicy tuna (w/orange sauce on top), and fried california roll. Lastly, their seared tuna sashimi was yummm. 

The items I weren't too fond of was the spicy tuna & tuna nigiri, and also the fried crab items. The fried crab leg probably would have tasted it if it was fresh. By the time we ate it, it was cold and soggy, eek.

Overall, good sushi boat experience. The boyfriend and I ate around 14 sushi dishes and an order of green tea ice cream - all for under $40! awesome.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Are you impatient like my father?

Are you looking for a sushi fix IMA (now)??

Well, Sakabune has one of the cheapest sushi-boat sushi offerings in the city. Different varieties of maki, nigiri, and other sushi-tapas, float around on bamboo boats. Each trays color coincides with a different price--very reasonable.

You can also order a la carte.

The oysters are really yummy. And so is the crab claw!

My dad calls it "expensive fast food," because the bill can quickly get up to $50 for 3 people.
author: Misha F.

description:
I went here with 3 of my gal pals and we ate . . . a ton . . . of everything . . . because it was cheap. I don't think it's good enough overall to get 4 stars but I give it a very strong 3. One of my friends insisted we go here because it was one of her favorite places in the Outer Richmond. When I saw the place I thought . . seriously? Then I realized why she likes it so much. 

After browsing the menu and looking at the prices and variety, we quickly pilled up stacks of sushi trays. The moving sushi boats are fun, especially when you are hungry and just don't want to wait to order. Not that waiting is a problem. They are almost too eager to get to you. The sushi is good. Not the freshest or most artistically made sushi I've had but, if you just need a quick fix, it's good. 

i wouldn't describe this place as very classy, unique or trendy. I would describe it as convenient, quick or cheap. For me, that makes it good enough to go back . . . on the right evening.
author: Lauren B.

description:
If you are not picky about your sushi or don't have the taste buds to differeniate between good and great sushi, then this is your place.  They have relatively good sushi here, at a fraction of the cost.  I think it might be the cheapest in the city.  

Yes, they probably don't have any special and over the top variety, but again, if you're a simpleton wanting to satisfy a sushi craving, it's perfect.  

It is usually quite packed in there, especially for the sushi bar.  If you already know what you like to eat and what to order, just take the table!  There's always instant availability.  Then you can order the sushi from the waitress - same price as bar.  Service is usually very good.
author: Jannie Q.

description:
One of the servers screamed at us, accusing us of being dishonest about which plates off the boats were ours.

The food was manky.

Found a complaint investigation inspection on Sakana Bune for December 28, 2009 at everyblock.com.

Nothing in detail, but you can find it here:

http://sf.everyblock.com/restaurant-inspections/by-date/2009/12/28/2992596/

I must say I'm not surprised.
author: Josephine L.

description: It was a good experience at the time when I was hungry for sushi, I had to chaise for my food. Michelle Z. is correct if you are not a sushi snob this is something good to try. If there is nothing else in the area you are going to end up in this place.
author: Mark Z.

description:
I really really love this place! I come here very often and so far it has never put me down. Parking is mostly meter but if your willing to walk a bit, there are plenty of free parking. 

Overall good sushi, great price =)
author: Julie B C.

description: I came here a few years ago and remember it not being the best so I usually go to Kitaro for lunch since Little Tokyo isn't open till dinner time.  It is pretty good for the cost. $15 and two rolls to go.  It's not the best place around but for the price it's definitely good.  Kitaro usually cost couple dollars more even though their fish is fresher I would say this place has the better rolls.  Not really super into sushi boat places which is why I prefer to order so that I know what I'm getting hasn't been sitting out losing flavor.
author: Nirea S.

description:
The food is okay. It's relatively cheap for a sushi boat place but the sushi quality isn't amazing. It's still tasty if you're not picky. They also have a good sized selection, you can always ask for the menu. The service wasnt great though, they were very deaf and slow. Everything I said had to be repeated 2-3 times, they forgot my hot sake, and the spicy tuna nigiri took about 12 minutes to make and it didn't even look like the picture...

So, not great and not terrible. You get what you pay for.
author: Julie M.

description:
When I first came here, the cheapest dishes were a dollar. Since then, prices went up, but I still like to come here. 

Yup.

I used to eat here at least once a week. I LOVE their salmon nigiri, and their other nigiri is also pretty awesome. Consistently very good. The waitresses are very speedy, so I can count on getting my tea refilled quite often. 

Too bad that finding parking is another skill in itself over here. Typically San Francisco. Also gets ridiculously crowded for lunch and dinner on weekends.
author: Hayne P.

description:
Sushiboat!

Come here when it opens to get seated since it gets filled pretty quickly. I came at a different time around 8pm and I had to wait about half an hour.

The thing i dislike about sushi boats are the quality and how long the food has been out. Honestly, you never know how long it has been out unless you've watched the chefs make and put the plates out.

I'm sure this isn't the best but it's cheaper than Jtown of course. Prices got a little more expensive by I think a quarter or so.

I only get california roll, spider roll, sometimes oysters depending how big they are and how long it's been out, honey walnut roll, and a few others. Most of the rolls i get tend to have the imitation crab in them.

Deep fried ice cream is alright. The batter or cake around the green tea ice cream gets really dry at times.
author: Jennifer Q.

description: This place is small and quaint. The wait for the bar seat at the sushi boat wasn't that long. Took about 20 minutes.  The sushi was great and the prices were pretty damn good too. The lowest price sushi was $1.50 per plate and the highest it will go is $2.95 a plate. I'm amazed at the prices and quality of this place. Too bad it's all the way in SF. The wait staff was great, they came and poured our drinks without us asking for it and waited customers attentively.  I'm thankful for my friend bringing us here, I would have not known about it.  Definitely coming back here for sure.
author: Verik K.

description:
The best mediocre sushi money can buy. 

This is the one sushi restaurant I will go to on an empty stomach, knowing I will eat my fill and my tab will never be over $20.    There definately is better sushi in SF but Ive paid A LOT more for a lot worse.

I give this restaurant five stars after all the crappy sushi Ive had in the Mission and Financial District.
author: Bigfrog W.

description: Not very much variety, fish didn't taste fresh, somethings gave me a gag reflex (oysters, weird squid dish) Service was okay - not much they have to do when you seat yourself and feed yourself. I will not be back. Just overall - gross. Go to Isobune in Japantown - more expensive but who says cheap sushi is a good thing?
author: S. M.

description: Fun, tasty sushi boat experience at about half the price of Japantown sushi boats. They have all the usual treats you can choose as the plates on boats float past you, plus a great salmon agimono you can order from the waitstaff (just $4.95). Very fresh sushi served in a very clean restaurant.
author: Roger H.

description:
mannn all imma say is
SUNSET ROLL.....
they pretty nice here and the sushi chefs are pretty frickin nice hahah
and its a BOAT....trust you spend about $20 here and your full!
author: Pierre L.

description: This Sushi restaurant is really awesome. They have the most fresh sushi I have ever tasted. I go here when I am in town and I love it. This restaurant is cool because it has those little boats that go around on water and you pick your sushi pieces from the boats. So very fun! I will definitely go here next time I am in town. The sushi with the creamy crab on top is my favorite.
author: Israelle O.

description:
The one star is for the food alone and nothing else- including and especially the service. While I was being seated, a Chinese waitress was having a dispute with a customer over a bill falling short or his tips falling short. Even after the misunderstanding was settled, the Chinese waitress spent the rest of the evening accusing how cheap and thick-skinned the man was with other waitresses. Very professional gossip queen here- do not spare the customers still at the restaurant. Let us know how much you hate us. Beautiful.

The waitress who served us was a different one with golden brown hair and as the pair next to us at the bar departed, she knocked over a cup of water that spilled all the way towards our side with a small waterfall running onto my boyfriend's pants. Seems like an accident and I wouldn't have been so worked up if they had only apologized. The waitress didn't care while i scrambled for my napkin so my bf could dry his pants. She continued to wipe the table and I looked up at her when i realized that she wasn't going to give us more napkins for the spill and certainly no apology that i could hear of. And just when you think the gossip queen was acting out of concern by asking if we are all right, she followed with "Oh, it's cold water right?" and when we confirmed, she turned away dismissively. No sorry? Perhaps at Sakana Bune, spilling water on paying customers is so routine that an apology is unnecessary. I mean why else will customer come to Sakana right? We're here to be hated. Here, their motto is "water spills, smack talk, and palpable indifference." 

I am never coming back again and i bet when i left them with my death glares, the gossip queen added it to her circulatory lists of events to ruminate about.
author: Natalie Y.

description:
My friend and I went here tonight and had a nice dinner. Is it Ebisu? No, but I also didn't feel like spending Ebisu prices either. For what you get (some amazing sushi) and the fun of having the little boats go by, and the fact that you can get outta here for $20/person with some sake, it's a fun way to start the evening.

People's opinions on sushi are varied based on what they are used to, and what they expect. I've been to many here, in LA and NYC, and I'd put this place in the realm of "decent, well made, basic sushi plus a fun place to go" category. If I wanted something fancier and pricier, I'd go there, but sometimes you just want a night out without having to get a loan application to pay the tab. And yeah, sushi boats.
author: Greg D.

description:
This is my favorite sushi spot in SF! Love the sushi boats and the variety that they have. 

I come here whenever i have a craving for sushi, and that's more often than not. haha. I also take family and friends here either for a nice little lunch or dinner and they all love it. Especially people from out of town have fun, because they've never seen a sushi boat before. 

My Favorites:
- Salmon on Top Roll : salmon sashimi on top of California Roll
- House Tempura Roll - deep fried unagi and crab roll
- House Roll - Unagi and Avocado on top of California Roll
- Alaska Roll - Salmon and Avocado roll
- Tenkasu Roll 
- Hamachi Nigiri 
- Unagi Bowl
- Tempura Udon
author: Sharon L.

description:
Came here again on Monday, towards 10. I guess they were near closing but they didnt put much out at the boats. Sushi obviously sitting there forever circling round and round... eeech. And lots of empty spaces not being refilled = no bueno. If they arent going to put new stuff out, they should just close down the sushi boat place and stick to just reg. orders, isnt the point of sushi to have it fresh?

Ordered terikyaki from the menu, it was good. 

Bleh need to find a new neighborhood sushi spot.
author: Amy S.

description:
I love sushi trains. It makes the dining experience a fun one because not very many places do this. I chose all kinds of different plate and I enjoyed them all. They were all fresh and they just keep on coming :)

My favorite was a fried potato cake like thing.. I don't know what it was called but I kept requesting for more :)

The outside was a little deceiving but don't let it stop you from coming in. :)
author: Stephanie J.

description:
Well, in all fairness I do back from time to time because of the super cheap prices.  But when it comes to the sushi, its probably the absolute worse within a 20 block radius.  But for the price, you cant beat it.  I sometimes get stomach aches after a meal there...  The pink
Kaopectate works great!

Hold on...   Fune Ya is hella sick!!!  They are pretty bad!  So this place and Fune Ya are disgusting...  Fune Ya inflamed my ulcers..
author: Demanding T.

description: I will be the first to admit I am generous with my reviews, but that being said I am giving this place only 1 star. The chefs are fine but the service was awful. My boyfriend and I waited 30 minutes after our meal for our bill, and when we tried flagging down  the waitresses she ignored us to go talk to her friends by the front door. We won't be coming back.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
The best deal for sushi boat. Their a-la-carte rolls also cheaper and bigger than those in other places. I love their spider roll with the whole soft shell crab. Other places would give you half of the crab for this price. 

I went there at lunch and late night. The place was quite fulled. The service was great.
author: Poyz C.

description:
I grew up 2 blocks away from this place.  How much I wish that it was around when I was growing up.  I absolutley love this place.  They have very good rolls and for the price, are very inexpensive.  I will drive from the east bay out to this place, just to eat.  No 5th star because the parking sucks.

Last time I went with a friend for lunch and we spent 30 dollars between both of us.  Did not over stuff ourselves this time, but the amount of sushi we ate would have easily been 50 dollars at any other location.  

Plus, the sushi boats going around entertian me.
author: Jim J.

description: I really enjoyed sitting at the sushi bar and grabbing my sushi off the little boats. The quality of the sushi here is nothing spectacular, but for it's price it is completely A-OK to have to lunch. It's best to come here during peak hours, so you aren't stuck with the same pieces floating around and around. The staff here are definitely not Japanese, but nonetheless they do a satisfactory job of refilling your tea and getting you extra ginger and such. I recommend this restaurant if you want the fun of watching your food float on boats, but not if you want high quality sushi.
author: Mina K.

description: This passable sushi boat is both conveniently located and inexpensively priced. Prepare to spend upwards of $25 for your fill of respectably made sushi in a clean, safe location right on geary. Pro tip: there is a small parking lot right across the street.
author: Lando H.

description:
Good for one thing..and one thing only...

HONEY WALNUT ROLL

It's like very similar to the chinese dish Honey Walnut Prawns but rolled into a sushi.  It's made with shrimp tempura, walnuts, avocado, and the sweet mayo.  It's creative and pretty good.

Other than that...the sushi is cheap so you're going to get cheap sushi.  It's okay because they have the sushi boat factor going on for them, but other than that, it's just not that good.  

Ending on a good note...I've always encountered good service here!  The waitresses are always really nice and helpful.
author: Helen V.

description:
Three stars is a fair grade for this busy place.
Sushi boat was invented in the city and this place uses the idea of floating sushi 100%
The variety is pretty limited, though their sushi is OK, and service is descent. 
I recommend trying their seared albacore nigiri - with a little sprinkle of the garlic on the top. The good thing is they make it to your order plus a few extra to spin on the sushi river, so if you care for more, you may be lucky to get extra off the boat.
Pros: don't come in after 1:45 pm for a late lunch, as long as you want to avoid dry rice and extremely limited choice on the carousel.
author: Sing T.

description:
I think it's more 3.5 stars, but for the price...can't complain!

You know, I wish I could sit here all night, sip on my sake and just keep ordering the fresh oysters ($10 for half a dozen and came with a tangy, spicy sauce!---yum) and the white fish sushi (sorry, can't tell you what it was ---I think it's escolar---but it was fresh, and mildly sweet and very buttery).

The sushi is amazingly reasonable and I'd rather come to this neighborhood place where it's not over-priced like Japantown.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
Like Amy said - this place is a solid 3.5. 

We came here on Saturday night, I had passed by this place numerous times before and there is always people inside - must not be that bad. We waited about 10-15 mins to sit at the sushi bar. Once we sat done, we looked as the boats went around and around and around. All plates are either $1.50 through $2.95. Alot cheaper than other sushi boat restaurants I've been to. The spicy tuna is def. super spicy - the guys liked this one the best. I liked the Ikura nigiri - my favorite! 

Service was good tho - waters were always being filled! Some of the plates on the sushi boat contained slices of sashimi, some were cut properly, while some were clearly leftover pieces that the chefs didn't know what to do with. If you want sushi that you don't see on the boats, you can order it by the plate and the waitress will bring it to you. Overall not bad!
author: Betty S.

description:
So it was a girls' day out for lunch today...myself and my 7 & 10 year old. The girls love the deep fried crab claw appetizer. They also can't live without their ebi. They complained today that the spicy crab salad was TOO spicy for them, but usually it's less spicy. 
Myself, I grabbed some fresh oysters off the sushi boats first. Delicious as usual. The oysters are the only reason I come here, and yet, I never order the appetizer. I prefer to see them in groups of 2...perhaps it makes me think I'm not eating so many oysters...
Got two plates of the spider roll. Today it was excellent. The soft-shell crab appetizer always seems too small for me, and yet the spider roll seems satisfying enough.
They had a scallop salad which was very tasty. The jellyfish roll was very good today as well.

Great selection of sushi. During our meal, we also grabbed sushi for the boys, and the waitress was good enough to box them up for me. 

Not bad for a girls' day out!
author: cindy c.

description:
I come here when I want to eat sushi off a boat and can't afford to go to Isobune.

The sushi is not exactly fresh but it is decent for its price. Unfortunately, the choices of sushi that they had on the boat was very limited, and sometimes they have some really weird and random sushi/stuff on the boat.

It is a good place to go to when you are on a budget.
author: Alicia W.

description:
I really enjoy sushi but don't consider myself a sushi connoisseur.  I came here for the first time a couple of weeks ago with my friend who recommended the place.  I thought the sushi wasn't bad though some of the reviews here were a little more critical.  To me though the place can be summed up as "good, cheap, sushiboat".  If you're looking for two out of those three things, and it can be any two, I'd say give this place a shot.  

One thing I do recommend is the honey walnut prawn roll.  What is this you say?  Honey walnut prawn roll?  Yep!  Just like the stuff you get a Chinese restaurants, but in sushi form!   I've never seen it before and it was pretty good.
author: Wilson C.

description:
This is a great place if you're looking for a sushi boat experience on the cheap. I thought the sushi was good, and the experience was really fun. Service was great! The only possible complaint I could have is that there was not a whole lot of variety on the sushi boats--many of the rolls were just different variations on a California roll--but they were all still really good!

The price is definitely right here. My friend and I spent a little over 20 dollars each for a bottle of sake 10 plates from the boats each!
author: Rose G.

description:
I trekked in here one day trying to switch up on my usual sushi spot, Kitaro. I like sushi but I don't know the first thing about what makes sushi fresh because honestly, it all tastes the same to me. 

I liked the idea of sushi boat but was sad that the selection was so limited. My boyfriend can't really eat raw fish, so of course, we were stuck with whatever had imitation crab. I saw their honey walnut roll and fell in love. It was definitely unique and tasted good too! Aside from that, sakana bune offers nothing too unique. Some of the sushi also looked like it had been sitting too long.
author: Connie C.

description:
Go for the fun novelty that it is! It's a true delight for food lovers to watch the beautifully constructed sushi plates circle the moat that the chefs work in the center of, smacking down fresh rolls, and the diners hover around... Sometimes greedily snatching up a plate of a certain pattern that you may wish you had not grabbed. I recommend the hot baked ramekin! It is filled with a warm mayo and sesame flavored hodge podge of tuna, veggies, tamago, shrimp, and more mystery bits.... It's like a really yummy sesame oil tuna melt! I recommend avoiding the rolls filled with imitation crab salad as they all taste the same blah...which is the majority of the choices but...Have patience, practice restraint and some good, fresh choices will come around! 
I loved the crowded cooky environment here...lots of young local families simply celebrating life's simple pleasures like pieces of mediocre sushi swimming round and round and round and round.... Hypnotizing sushi....
author: Libra J.

description:
I went to Sakana Bune Japanese Restaurant on a Friday evening. I was looking for a sushi bar with boats for the entertainment value. I wanted to try Warakubune Sushi but it was closed.

We arrived around 6:00pm and there was about a 10 minute wait. Since the restaurant is on Geary Street, parking can be hit or miss. 

Like other sushi bars, seating is a challenge since people sitting at the bar don't come and go in the same numbers as people arrive. We were a party of 4 and though 3 seats were open, the staff did not let the party of 2, who came after us sit. (This is the correct way, to the chagrin of the party of 2).

Overall the experience is good for those who might be intimidated to sit and order at a traditional sushi bar. Though the strange thing is that the most intimidating sushi (nigri) was the predominate type on the boats. While the less intimidating (combo rolls) were scarce and had to be special ordered. "Regular' Japanese food is also available to order.

Sushi Freshness: 6 (1-Won't eat; 5 - what you would find at Safeway; 10 - to die for). The sushi was fresh - not great not bad. Somewhat close to what you would get at Safeway.  

Sushi Creativity: 6 (1- Typical nigri rolls; 5 - typical nigri rolls plus some unique ones; 10 - Many different rolls). On the boats its mostly nigri-type rolls. Though looking at the menu, it looks like they offer some unique ones.

Service: 9 - Sat at the Sushi bar, wait staff attentive and seating us before the party of 2.

Cleanliness: 9 - Overall the restaurant seemed clean. I didn't use the restroom to judge that.

Overall: 7.5

Sakana Bune spot to try if you want to have a sushi boat experience. If you consider yourself a sushi snob, I wouldn't recommend it with so many good sushi restaurants in SF.
author: Mark K.

description:
I have heard so many bad things about this place that I needed to try it myself to confirm it. My expectations were low so I was expecting the worst. It really wasn't that bad if you enjoy imitation crab meat salad on every roll that goes around the sushi boat. 

This restaurant is not going to be the type of restaurant where you plan to go to or make reservations for. it's a place with decent food, at a decent price, that does the job. If you are looking for more than that you can forget about it. If you were from out of town and you came here with your friends then yeah.........your friends would probably not talk to you anymore. The food itself was actually decent. The sashimi was good and the rolls were ok. Their most expensive dish is 2.95 so you really can't expect that much. The only thing that I dislike about this place is that they put mayo on everything. I saw a big jug of costco mayo inside and it was just a turn off. 

We ordered like 3 orders of salmon sashimi and 10 other plates of rolls and the total bill came out to 40 dollars. Not bad. 

My overall experience..............it did the job. It got me full.
author: jason g.

description:
I love the sushi boat not gonna lie it entertains me. 

The service here is wonderful. I drink a lot of water, more than the whole restaurant combined probably but I always have a full glass when I am here. I love that. 

Prices are very reasonable but you may end up spending any savings in gas just trying to find a parking spot. 

At one time my husband asked me to go in and sign in while he found parking. I said "No way because by the time you find parking I will be waiting for you to pick me up with a full tummy. Yes it sometimes can be that long looking for a spot. 

Overall pleasant experience every time we go there.
author: Corina W.

description: unbelievable!!! rude waitresses who gave my 18 month old dirty looks because he was playing with chopsticks and the soy sauce plate!  i seriously cant believe that then had the audacity to rudely confront me at the end of my meal and provoke argument with me in front of my son!!
author: Marilyn C.

description: The kid's favorite place. It's very reasonably priced. The staff is always very kind. We usually head across the street for ice cream afterwards. It's not high end sushi but it's perfect for a quick mid week no fuss dinner.
author: J H.

description:
Food is ok.... however..... place is un cle an, and has ro ac hes on the glass infront of the sushi boat line.  T h at was the l ast time I ever came here.

After having that experience, I wouldn't come again. 

More o v e r, my r e v ie w of th is place had been d e tled t w ice. They dont wa nt peo ple knowing about the ro ach es! I give them 5 stars for  cove r ing it u p, but one star for actua lly eat ing here.
author: Jeff G.

description: This is based on my bffl's mom buying us sushi. She says its cheap and I think it's tasty. The rice and sushi are flavorful. The fish doesn't have much taste sometimes, but otherwise it's good enough! Coming back here cause I just got the menu and its CHEAP
author: Vivian L.

description:
Since I tried its next door rivals, Kitaro & Little Tokyo, I thought to complete the whole side of the block and go to Sakana Bune. Sadly, the restaurant lived up to its 3 star reputation. I found the sushi to be quite mediocre and the sushi boat line up didn't even add a little bit of interest to my meal. It doesn't offer the variety that its rivals offer. There were probably about 10-12 types of sushi on the boat line up. 2-4 sushi are displayed on each boat and you can just grab the plate on the boat which indicates the price for the sushi. The honey walnut roll was to die for but the rest of the sushi were as ordinary as traffic on the Bay Bridge.

They've especially salted the wound by bringing the wrong order to my date and kept insisting that the $15 rolls were what he ordered and it looked completely different from the menu. Of course, it tasted different too. Eat here at the slightest desperation for sushi or if Panda Express is closed. lol
author: Charmian D.

description:
Ok so the service was almost non-existent, but I don't like to be bothered unless you're refilling my water or bringing my check anyway...plus, I can grab my own sushi!!

Full for $17.25...and every piece was good and tasty which is more than I can say for spots that charge that much for 1 roll!!!  I definitely recommend if you need a sushi fix; I much prefer being able to eat an assortment of pieces over eating an entire roll for $10-$13, Variety is the spice of life!
author: Jennifer P.

description: Low quality food and the worst is the service!! I have never met such ill mannered "thai" waitresses. Don't go there!!!! That place makes me sick!! And shame on the management!!!
author: uncle m.

description: Sushi is cheap and you get what you pay for. Clearly their staff has never heard of the saying "the customer is always right," as they treated me rudely and disrespectfully.  The sushi on the sushi boats sits out for ages to get warm and is not fresh, nor of top quality.  The house salad I had was literally some wet lettuce with a dressing that seemed like nothing more than straight mayonnaise.  Take my advice and go to another sushi place if you're in the richmond district.
author: Josh L.

description: Good prices and easy to stop in for a quick bite for portions that you can totally control. I'm a small snacker, so I can come in and have an afternoon snack for $10 and try several types of sushi.
author: Amy M.

description: Perfect place for a quick bite but can't decide on one type of sushi. Variety come floating in a boat to choose from. I come here for my lunch break when I crave sushi and tired of going to Kitaro on the same block.
author: Katherine V.

description: This place was good back in 2005 but now it's gone downhill. But if I am in the mood for sushi boat variety I would come here. You have to sit in the bar because the variety is minimal. So if you have time, just sit there and hawk the chefs when they put out new items or else you won't get your money's worth by eating the same thing over and over. The prices are high for how little you get but I guess you're really paying for the experience and variety. The food is good but it's pricey. The service is quick and decent.
author: Sophia K.

description:
Not all sushi can or should be excellent. There is certainly a place for quick, quality, inexpensive sushi, at least as far as I'm concerned. 

I found myself in the outer Richmond running some errands and in desperate need of lunch. Alas the stars aligned and there was an open parking spot right in front. Score! 

This is one of those places where the little boats carry various items around and you grab what you want. Glorious instant gratification. 

The quality was decent, the staff friendly, and prices reasonable. Not a high end joint by any means, but perfect for a quick lunch drop in. I'll be back.
author: Dustin E.

description: This place is stellar!! I was weary of sushi boats for fear of grabbing something not fresh. This was not the case here. They had a huge variety of rolls coming around and it was all very fresh, tender and had quality taste. They had some different rolls that were fun to try. I will definitely come back for more!!  :)
author: Lucia A.

description:
I was brought here by a wonderful fellow yelper on my birthday.  I sat down at the conveyor and proceeded to grab three dishes in rapid succession from the conveyor belt.  The good looking couple sitting next to us speaking Russian to each other glanced over in reaction to my voraciousness and I glanced back with a sheepish look as I noticed that in one fell swoop I had consumed 2/3rds of their entire meal and I was just warming up.

This visit everything I had was wonderful.  Considering the price and speed of my meal it can't be beat.  Please do not come here expecting gourmet sushi although if you wish you can sit at the tables and order freshly made rolls including their specialty rolls and probably won't be disappointed. 

The couple didn't seem to notice that I had continued to make a pig of myself, washing down the boatloads of sushi with generous amounts of sake.  They were more interested in each other.

The passing boats left empty plates in their wake and a sleepy satiated smile on my face.  It was my birthday after all.

The handsome couple left arm in arm leaving behind a significantly smaller set of plates and with expressions similar to mine probably less due to their meal and more in anticipation of their next course.

The restaurant has added a program that runs on their overhead TV that shows animations of cartoon boats towing pictures of their sushi with the names of each one.  I was highly entertained.  I didn't know I had just eaten jellyfish and sharks fin.  I just knew it was tasty.  :)

I no longer live around the corner and work from home but when I am in the vicinity I love to just drop in for a quick bite.  I'm definitely a fan.
author: Theron L.

description: I love sushi. I love sushi boat joints. been coming here for about 9 years, never disappointed. My girlfriend took me here 3 weeks ago for my birthday lunch and it was about 2:30 in the afternoon. We were the only ones in here and the boats were stocked with fresh sushi. can't complain one bit! Every time i leave this place, im stuffed to the brim and my wallet isn't that hurt lol.  if u are a sushi head who needs some instant gratification every now and again, this is the place for you.
author: Raymon B.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE! i go every weekend. I am a regular customer. Service is very nice. Have good sushi variety. Enough to take off of the sushi boats and good menu. 
A must try!
author: Ana P.

description:
I've got to concur with Sarah P.'s January review.
Had lunch here today on a whim and my tummy is just not right, even a few hours later. Had the veggie udon and a few items from the sushi boats. Udon was straight up bland and most the sushi rolls had imitation crab mix in them. Plus I wouldn't touch their pale, pale salmon with a ten foot pole. It is cheep but I guess you get what you pay for. Now I'm going to sip some peppermint tea and remind myself to never be the victim of $1.50 sushi boats again. OUCH!
author: Sky C.

description: It's hard to get seats if you're in a big group. We were a party of 7 and ended up having to split up. It was fun to watch the sushi boats float around and around, and just waiting for the one that I want and then quickly grabbing it before it floats away. You can also ask the waitor for requests of sushi if you don't see it on the boats. They have fairly good service and I like their tea. It helps soothe my stomache and gets it ready to consume lots of sushi. Every plate is a different price and there is usually 2 pieces of sushi on each plate. Plates are about $1.50-$3.50. There's a piece of paper that will tell you how much it costs. After you're done eating, they calculate the price by counting your plates. It's pretty cool and fun. I like the boats. :)
author: Kelly H.

description:
Ordered to go form this place and the food was just ok.

The udon was typical, nothing special.

I had some sort of tuna roll (can't remember which as the bf ordered for me) and the fish did not taste very fresh. He also ordered a deep fried carrot roll, which actually kinda good, but seriously, anything deep fried is pretty good.

Overall not very impressed but a hell of a whole lot better than Kitaro two doors down.
author: Pauline T.

description:
My friends and I always have the best time here! You just need to know what to expect. First of all it's not fancy in any sense of the word. It's basically a cheap "lunchy" place to go. Second of all, don't expect awesome service. Although the servers are always nice, they tend to hang out in the corner and often "forget" about you.

That said, I'm still a die-hard Sakana fan. It's a great place to bring larger groups. I rarely have had to wait for a table, and there's typically a few spots open at the bar. I usually just pick my sushi from the floating bar, but I've also had the tempura and mochi from the menu, and it's delicious. 

I went there last night for dinner and at the end of our meal they handed us roll-out Sakana 2011 calendars. Hilarious.
author: Blake Y.

description:
It's sad that this place has been around the area for so long, yet I haven't had the chance to go and experience this nice convenient sushi boat spot.  There's something about the a train of boats carrying sushi and sashimi and other dishes over and over that can either entice you or confuse you.  Enticing, yes, that would be the glimmering salmon sashimi that after a 2nd pass, we just had to grab it.  Confusing, well, theres that repeated fried calamari ring that for sure has been there for the last 45 mins and is no way getting any attention, other than the wonderment of "is anyone going to take that?"

And if none of the items on the sushi boat looks worthy, you can always order from the menu, in which, I had the uni and ikura, both really fresh tasting and delicious.  I had a good time and the sake and beer were a great compliment.  For the sushi boat lovers, definitely, here's one for the outer richmond folks!
author: Vincent K.

description:
I came here once with my family. We get seated at the sushi bar, we start picking plates off the sushi boats, we start eating the food. Several plates in, my mom says, "This place is pretty good for all-you-can-eat!" O_o 

LOL!! My mom is hilarious! BTW, this is not an all-you-can-eat joint! This is a pay-a-certain-price-per-plate kinda joint. Reasonably priced with a nice selection of food items. They have edamame, nigiri, maki, occasionally gyoza, oysters, fried crab claws, some deep fried rolls (deep fried CA roll), some special rolls (I had one with honey walnuts in it... pretty good)... 

You can also order menu items to be brought to the bar or you can sit at the tables for menu items. The price list is posted on the glass so you can control the final price of your meal. The food isn't 5-star quality but it's a fun place to enjoy a meal with friends and have a good time. Stroll on up to Creations for a refreshing dessert and you're good to go.
author: Christine C.

description: It used to be so good, the food were fresh and taste really good, many choices and great price too. But the few times recently when I came, their food were dry and not many choices. I am glad the price is still the same though.
author: Suabot J.

description:
This my friends favorite sushi restaurant.  It is near his house and sometime we come here to eat.  Sushi alway keep adding fresh sushi.
You can sushi order a roll instead of getting it from the boats.
author: John F.

description:
Boats that go round and round with sushi on them. Not a bad place to go for cheap sushi. And its a bit fun to grab sushi floating by. And its pretty tasty. You just gotta keep a good on the sushi, some might have been sitting on that boat for awhile. There are times that were sushi was sitting there for the entire hour and half I was there. Keep an eye on the sushi that the chef puts out or better yet just order the one you want. 

I recommend the 'Salmon on Top' (Raw Salmon on top of California Roll)
author: alex c.

description:
I've been here a couple of times and always enjoyed every visit, of course some more than others. Personally I love sushi boat places and the prices here aren't that bad, at least compared to other sushi boat places. I only know of 2 other sushi boat places in their neighborhood, at another Japanese restaurant on the same block and the sushi boat restaurant in Japantown (I think it's called Isobune?).

Overall I like the selection of sushi the restaurant offers, however one thing I didn't like was that the sushi selection changes depending on what time of the day you go. There's this one roll I always enjoy, I don't remember it exactly but it's kind of sweet with walnuts on it, I know it sounds weird but it's soooo good so if you see it, get it!

The service at the restaurant is fairly good every time I go there. Waitresses are attentive and really nice. Only problem is that the restaurant is fairly small and seats are limited even with the regular dining tables which are also very few. So on bust hours you're looking at hours of wait time. But the food is enjoyable, if you have the chance check out this place.

4 Stars only because sometimes the sushi selection isn't as plentiful. But I haven't been there so many the next time I go I'll probably bump it up.
author: Ryan C.

description:
I'm a sucker for a sushi boat.  

We rarely venture down to this end of Geary St./Blvd./Ave., but on Sunday at 12:30 pm we were here.  The restaurant that first caught our eye had a line waiting, and no tables for two, so we peeked into this corner restaurant -- and saw the boats.  That was it for me!   We barged inside and took our places at the canal.  

It turned out the two chefs on duty were very good!  One of them tackled some of the fancier rolls, while the other made sure everything on the boats was fresh.  The waitress paid meticulous attention to our tea, and the whole experience was an uninterrupted delight.  We ate our fill, and then paid $23 plus tip, and we were happy to do it!
author: David D.

description: It has a sushi boat so that's a nice touch.  The S6-Veggie roll here is realy good.  I ordered a Chicken Teriyaki but it was such a small portion and dry.  You better off got o Kitaro right next door.
author: Aaron L.

description:
Before we went to movie in the park at Dolores Park Sat night, we decided to grab some sushi to-go and have it at the park. Sushi and park sounds so good together... until you have to wait 40 minutes for take out!

Went in there around 6 and left after 6:40. Place was not busy, only the sushi boat area. Came here since sushi is cheap and we thought it was gonna be fast since it's take out and it was close to my friends house. 

Ordered the Salmon Lover, Rainbow, Dragon Roll, and Tekka Maki. The prices were reasonable but the fish weren't so fresh at all. The salmon on the salmon lover tasted like frozen salmon straight out from the freezer. The sushi rice also tasted like they used regular rice instead of the Japanese rice with sugar and vinegar. Sushi rolls were petite and I could probably fit 3 pieces in my mouth.

If we had time, I would of rather went somewhere else. Probably wouldn't come again.
author: Juliane N.

description:
_    ~~   ~~    _  _     __   __    _    /\
 \ \_(__)(__)_/ /..\ \_(__)(__)_/ /.. /  /   ...
  \_________/     \_________/    \_\ (_)
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
