I felt like going Titanic on their lame sushi boats.  Boring sushi, boring taste, boring all over the place.  

Two stars for hot tea and wakame salad.
author: Jay H.

description:
I ate here dozen times. Not my special go to restaurant, but my bro is a fan. I guess it's ok, the food matches the price. And I can't say much for the price, since that's all I can afford for now. And rest of my $ must go for my "other interest".

My fav here are seared tuna. White tuna specially. They also offer regular and super white tuna all seared and non seared. If you don't see them, asked them to make some for you. If you don't know what they look like, just asked. After all, the server is there for you. Oyster is good and fresh as long you asked them. You can fish out from the bar, just keep an eye for the fresh one. They used to have kazunoko, but then they stopped. I also ordered uni and it came with special plate maybe about $5? (forgot). I have to say, one is fresh and one it doesn't. I have to throw that 1 out, it was awful. Their cooked sea bass is very tasty. If you ordered it with half rice bowl (give half for your bf/friend/share other ppl - don't waste it) it's ok. Otherwise, it might be too much flavor just to eat it like that. And don't miss out on that daikon, that's the good stuff. Baked Oyster, spider roll (if you lucky), tobiko, and ikura are so so.  
Service is fast and good. On busy day weekend night, there's always await in sushi bar. You can't make reservation for the bar, but you can on regular table.   

Cleanliness is a bit sketchy. You can tell from the melanin tea glasses, they are all feels like they were soaked in bleach for too long (or too many times). You can even smell the bleach sometimes. Everything is from melanin. From the sushi plate, the sauce whisking place, to their ginger and wasabi plate. I guess, this is the price for having affordable sushi. 

They used to have their soda from fountain and first refill is free and now they just serving from can. And to my surprise it's $2. Wow... I'll stick with my tea. 

Parking is a bitch even on lunch time.
author: Icey M.

description:
What can I say...? I FREAKIN' LOVE THIS PLACE!!!
Having lived just a couple of blocks away from this restaurant, I have been there so many times, and never had a bad experience with the food or the service.
Of course if you go there, please do yourself a favor and do sit at the bar, that's the whole experience right there! 
I love how you get to see the food in front of you and you just pick whatever plate that looks good to you.

I always get half a dozen of oysters and they are always fresh & tasty, not once did I eat a bad one. Their walnut prawn rolls are really good  and so many other plates as well. 

What's great as well is that you just stop eating whenever you're full. No left overs & no doggie bags necessary.
Their prices are really affordable =) 
I just hate the fact that after a good hour sitting there I personally start getting dizzy looking at the boats going 'round & 'round!
author: Fabien F.

description: I've never been here b/4 and we came at dinner time and it was fairly busy. We sat at the boat bar. Picking the freshest selections are best. Very very  inexpensive and not world class sushi by any stretch - sort of like shopping @ Ross: you can find some real treasures -  for the price it can't be beat! It's owned by chinese folks and latino servers lol!! only in SF/The boats made me dizzy!!
author: E S.

description:
Woah, I just read the review about the surfing roach.  Yikes.  

I did not see any adventurous insects on my trip to Sakana Bune, but I did find mediocre sushi at decent prices.  Service was good, the waitresses were attentive.  It was very quiet inside.  Awkwardly quiet.  Pretty shiny gold sushi boats.  As somewhat of a sushi beginner I was a little confused at how you're supposed to know what is what on the sushi boat, so I just stuck with what I recongized: caterpillar roll (ordered, not off boat...I saw that they had eel on the boats AFTER I ordered, grrr), avacado roll and edamame.  Yep, boring and safe, I know.   Still even with something basic like the caterpillar roll I wasn't super impressed.  Next stop, Kitaro.

P.S. Does anyone else wonder how a roach got onto a boat that is moving and surrounded by water?  We should all start worrying a little bit that acrobatic, surfing roaches might exists.
author: Courtney N.

description:
Horrendous sushi boat place. Worst sushi place ever, never ever going back even if sushi is free!
 I'm sorry but the fish were not the freshest, dry and some even looked discolored. I mean, there are some edible sushi boat places but this was not one of them!
author: Yan M.

description:
Ok, this is actually a 3 star restaurant, but they get a 4th star for being open.... ON SUNDAY AFTERNOON!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Do you know how hard it is to find sushi on Sunday after a hungover soccer game? It's hard. Luckily this place has filled my craving multiple times. And for sooo cheap!! There is only 1-2 "exciting" sushi boat rolls, but great maguro nigiri and tempura rolls and variations of the california roll. Definitely worth it. 

Once Jessica L. and I ate appx. 15 plates and were back to our car in 15 minutes. Oops! Guess we inhaled a little too fast. 

The only thing about sushi boats is that they give me ADD. All I do is stare 'up river' and get super exciting every time I see something I might want. I can't let something pass me if it looks good. I'll have 5 plates waiting to be eaten and I'll still be looking up river, one hand on chopsticks, the other ready to pounce on the next delectable plate. Even after we've paid, I just stare at the boats wondering if I missed something amazing. Then I feel my friends pulling me out of the restaurant, the whole time I'm screaming, 'WHAT IF??? WHAT IF THEY MAKE SOME MAGIC ROLL AND WE MISS IT?!?!?"

Ali... Sushi boats aren't magic. 

(to be honest right now, I'm wondering what is floating down the river...)
author: Ali R.

description: This place is one of my favorite sushi restaurants. It is very affordable and they always have their sushi boats filled with nigiri I like.
author: Tracy R.

description:
Contender for the worst sushi in the City.  All these chinese run Fune style conveyor belt places are horrible.  In Japan, pieces that don't move off the belt within a certain amount of time are either combined 2 for 1 to get them off or are eventually discarded and NOT served to customers.  I've been served up sushi with the consistency of wax here and was incredibly insulted that I had to pay for it.  The waitresses are cute, and that's IT.  If you really can't spend more than this for sushi, don't bother eating it.

author: Eric X.

description: I think this has to be one of my favorite places to eat sushi, because it's very inexpensive and also very fresh. The udon and tempura combo is also very cheap for just $7 bucks for both. Lunch is also very affordable as you can get a salmon, chicken teriyaki or katsu for about $5-$6bucks each. My hubby and I usually go here at night and spend less than $20 on both of us with tip included. My only complaint would be the long wait sometimes, so come early and sometimes they don't replace the items I like on the boat very often!
author: Petra S.

description:
HORRIBLE customer service.  
My husband and I went there for the sushi boat service, and we ordered a chicken teriyaki appetizer (not the full dinner).  After 30 minutes, we asked them about the chicken.  Took them 5 minutes to report back that they lost our order.  We ordered it again.  Another 20 goes by.  We're watching people who were seated after us finish their meals and leave.  Inquiring about our second order, looks like it  was lost again - but within 10 minutes, they give us miso soup and the chicken.  OK, we didn't order the soup, but thought maybe they were apologizing for the poor service?  They never did say sorry.
 
When it comes time to pay, our bill is outrageous.  Turns out they charged us for the expensive sushi boat dishes, instead of the cheaper ones that we actually got.  As you may know, they calculate the sushi boat service by the design of the plate that the sushi was served on.  The lower priced sushi and the expensive sushi plates are very similar, but different enough.   And then we noticed, they charged us for a full chicken teriyaki dinner.  Are you kidding me?  Well, if they thought we ordered the full dinner, where was the rice?  Where was the salad?  How about more chicken than the little bit we got?
 
Of course, we complained.  They corrected the sushi plates without question, but then said that since we had to wait, they'll only charge us for the appetizer size of the chicken.  WHAT?!?  That's what we had ordered in the first place!  And they didn't even give us a full dinner - even though they thought that's what we ordered.

This was the only time that we have left a restaurant without leaving a tip.  I'm sorry, but that night was inexcusable and they were not only NOT apologetic, but they acted like they were doing us a favor by charging us only for what we had actually ordered?  We have never been back.
I wish I could give 0 stars.
author: Denise M.

description:
Honey Walnut Prawn sushi :) 

I always find myself coming here for lunch or for some light dinner before a night out. So if you're poor, on a budget, and just plain cheap at the moment, come here for some good sushi. You won't be disappointed especially with these prices. Be smart about what you get since each different colored tray coincides with the price.
author: Alexa M.

description:
Amelia your post is frightening for sure. BUT I agree with Ali R. this is a rare sushi place open for lunch on the weekends in the Inner and Outer Richmond. And its pretty good!

I like that the boats include quite a few "fancy" rolls for their menu - what a great way to get people to try the bigger expensive rolls without committing to 8 pieces. They also have random sides on the boats (edamame, Oysters, etc). The sushi is very good but not fantastic. Service is fast and I love this place after soccer games too.
author: Jessica L.

description:
It's not the best place for sushi, but it is cheap. It's cheap probably because their servings are smaller than most places. One thing I hate about most restaurants is that they give such big portions and charge so much when sometimes, I'd rather have half the portion at half the price.

At Sakana Bune, you can order more of a variety because their dishes are not gigantic. A lot of their hot dishes are only around $6-10. Ordering two things here could cost as much as ordering one thing somewhere else.

This is a good spot to eat regularly because it won't chew up your wallet, but you're looking for sushi with a wow factor, find another restaurant.
author: Jonas T.

description:
Been to Sakane Bune a handful of times, but not till I came from lunch today did I feel the need to review the place.  I just ordered sushi, and I'm sure glad I did because a co-worker of mine ordered a chicken terriyaki entree and it took over thirty minutes to get to her.  I ordered the rainbow and the hip hop roll (eel and avocado).  The fish wasn't the freshest I've had, but was passable.  The white fish, as a co-worker noted was creamy..which I guess is a good thing cause I enjoyed it and white fish is usually my least favorite.  The avocados used were a bit mushy, perhaps a little over ripped or been sitting out too long.  

From what I can tell, the chicken terriyaki was below par, a mix of white and dark meat and some with skin still atop.  Sucks because she waited for thirty minutes and she couldn't even say it was worth the wait.  

Service was non-attentive.  We had to keep asking about the chicken terriyaki entree, and never once did they apologize for the delay.  Sure they filled our tea and water, but not before spilling an entire glass of water on one of my co-workers.  Later we had a hard time flagging the waitress down for the bill too.  

I have to admit, I'll probably go again for quick and passable sushi, but hopefully get a seat at the bar accessible to the sushi boat, as I usually have a better experience there.
author: Marie B.

description:
Super cheap sushi boat joint. But the variety is lacking. Sure, every now and then an amazing oyster/custard on a half shell or a walnut /avocado roll will float by, but for the most part it's your typical nigiri and other simple rolls.

The sushi I ate wasn't bad at all, so it'll satisfy your sushi craving, but if you want something more than the Safeway pre-pack variety (which this is one notch above) you'll probably want to go somewhere else. But at $1 - $1.95 for a plate of two, you're getting what you pay for.

I also tried their vegetable udon soup which was filling but I was hoping for something with a bit more kick in the broth. My friend, Arlene has a good point when she says she refuses to order udon at restaurants because she knows it's one of the cheaper things for the restaurant to throw together and she rather not spend $6 on something that really costs $1.
author: Viv C.

description:
Sakabune is not bad if jus want to chill n eat small plates. I mean technically you get waht you pay for. Dont expect GRADE A sushi from a place like this. I personally think the sushi here isnt that bad. Its not a authentic sushi bar slice n dice place, its just a little restuarant with little boats that sail across you. You pick waht you want and they jus add up the plates. Cheap meal, So if you hankein for a small snack and jus feel like eating some sushi, jus come by.

props to the honey walnut roll...
author: phillip w.

description:
Don't blame me, for I know no better.
Sakana Bune was my first dip into sushi, and while I was iffy at first, I didn't think it was so bad, but on occasion, the eel feels like it's tasting me back... it's not supposed to be that way, right?

But my heart goes out to the honey walnut rolls, oh honey walnut rolls, I know I'm allergic to shrimp..even tempura-ed... but I eat them nonetheless... but I believe that they are the only reason that I keep going back.. oh, and the super nice wait staff... 'sides, on occasion we get our edamame on the house. Oh, and although I've never had chicken udon anywhere else, theirs is pretty tasty, and they give you a lot of chicken.

:edit:
Sakana has improved their menu and seems to be a bit fresher (unless you get there right before they close). Yay!!
author: Jenn H.

description:
SuuuuuuuuuuuuuuShhiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiii Boat!

I don't know why I said it like that, but hell.. I can't think of much more. 

This is a standard, typical sushi boat restaurant.  Nothing special and ZERO offense, people.  The Tamago, for some damned reason is one of my tests and the tamago was a rubbery thing of no good yuck yuck.

The other stuff was okay.  It was horrible... but it wasn't the best.  BUT SUSHI BOATS!  YAH YAH YAH!!!!

This is a high end formalize terminology for.... not really the best sushi.  But simple, cheap, and you can't count as you go, while playing bobby bob with the boats..  So fun and easy.

And the little boats are fun. did i mention?
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
Another case of curiosity almost killing the cat.  

My thirst for novelty was piqued by the fascinating procession of things on the sushi boats: kimchee snails, baby octopus in sweet and sour sauce, fat hoso maki stuffed with spicy tuna, all of which I ate and instantly regretted.  The tuna was obviously heavily spiced and ground up because it was old and tough and smelly, and the other two dishes were excessively chewy and gave me a headache.

What saves this place from an all-out 1-star diss is their no-rice maki, a trend I'd dearly love to see catch on.  They have an "avocado sashimi" roll that is actually pretty darn tasty by virtue of the great quality avocado they use(d).

I'm baffled by the amount of people eating sashimi plates here though.  I had a small order of "hamachi toro" (riiiight) and hey, what do you know, instantly regretted that too.

Sashimi Snob says no.
author: Naomi M.

description:
I went here over the weekend, and I must say that it is a good place to go to if you're looking for some quick, affordable sushi. 

Their sushi boat bar looked pretty cool, although I didn't sit there. 

Their meals were affordable and good. Most sushi rolls cost about $5-$8 depending on what you are getting, and consist of about 8-9 pieces I believe. They do have more sushi rolls of course, some ranging from $12-$15, but those are the fancy ones if you're into that stuff. You can also order small orders of sushi (2-4) pieces ranging from $1.94 - $3.95. 

I ordered two rolls (caterpillar and bune), chicken katsu (came with salad, soup, rice), and a small roll and the fee was only $25. Not bad IMO.

I like this place because...

- affordable
- tasty, especially considering the low price
- nice, friendly staff

Keep in mind....

- They do accept credit/debit, but you need a minimum $20.00 fee.
author: Joy Q.

description:
I heart this place. Inexpensive and yummy...plus there's usually no wait at lunch. Try their Walnut Roll...so good!

The service is great too. They are always on hand to fill up your tea, or take your order if you don't see something on the boats.
author: Jayson J.

description:
I only like this place cause it's the cheapest sushi on boats resturant I know of.

I love their calamari in a bowl dish.

The one thing I hate about this place is there was a piece of seran wrap in my udon. No, sorry, just i'll get you another one.
author: Keit K.

description:
If you're in the outer Richmond Sakana Bune is hands down the best option for sushi for the following reasons:

1) Price. As SF sushi bars go, it's a GREAT value for you money.
2) Service.  They are on the ball here.  You never have ask for more tea or (free) refills on soda.
3) Speed. Their turnover volume is amazing.  I've been able to get a spot for one or two within 15 mins on crazy busy weekend evenings.
4) Novelty.  What can I say, I love rotating sushi boat buffets!

So yeah, probably not the most authentic sushi ever, and there are more "gourmet" sushi restaurants, but all-in-all a pretty good joint.
author: Dave S.

description:
Are you a fan of sushi boat?  TRY THIS!!  It's an alternative to upscale Isobune in J-town..

Way down Geary, where it becomes foggy..

Three words-

CHEAP..(1.50 for salmon sashimiii)  loves it!
FRESH..
GOOD SUSHI/SASHIMI

Okay, 5 words, I suck at math..haha
author: C Q.

description:
My roommate and I used to come here at least once a week. I'm really disappointed in the past few experiences and will probably avoid coming back here again. Lately, the sushi boats have not only been half full, but every single roll on them has the crab mix in it - no diversity there. Also, the past 2 times I went, I have come home feeling sick to my stomach. I'm thinking they're not caring about leaving old sushi riding around on the boats anymore.

GROOSSS
author: Sarah P.

description:
I live right down the street from this place and I have to force myself not to eat here.  It's great because it is sooo fast. I can run in and have 2 bites of sushi and some miso soup all for under $10 and 10 minutes. I'll stick up for their wait staff, everyone has always been really friendly to me. 

I really wish I didn't know the stuff I know about this place. Like I said I live right down the street and walk by everyday.  They always have their kitchen door open to the sidewalk and use the sidewalk as an extension of their kitchen counter. One day I walked by and a bunch of little black birds where perched on a box of lettuce. (If it had been pigeons I would have puked, i'm sure of it.) Another day they had a bucket of teriyaki cooling outside, without a lid! 

I also saw them bringing in frozen deep fried oysters from Costco and packaged Udon.

Their Kitchen isn't very clean, they don't properly recycle. If you must eat here, go when it's busy and items aren't endlessly floating around. 
Sorry neighbor.
author: T B.

description:
I just love going here. The servers are very attentive and friendly. The food is pretty fresh. I always just order what I want to eat rather than wait for the boat to come to me. The super fatty white seared tuna is delicious and I always keep coming back for it. 

The only thing I wish was that parking was a little bit easier. But otherwise, this place rocks!
author: Helen H.

description: I love this place and frequently eat here. Their walnut prawn rolls are very good. The prices are very good and I love the floating sushi boats. They have a good selection there and you only get charged per 2-3 piece plate that you eat so it can be very inexpensive.
author: Ben S.

description: I come for the seriously good deal you get on nigiri here. I usually end up eating at least a dozen pieces of the salmon, it's just that good. There are a bunch of other great rolls available too; the honey walnut roll is surprisingly tasty. I always leave feeling completely satisfied, and the service is top notch. My go-to place for lunch or a quick dinner.
author: John R.

description: My mom and I came here to celebrate her birthday, her choice.  The food was pretty delicious and cheap.  The boats are super fun--especially for people like me that have a love for sparkly things and toys--the boats and sparkly gold.  All was good and well until I took a large swig of water and then realized that my cup was sort of crusted and dirty inside--like a film.  It was not noticeably dirty, but it was noticeable once I smelled the gross smell of grime.  I was uber-grossed out after this, and I am not totally sure I can bring myself to go back even though I was super optimistic at first.  AGH.  Hard times.  The servers were friendly and one of the sushi chefs was very chatty and nice.  Hard choice!
author: Julia D.

description:
If you like conveyor belt sushi, go for it. I like to look at my food before I eat it and the belt was whizzing too fast. 

Opted to sit at table as wanted to stretch out and ordered a few rolls. Looked at the prices and thought things couldnt go wrong with these prices, and ordered the Rainbow, Aztec and Monster rolls. Kept a menu behind incase we wanted more.... Maybe in hindsight I should have stuck to the basic as they looked better... 

It was a little hectic at the conveyor belt but only a few of the tables were occupied, but boy, THE SERVICE WAS SLOW.... we had to wait around 15 to 20 minutes for each roll to come out. Good job we didnt wait for everthing to come out before starting otherwise we would have been chomping the table. We were staring at our empty plates for majority of the time we were there. And looking around, it was the same for everone else. The wait staff seemed to not care, mucking about behind the cash desk in between clearing out areas at the bar to make room for people waiting. 

Rainbow roll was pretty medicore. Never been so unsatified before- its usually the roll I get to rate a sushi restaurant. The selection of fish, especially the salmon was not very appetising, the salmon looked very pale. I hope I dont get sick later. The Aztec roll and Monster roll looked exactly the same as each other- we even thought they made a mistake. Both had baked salmon on the top (we were warned that it may take a little time to prepare these rolls as they needed to be cooked somewhat- !!!!- how long does it take to cook thin slices of fish on some rolls?!) the fish was WAAAYY over cooked. I had to soak roll in soy sauce to help move the fish down- so dry.  Am glad we didnt order more and made it a light dinner cos we would probably be still waiting for it by closing time.

The thing with sushi rolls is not matter what, you are drawn to the menu with the pictures. They wet your appetite and it makes you look forward to your food (well it does for me)... And the rolls we got looked NOTHING like what we were expecting. Man, i aint coming back. $36 on three rolls and  a soda, spent one and half hours staring at empty plates.... There are so many other choices nearby, go elsewhere.....
author: Sushi Y.

description:
When I just want to gorge myself on cheap sushi, I come to Sakana Bune. One does not come here expecting an exclusive sushi bar, friendly chefs, sashimi right off live fish, and omakase. For me, coming here is purely an exercise in gluttony.

That's fine though, because there are certainly worse things you can stuff yourself with. Their sushi boat selection actually has a fair amount of variety; enough to eat eleven or twelve plates' worth without consuming the same thing twice. And, unlike the claims of a previous reviewer, it's not just derivatives of california rolls either; there's a fair amount of nigiri and sashimi.

You could call it the McDonald's of sushi restaurants. I give Sakana Bune three stars, because you wouldn't give McDonald's more than three stars, would you?
author: Horace K.

description: Of the three sushi restaurants right next to each other on Geary between 21st and 22nd, this is the middle-grade one. The sushi was acceptable given the price, but it wasn't anything super special. The prices were middle of the road as well, perhaps cheaper than I might expect for the average Japanese place. Atmosphere was ok, not as polished decor as Little Tokyo, but better than Kitaro. I'd go here again if I was looking for casual Japanese but didn't want to spend too much. This place is taken up mostly by a sushi bar, not a lot of tables. This doesn't really matter though since I've never really seen any sort of wait for the tables
author: Tyler C.

description:
As far as the quality of the sushi is concerned, four stars is an overstatement. However, you get what you pay for. And for being the only sushi place open at 10:30 on a Friday night in Outer Richmond -- when my stomach was growling with hunger pains, I'll give them four stars.

The sushi is not fantastic, but for the price, you can't beat it. The selection is good and the portions are generous.

One suggestion... Slow down the sushi boats! When you have customers with hand-eye coordination as terrible as myself (yes, I take after my dog), the 100 mile per hour sushi boats will actually cause me to have to think before I pick. Sushi boats are not supposed to incite brain activity!
author: Ed A.

description: hey folks say what you want (and you do) but this place is cheap and tasty.  It's a LOT cheaper than most sushi boat places and I have never ever had a bad piece of fish here.  My flat mate and I have eaten here for under $10 total on several occasions.  Of course there is better sushi near by but the watch words are "cheap" "quick" and "tasty".  No frills here but you have to give them props for keeping a very healthy business going when they are one of three sushi places on the block.
author: Julienne G.

description:
Its not the greatest of all places but for the price you pay the food is quite good. The wait staff is friendly and on top of it.

I would absolutely recommend it.
author: Amlan S.

description:
I LOOOVE this place!  I found it a few months ago while working with a new client.  Found it for lunch and have been hooked ever since.  I live in South San Francisco, so it's a bit of a hike to go have dinner there.

The sushi rolls average from average to excellent.  Today, I tried a roll that was quite spicy and excellent.  In almost any sushi establishment, I gotta have a bit of soy sauce to bring out the flavor.  Today, not the case!  I was very happy with my meal.  With tip, my dinner was still less that $15.  Excellent!

I usually feel a bit bad for the waitresses that work at these places...  They are usually running around like they think their job is on the line if they don't look busy enough.  Here, not only were they relaxed, but actually having a good time.  Man, the laughing of those sweet voices was...  Kinda hot!  I just thought of that...  It brought up the mood of the place for sure.  Mind you, service was still great.

If it were romantic or had a little more atmosphere, it would be THE place for me to go.  But, it's still a great place for lunch, dinner and to take a date and enjoy good food and chit-chat.
author: R G.

description:
It's okay. parking is CRAZZZY. It took us an HOUR to find a spot on a Sunday night.

taste was greattt. Or maybe it was because I was sick and i couldn't taste anything? but yeah. I LOVED the sushi here, and I ate A LOT. 

knocked off a star for...how we went around for an HOUR trying to park.
author: Betty T.

description:
Not the freshest tasting sushi.  But it works for the cheap prices.  There is also something extra going on in my head with food floating by me every half second.  I morph into Sylvester the Cat with swirly, hungry-eyes.

Staff is mostly friendly.  The interior decor is so-so.  Parking during lunch can be found by circling th block once.  When you need something quick, cheap, and serviceable, you can rely on this place.
author: Pete M.

description: There are not many sushi boat restaurants in The City. The sushi here is average, but this where I go for sushi boat.
author: Forest S.

description:
i am not a sushi expert i am just a foodie who is MAYO-PARANOID;) i hate mayo and they HAD mayo in their sushi!!! really? is it a necessary sushi ingredient? i i didn't know that!  I was politely getting rid of it (with a smile on my face in front of the waitress). Oh... how painful that was!...

i mean that's a nice place and blah-blah-blah but i would prefer to go somewhere else instead.
author: moa m.

description:
People come here because of the price. The sushi is alright, nothing special. Sometimes, when you sit at the bar, you get tired of seeing the same things go by.. 

Parking sucks though if you're going for dinner.
author: C. Z.

description:
This place is good when 1) you're feeling like basic sushi 2) you're feeling cheap 4) it's midday and you don't want to wait for a table or for the  sushi boat counter. 

My hubby loves this place but he's into quantity, not quality. True, their honey-walnut roll, though decidedly not authentic Japanese, is yummy in that sushi-shouldn't-be-sweet-like-this sort of way. And their basic sushi is good and satisfies the 'sushi tooth.'

But don't expect any monkfish liver or other exotic type sushis. It's like the pizza by the slice place if you're not into going and getting a table at the woodfired place.
author: joann p.

description:
Ok... this place flat out SUCKS! 
I've gone there a few times and it wasn't that great but the last time i went there... that was the last straw. 
First off, there was about 6 or 7 of us and we got a table in front (there weren't that many people there, mind you), we looked over our menus , ordered sake...and from there it all went downhill.

Where to begin?
So, we had to keep calling them to us so we could order. Then once we finally did order, it took them about 15 mins to bring out ONE order of california rolls (for ONE person at our table). 20 mins later we wanted to know where our damn food is...they said "it's not ready"....10 mins after that, i started getting pissed off! 
Another order of avocado rolls was put on our table and I'm like HELLO??? where's the rest of our order??!! 
More time went by...and nothing. I just about had it at that point and after about an hour of waiting for a freakin' honey walnut roll, i went up to one of the chicks and said "you know what...just give us the check...your service blows" and right at that moment, another waitress literally swoops in with the roll i ordered. I turned it down and said "too late...no thanks" and we walked out. It almost ruined my night...almost.

PLUS ONE star for the sake...it got me buzzed... so that was good. 
MINUS A BAZILLION STARS FOR NO FOOD @ A RESTAURANT!!!!!!

People, there's like 2+ other sushi places on the same street..so don't even bother giving this place the time of day...
author: Diana T.

description:
You get what you pay right? I just like how it sail on a little boat. 

Food wise... it's edible.. 

Not much I can say because you can probably get the same thing from Kome Buffet.
author: William C.

description: Food is always of good quality. The service here is top notch. Even on a busy night, there is not that long of a wait. They always have high quality Uni.
author: James B.

description: Sushi here is alright, if you sit at the bar. Good luck trying to find fresh cold sushi though. Most of the once that pass by you are like room temperature.
author: Terry S.

description:
When I think of sushi, I think of a serene river in Japan. I think of cherry blossoms floating on top of the clear, crisp water. I think of salmon and tuna so bountiful they are leaping from the surface and splashing joyfully.

I wouldn't really call this a sushi place. The funky smell, the dirty appliances (severe cockroaches, see http://www.cleanscores.com/1478/Sakana+Bune+Restaurant# ) in full view from the seats at the sushi boat bar.. that's not what I think of when I think of sushi. 

But, this place IS good for things that can't possibly go wrong, like miso soup, veggie rolls, and these strangely delicious deep-fried potato cake thingies. Plus, it's CHEAP. You can fill up on the non-shady items for around $10. Here's what I had:

Potato cakes 1.25 each ( had like 2 of them, so 2.50 total)
Rice inside tofu pocket thing forget the name 1.25 each (2 plates of 2 = 2.50
Green Seaweed Roll (tasty!) 1.85
Brown Seaweed Roll (super tasty!) 1.85
Cucumber roll 1.25
Miso soup 1 (?) can't really remember the price of the miso

Equals exactly $10!

For that, I would have given this place a solid 3 stars, but I had to dock it for two infractions:

1. Server guy spilled water on me. He said he was sorry, but he didn't do anything nice for me. If I had gone to pretty much any other sushi place in the city and had water spilled on me, they would've discounted the bill or brought me free dessert or SOMETHING. Psh.
2. I get motion sickness easily. Especially on car rides, I puke sometimes. The sushi boat line was moving around so fast, that I literally got motion sickness from it being right in my face.
author: Rachel H.

description:
This place is fun and has a great community feel.  It's cheap and decent, but not a place for a connoisseur.  My friends and I like to have eating competitions to see who can rack up the most amount of plates. The record, in my group is 25.  
The service is good and if you don't see anything coming out you like mention it and they will add it to the flotilla.
author: mika m.

description: Food is pretty good, prices are OK, but the staff, including manager, are SO rude!  It just ruins the entire experience there.  With so many other competing Japanese eateries, why not have a pleasant dining experience?  You're paying for it.
author: A T.

description:
I have been coming to this place for about 8 years....love this place.  I like the cost, the service and food.  

Those boats go by quite quickly.  If you missed your plate do not worry it will be back in a few seconds.  

I am kinda of guy when there no tea in my cup do not be surprize I'll just help myself for a refill!   When that happens.......

It nearly become a World Wrestling Federation match with sweet looking Japanese girls!  

I always gotten my tea refilled ever since! 

Who ever said that candied walnut sushi  rolls was good is right on!  Best you're ever tasted in your freaking life.

Thanks
author: Tristan T.

description: I love sushi boat. But sushi boat restaurants here are quite disappointing when compared to those in Asia. Having said that, I am someone who needs immediate gratification. I want what I want and I want it now. This is especially true when I'm hungry. So the food usually starts off as a 4 (out of 5) for me...cuz I'm starving... by the time I'm somewhat full and there's glucose traveling to my brain, I realized the food is of average quality. The service is oh-Kay, I mean you get the food yourself but the waitresses check on you every so often to refill drinks. This is a close drive from home so when I'm starving and I want sushi, Sakana Bune can usually satisfy me right away.
author: Chrisy C.

description: It's ok here , everyone that works here is super cool and nice! Only reasonable boat place in the neighborhood.. Sashimi is usually almost always fresh. I think for the prices "which are very good" you will not be dissapointed
author: Damien F.

description:
I thought this place had ok conveyor belt sushi. Nothing on the conveyor was over $2. Going into these places you know that you are not expecting the best sushi in the world (it is so cheap), so you can't judge it that way. I was surprised to read all of the negative reviews on Yelp. 

Our food tasted good and seemed fresh. I noticed the chef taking off plates periodically and replacing with new plates. Maybe all of the bad reviews/inspections have caused improvement.

Moral of the story - you get what you pay for. Overall this was a good, sushi restaurant for the price.
author: Brandy S.

description: Really enjoy this place, especially being a sushi boat restaurant.  They do have seating at normal tables if you want to order something specific.  The sushi here is pretty fresh and its usually busy enough to see the sushi chefs placing the freshly made dishes on the boats.  Prices are fairly reasonable, just watch how much you're eating along with the price of the dish.  I will definitely come back!
author: Jesse C.

description:
4 stars for their cheap (prices) sushi.

The fish isn't the freshest batch you'll find in SF, but it isn't bad at all. Nice too if you are taking friends who've never seen a floating sushi boat. My little brother loves it everytime he comes by to visit SF. Love that he can just pick what he wants off from the boat. He's been a foodie since he was 5. 

I can almost use the term fast-food (in a good way) to describe this place on the occasions where I just want something to right away. As I walk to a seat at the bar, I ask for my tea and a bottle of Asahi, pour myself some soy sauce, mix in some wasabi, crack those chopsticks apart and starting eating all within a few minutes of entering the restaurant.

One nice thing about this place. You can get pretty inexpensive toro. That stuff is the dessert of sashimi. Just melts in your mouth. Even the smell from your post-meal burp smells good.
author: Kien L.

description: Decent place for sushi! Though, there's usually a wait for seats at the sushi boat bar, everything is reasonably priced and there is a wide variety of items on sushi boats. They also offer a ton of other items and rolls on the menu, and an unagi bowl special, with soup and salad for like $4 at any time of the day. Not many items are particularly fresh tasting nor cold.
author: Chelsea P.

description:
People should know, before going here, that their expectations of really quality sushi should be throw out of the door.

The quality isn't poor by any means, but it isn't your fancy sushi place where the sushi chef sits in front of you and plans your meal for you.

The food is cheap, which is hard to find for sushi but it's good...you leave feeling satisfied.  Go here for a quick cheap meal.  My bf and I come every couple of weeks to fulfill our sushi needs, we save the fancy places for other ocassions.

Word of warning, the waitresses can be a bit much.
author: Winnie L.

description:
You gotta have good eyes when you come here. My bf says it's not good to eat sashimi here, but I always eat it anyway. You just have to see if the sashimi look fresh. If it does, then just grab quick! because this is a sushi boat and food just float around. Good sushi won't wait for you! hahaha

My bf says this place is cheap, but I think it's pretty expensive when you come hungry. We ended up paying $60-70 sometimes just for the two of us. (maybe because of the sashimi I always eat. they are the red dish and red dish is the most expensive one)

Service is alright. Some ppl say it's dirty, but I think it's alright.
author: Sweet J.

description:
I absolutely love this place. I literally came here twice a week when I used to live in the city. 

Probably the main thing that attracts me is the price - you can get a lot for paying little, compared to the sushi restaurants over here in the East Bay. The sushi combination plate at Sakana that I've gotten is around 7 bucks, whereas the plates at most of the restaurants here average around 14 bucks..Yeah, Sakana Bune is the way to go. But they only accepted credit cards on charges $20+.

I love the sushi. I've never actually tried the rolls or the actual food. But the sushi, I can't get enough of. If you don't see something you're craving for on the boat, simply ask them and they'll make it for you. Depending on what time you arrive, the boat is usually full (but I don't mind waiting for it). If you don't want to wait, you can pick out the sushi you want from the boat and bring it to a table. (The tables are usually empty since the boat is more popular). Try the mango mochi as well, it's to die for in my opinion.

However, the service here is pretty bad. Not necessarily slow, but it couldn't hurt for them to smile every now and then.. They are pretty rude, which is why I never leave a generous tip. But they always expect one. Once my friend's mom didn't leave a tip, and they asked why. Are waitresses supposed to do that...?

Either way, I'm a patient person and the service will never stop me from coming here. It's toooooooo awesome.
author: Tiffany T.

description:
This place is aight. You know?  For Chinese sushi.  The rice is small and the fish is big, thats good.

The things I like about Sushi boats is that I dont have to ask for anything or deal with waiters or waitresses.  

The tea is brought to me, and the soy sauce, wasabi, ginger, chopsticks, food, everything is in my face.  I eat until I cant eat anymore, they come to count my plates and I pay. Simple as that.  

Minus some cool points because they dont have much of a variety, but my Number one FAVE they do have here is the White tuna.  oh that is delish. like butter in my mauhf.

Im not a picky eater sooo.....i like it.
author: kim w.

description: I love this place. It's become one of my favs. I must say however, that I have never ordered off of the menu. Go early for the freshest pick off the sushi boats and you won't be disappointed! It's not gourmet by any means but what can you expect with plates for $1.95-$3.95? It's quick and cheap! Most of the boat selecton rolls are some variation of the traditional Califormia Roll. but tasty! And the nigiri is usually really good (depending on the time). Plus, the big beers and sake are very affordable. If you're looking for a quick bite for under $15, go here! Sushi snobs need not apply....
author: Turi M.

description: I only come for the sushi boat... and maybe I only come for the HONEY WALNUT SHRIMP SUSHI! I usually sit down waiting for it to come around then I learned that I can ask the chef to make it so if you don't feel like waiting ask! If you're on a budget its pretty easy to spend a good $20+ here.
author: J B.

description:
I absolutely love this place.  I go for the nigiri and honey walnut roll, and my boyfriend goes for the snails and other cooked sushi.

The fish are very fresh, and some of the best slices I've ever seen.  The "extra white" tuna is absolutely phenomenal, and I could eat an entire meal of just salmon rolls/nigiri/sashimi.

Service is fast, even when they're busy, and it's the best-priced sushi in town.
author: Lucca C.

description:
I'm glad SF has a reasonably priced boat place, but unfortunately, their quality is sub par.  Plus, the parking sucks in this area.  Come on!  If I'm so lazy that I have to grab a plate of sushi that floats by - so lazy that I can't be arsed to order something from a waitress - then I sure as hell am too lazy to take Muni out here!

For great boats, try Isobune in Japantown.  More expensive, but worth the price.  For great sushi, go anywhere else.  But I still come here because I can get stuffed on sushi for like $15 and I can put away the raw fish, believe you me.
author: Frankie D.

description:
The sushis on the boat go 'round and 'round..

Eels. California rolls. Potstickers and other sushis I can't name. They just keep on comin'. But the one that's worth the wait is def the honey walnut prawn sushis. They don't come around the corner often so when they do, you really need to swipe at it and claim your sushi. But seriously, there are many other sushi places out there but choose this one 'cause you can't beat the price.
author: Steph W.

description:
We stopped here for a late lunch, since everything else was closed. I was reluctant at first, since the place didn't look too appetizing from the outside. I was also worried that the food on the sushi boats might have become gross, after having been ferried around for hours. But my worries were unfounded after all.

The food was great! I loved the salmon sashimi, and for the price, it can't be beat. The sushi was surprisingly fresh, despite the fact that we visited at 3pm. Service was also excellent. I had the deep-fried ice-cream as a dessert, and that was a nice treat too. I'd certainly come back, given the fine food and great prices. Two can easily dine for less than 20 bucks.
author: Barn M.

description: Cheap mediocre sushi.  Service is decent.  the speciality rolls are better than the floating junk.  it's still a better buy than kitaro down the street, I guess.
author: Kris H.

description: It's not the freshest sushi I've ever had at a sushi boat place but this place fills my need for it, the plates are affordable and if you're not paying attention your bill might end up being a lot higher than you originally intended.  The only item I remember ordering off the menu is their tempura which is average and what you'd expect as far as tempura goes.  The service could be better and it's usually hit or miss with any of them.  Finding parking is difficult on any given night so have patience if you drive here.
author: Emy B.

description:
this place is awesome!!!!! i've been here a grand total of three times and it never fails to disappoint. the last time i was here my friend introduced me to the super white tuna and since then i've been in love. the buttery, melt-in-your-mouth texture and flavor were to die for!!!!

I was just here today for dinner and i alone had about 6-7 plates of the super white tuna alone. :) so good. i think the chef noticed i kept taking the super white tuna so he put out some plates with just the fish for me. :) haha. but yes i can't wait for the next time i'm back. :)
author: Anne H.

description:
Sushi boat restaurants are like floating buffets if you're a patient diner...and a little like Russian roulette if you're a hasty diner.

So this place probably isn't the best sushi place in the city, but if I'm getting sushi, I'll probably be in here.  This place is cheap-plates are $1.25 to $2.95 and I'm eating within seconds of being seated; a great place to get a quick bite to eat.  Sometimes.  

I've come up with a rule for this place, if you recognize a plate go by 3 times, let it go.  The best meals were the ones where I waited until the ones I wanted were fresh off the chef's cutting board, and the worst meals were the ones where I grabbed indiscriminately.  

Good (to great) sushi and great prices, would I drive for 20 minutes to eat here?  Probably not, but 5 minute walk is just about right.
author: Mike U.

description:
I'm tearing myself up between a 2 or a 3 star review. So I guess I'll decide by the end of this thing.

Pros:
creamy avocado
delicious fresh oysters w/ some kind of yummy spicy sauce (me, not being a fan of oysters)

Cons:
my friend told me that there was a fly in their soy sauce by the time they finished the whole bottle (but that didn't stop me from coming here)
It looks very Chinese actually, rather than Japanese. There is nothing special about the decor and it looks kinda dull and sloppy actually.
the service was not very friendly, but it wasn't horrible either. 

In-Betweens:
basically everything else belongs in this section. The rolls were alright, but none being memorable.
spicy salmon roll
unagi roll
california roll
some other roll w/ hamachi in
the tea was not the rice tea they should've been serving.

just a note:
They do have the option of sitting at the revolving sushi boat or at the tables

result: the oyster saved your ass.
author: Elaine H.

description:
The floating sushi boat concept is well, good in concept, but not always so fantastic in execution. In Japan, when you eat at a place like this, everyone around you has piles of empty plates around them and the sushi/sashimi offerings are glistening. So you know the turnover is high, and the food is fresh.  Not the case at Sakana Bune, at all.

I was thrilled to be seated immediately and to be able to grab a plate of tuna sashimi to satiate my hunger. But from there, it all went downhill.

Cheap? 
Yes.
Tasty? 
A resounding no.
Instant gratification if you're starving? 
Yes (but not worth the tummy ache later).

Also, I'm pretty sure the owners aren't Japanese, not that it always matters, but it makes me dubious.  They had some dim sum offerings on the floating boats, which threw me off (deep fried crab claw, anyone?)  And when I ordered the udon, there wasn't even one bottle of nanami togarashi in sight or offered. Not recommended.
author: Suepattra M.

description: Good place if you are looking for inexpensive and tasty sushi, the best in terms of ratio quality - price. I would recommend to try ikura, fried ice cream, salmon lovers and seafood udon. It is definitely not the right place for a date or private conversation, however it is perfect for regular dinner after work.
author: Elena C.

description:
It's rare for me to find a sushi restaurant outside the Bay Area that I enjoy, and so when I do I like to ask its staff what *their* favorite, go-to Japanese place is when they're in San Francisco.

I can't believe THIS place was one of those which was recommended to me recently.  The raw fish was just a few hours away from being totally stale and off; the rice was seasoned poorly; and the portions were sad.

Okay, so it wasn't terrible, but it was bad enough that I regretted making the effort to come here and I even lost a little respect for the restaurant that referred me here.  Maybe by recommending a crappy place they were trying to highlight how good they were in comparison.
author: James L.

description:
This place only good for when you short of money and don't care of quality and service, the price is cheap, 
The server Latino girl order me can not cross the line of the table after I sit down on the chair she setup. She need to save that for a signal customer. I get yell for didn't do any thing.  OK when I start eating my dinner then I found the sushi rice are raw! Make sure the rice not the fish, I don't wanna eat the rice raw.
author: jimmy l.

description:
Ew...where to begin....

My friend and I wanted sushi so we went here because my friend used to like it. We wish we had a magical sushi time machine and pick a different place.

We sat down and had the kids at the table next to us practically sitting on our laps because the tables were so close. It was really weird and I felt like I had to censor my conversation on a girl's night dinner.

Our waitress never really came. We had to flag someone down every time. We ordered our food and got things at random times. I was slightly mad that when I ordered one roll the girl just went to the boats and picked it off of it. I really don't like to get rolls off the boats because I have no idea when it was made and how long it was just flowing down the river. 

The food was ok, nothing super great and crazy. The rolls were sloppy and didn't look like someone even put any effort into them.:(

The "service" just got worst and worst. We kept asking for the check. We told them our meter ran out and we need to go. We kept asking. And we got it, Hallelujah! 

We just threw our cards at her and reminded her that we needed to leave...NOW! She then fought with us how there is a $20 min. We said that we were sorry but we had zero cash. She claimed that she told us many times before and went to go check her list of names of people. 

It of course being my first (and last) at this dump, I wasn't on the list. The girl then continue to write our names on this blacklist of people who don't have enough cash. This process took 10 minutes...during this process, my friend said "we need to effing leave, just let us effing pay!" We paid, we didn't tip. Our bills were even wrong to begin with. 

They told us we are written down and we won't be able to charge next time...and I yelled as I left "THERE WON'T BE A NEXT TIME"
author: Karen B.

description:
I'll give this place 3 stars cause they have great service, Hot sake, cool beers and CHEAP CHEAP ass food.

Unagi-Don for $4, what more can you ask for? sushi is alright, and the rolls are nothing great.
author: Jose S.

description:
i ALWAYS come here for sushi.  I don't care what any of you say, I'll always count on this place for some cheaper Japanese food.  I can share an entree, two specialty rolls, a few California rolls, spicy tuna rolls and still just spend around $30.  Tell me where else you can find that price and I'll think about going somewhere else.

I also just prefer their California rolls over other places because they use the crab salad and only costs ONE DOLLAR.  Sashimi special for 4.95?!  Man, I don't know why I don't come here even more often than I do.  Unagi bowl for $4.95!  $3.95 during lunch!  I'm getting hungry just thinking about it.

The only real gripe I have about this place is their service.  One day, we'll have really good service, on time and attentive... and then another day, we'll have to keep flagging them down and telling them to check on our food.  There was always this one waitress named Wanda that really took care of us but she's no where to be found.  Oh well, I'll probably be back there again in a few weeks.
author: Chris C.

description:
I thought it would be kinda cool since they had the boats floating around kinda like Isobune in J Town.  But the food was not very good.  I would give them 1 star for the food but since they are relatively cheap, I guess I'll be generous today.  

But seriously, there are so many other Good, Quality Japanese restaurants, why would you even consider going here.  Below Average Sushi at Below Average Prices.....
author: Mark W.

description:
Service here has continued to decline here...it's sad because I use to go eat dinner at this place often. The girls working there seem to just want to talk to each other more than they want to do their jobs. Then they wonder why they receive a bad tip...
The selection on the sushi boat depends on what time you go there. If you don't see what you like you can just order it, but the issue is getting one of waitresses to take the order. The soda tasted watered down. I asked for a Sprite and the waitress fails to inform me that they have some generic version of Sprite. Taste is not the same..anyways...i wish the owner luck and hope customer service gets better very soon.
author: Mike W.

description:
I've been back here many times since my review from a year ago, and I'm still a very happy customer. New favorites of mine are the K & Y Roll (hamachi, avocado, crabmeat and masago) and Monster Roll (baked - fruit, hamachi, secret spicy sauce, masago). 

If you're looking for the whole Japanese ambience, this is not the place for you. If all you want is good sushi at great prices, come here to Sakana Bune :D
author: Jennifer C.

description:
This is where I get my cheap-sushi fix both cheap in price and decent quality for what you pay. The service is hit or miss for me. Food-wise the quality is ok, just be careful of what you pick off the boat like any sushi boat as some of the pieces have been sitting for awhile and dry out. Something that's sad to see is they'll switch plates to the opposite sides to look like they are making more or newer pieces, but it's just switching it to the opposite side.. 

My favorites from Sakana Bune: Honey-walnut roll, salmon sashimi, mixed seafood "pie" thing that is delicious comes in a little white cup with a mild spiced topping.
author: vanessa g.

description:
I used to eat at this place, and it was not bad.  But then again I was young and didn't really know good sushi.

The sushi is HORRIBLE.  About as bad as it can get.  Even when you order directly from the chef instead of taking one of the rolls that has been floating around for a week.  

I didn't finish most of the sushi the last time I went there.  It was that bad.  I would have actually rather been hungry than eaten there.  I had to go fill my stomach with some good sushi afterwards to counter the taste.
author: Serge S.

description:
Musi-Musi!
Great for sushi boat! I've been a loyal customer for quite a few years now.As one of the very many japanese restaurants on the same block, Sakana Bune has the BEST prices and best tastes. Each boat of sushi ranges from $1.00-$1.95, with items ranging from california rolls to honey walnut prawn rolls. Each plate has about 2-4 pieces on it.  Each plate has about 2-4 pieces on it. 

The wait can get long if you come in during dinner time, but has the best selection when there's a crowd. The waitresses are very nice, but the single waiter is always pissy.

 It's not the most authentic sushi place (i.e. if you are japanese, you prob won't love it), but I've been to lots of japanese places and I rate this one pretty high. The sashimi is not the best quality, but if you're more into rolls like me, there's a huge selection.The sushi chefs are really nice and will make almost any roll you want that you don't see on the boat. Some of my favs on the boat are: everything unagi, the deep-fried house tempura roll, the one dollar 4 piece california roll, the super-white tuna (so buttery!--the only sashimi I will eat!). I prefer the boat items over the regular menu, but menu items are good too.  Avg bill should be around $20-30/ two people, but really depends on how much you eat.
author: Jessica h.

description:
Either I went to the wrong restaurant or they just can not accommodate a party of 6 people.  One of my friends told me this place is a nice lil sushi restaurant in the Richmond District so you know I have to try it out.  Their main selling point is of course the sushi boat which of course I was unable to try because of the long wait and there were 6 of us.  So we all sat down in the table and ordered of stash of sushi.....caterpillar roll, seafood roll, aztec roll....sashimi and other stuff that looks really good on their menu.

Uni came out first...nice...not even 5 minutes and we have our first dish.  10 minutes later our Blossom Roll came out...kool...just what we needed....food!  Another 10 minutes passed before our caterpillar roll came out....ok...kinda odd....whats taking so long for our rolls to come out.  Literally....10 minutes later...our sashimi came out.....you get the picture....our damn rolls came out late...spread out......and we were hungry!   The seafood roll (hamachi with vegetables, rice, onions, with some white tuna) did not look like the picture at all....shoot......it looks like maguro instead.  We even complained to the waitress...she was not much help...more or less...she was lost and forgot what we ordered.  Shucks!!!

I was pretty disappointed in their service...took too long for our food and the waitress was not really helpful.  My buddy was extremely disappointed as well since he suggested this place. *shaking head*
author: Dave L.

description:
I like this place. It's fun. Not great food, but fun. 
The good:
That tiny fishy veggie bake...i dont know what its called but it rules.
The fruit roll: pinapple,mango,egg,cucumber=refreshing
The tempura walnut roll. How delightfully decadent!

The not so good:
pretty crowded a lot of the time
the katsu: the meat has questionable texture (mmm cartilage)
some of that stuff goes for a pretty long boat ride if you know what i mean
author: Lauren T.

description:
Fish is obviously not fresh but because of the price, it is definitely worth it when you have that craving for a sushi fix. Esp salmon nigiri.
It's gets pretty packed during dinner time for bar seating. so be prepared. the wait usually isn't too long. 

i would recommend for those who have never eaten at a sushi boat restaurant.

a big NO NO is picking a plate from the boat and putting it back because you changed your mind!! i've seen this happen before and it's a definite NO!!!!
author: Bevo T.

description:
This is a really good place if you're craving JUST sushi. If you want like udon or lunch box, go to Kitaro =) I felt like the cheapest plate was too cheap for me so I got the one price higher plates haha. It just seems better. My favorite one is the unagi sushi roll! I recommend this to everyone! Fried eel is most definitely the shit. I ate here with my freinds on a late sunday afternoon. Not crowded, pretty decent. The waitress are nice, they re-fill your tea and what not. 

The sushi boats are pretty fun when you're excited to pick one of the dishes and you don't know what's really in stored for you until you bite it. I think that's pretty awesome haha. Anyways it's cheap and tasty, what more do you expect? =D
author: Alice Z.

description:
We live in the Richmond district and frequent Sakana Bune every other week.  We LOVE this place; it's our saviour when we're too lazy to cook and too hungry to wait.  This place gets busy during dinner time on all days of the week, but turn over is pretty quick.  Service is consistently prompt and friendly and the sushi is really fresh.

The beef teriyaki and grilled salmon are excellent.  As for sushi, we love the spicy crab rolls, the nigiri (always tastes fresh) and the unagi rolls.
author: Dexters Parents p.

description: Yaaay!!  This was my "little kid in a candy shop" experience, I had so much fun!  And I was surprised that the sushi didn't taste like cat food, it was great - especially the soft shell crab rolls, so so so good.  It did have a sort of funky smell when you walked in, but it wasn't like threatening and we got used to it, I can't wait to come back!
author: Rachelle P.

description: Before the service here was horrible, but the sashimi here is always fresh. This place isn't as cheap as the one on 5th and Clement but the selections are bigger and tastier. My favorite is spider roll, fresh oysters and albacore toro. The service now is much improved. I'm over 21, but the happiest is that I don't get carded at all here. The best part is if there are no available seats in the sushi bar, you can sit on the table and can just walk up to grab the sushi plates off the boat.
author: lisa c.

description: This restaurant had a great selection of sushi, and great prices too. My boyfriend and I had heard this place was good and finally tried it for the first time and had a great experience! The sushi was all really good and fresh, and was a little different from other places, we liked that about this place. We will definitely come back!!
author: Jessica C.

description: This is the best Sushi boat place I have ever been to. The dishes are cheap and with better quality most regular Sushi bars. That is rare. I love the Fresh Salmon and some baked fish stew thing that they make. Sake and beer is cheap and the waitresses are cool, in there white shirt and tie. All they need is a pleated skirt and they would have that school girl look. Sorry, didn't mean to be a man, but you guys know what I mean. I'll be back.
author: Moby L.

description:
Best Kaiten zushi (sushi boat style) around.

The a la carte boat sushi prices range from about a dollar to $2.75 per plate with an average of two to four pieces per plate. 

It's a nice place to go for a quick bite to eat, without the hassle of regular restaurant dining. 

Perks:

- Prices
- Attentive servers
- Sushi Boats
- Variety
- Being kaiten zushi there is literally zero wait time for food once you're seated. Unless you're waiting for the boats to make another revolution. 


Drawbacks:
- Not the most unique or aesthetically artsy of rolls. If you are in the mood for something complex, best to order a roll from the menu or go somewhere else.
- The dining may come with wait time on the weekends.
author: Jenn F.

description:
i thought this place was great!!! good variety of sushi to pick from. even had some tasty baby octopus!! try it.....its delicious. i also tried what i think  was opihi/ limpit sushi. i love the little boats. makes it fun to me. very comfortable and well lit place. it didn't feel formal and intimidating like other sushi places can be. great prices and great taste. the price range is dependent on how many plates you eat.
 i had 11 lol. that came out to be $25. i was very pleased. i murdered so much sushi in there. everything was great.
the only negative i have to say is about the sashimi. like other reviews have said it was not very fresh. on some that went by you could see flesh coming apart indicating it wasn't very fresh but everything else was great. i know i will be coming back.
author: RAy J.

description: I guess we lucked out the first time we came here when we came later in the night because everytime we've been back since during the normal dinner hour, the selection has been bad. These last couple times, the majority of the rolls they'll pull out are basically glorified california rolls (california roll w/ avocado on top, w/ avocado and shrimp, w/ salmon, w/ tuna). No dragon rolls or any other special rolls came out.
author: Karen C.

description:
Redemption night. Each dish tonight was fresh, and tasted good. This included nothing strange, just the basics: Salmon sashimi and nigiri, super-white tuna, albacore, maguro, veggie tempura, and edamame. 

Yay.
author: Amy J.

description: I am surprised that everyone doesn't love this place.  Fresh fish for decent prices in the Outer Richmond?  How psyched am I that my friend Amy L. finally introduced me to this yummy place.  Those smack-talkers about the Avenues can come check this simple, straight-forward sushi place out and compare it to the fancy places - maybe they'll see what they're missing . . .
author: Carrie R.

description:
My husband and I love this place and are suprised by the bad reviews we found here... SO far, we always had a great experience!
The sushi boats are a must and you should try the honey walnut roll!
author: Tinette M.

description:
I've been calling this "OK Sushi" for years.

It's floating-boat style, so if you want what's on the merry-go-kaiten, service is really quick.  It's also pretty cheap.  They've replaced the old faded wooden boats with new glittery plastic boats.
author: James D.

description:
Pretty good for sushiboat. At least they don't spread all that mayo stuff all over sushi. Well when I eat sushi boat, I usually eat the raw fish... to my surprise .. was better than I expected. Delicious!! I had so many salmon nigiris (1.65... deal!) ... The tuna was okay too. The white tuna sashimi kept spinning around sooo many times ... I regret that I didn't get it even though it was 2.95. Raw oysters were yummy but small, $2.95. 

Deep fried icecream = yummy, 2.95.

Service was so-so .. but who cares .. it's sushi boat. All I cared was that my tea was refilled and that they counted the plates right... which they did =)
author: Allyson L.

description:
My best friend brought me to this place a couple of years ago. I come here whenever I need to order cheap California Rolls in bulk, or for a quick bite when I'm visiting one of my close friends [she lives on the same block as them], or when the boyfriend and I are in the Richmond and we're hungry.

I love the Sushi boat. Their sushi is alright for the price you pay. The one that bugs me is that the sushi on the boats are pretty much all the same: California Roll with something on top. It's a good thing I love CA rolls. Their entrees are alright too. And their scoops of green tea ice cream for $1.50 is pretty worth it to me.

There are quite some times when I've encountered bad customer service here. One time involved being accused of taking sushi off the boats and leaving the plates on there. I decided not to tip them, and the lady ran out after me, saying "you don't need your 50 cents? Bus money?" as my friend and I were walking back to the car. I didn't return to that restaurant for a couple of months, even when I was in the neighborhood and craving sushi.

The waitresses are a little mean and careless in general. Plus they're not the most attentive when it gets busy at night. And parking is a killer there.

I still go to this place because I can't find anything cheaper. But I wouldn't come out of my way to come here, only when I'm around Geary or Clement.
author: Sandy L.

description: for the price it is good enough. I know that good enough should not be a measure of food, but you are in and you are out. We have gone to this place a bunch of time with friends and sit down, grub, tasty sushi, at a low price and left happy fat out the door. You get what you pay for and this place gives you a little bit more. I will continue to eat there.  For the price you simply cannot beat it!
author: Joseph H.

description:
I have been going here for a few years now. Sushi is cheap and the fish is of good quality. What is the point of paying a large amount for sushi? Here, you don't have to bother. My all time favorite is the Honey Walnut Roll. The service matches the food, it is also excellent. I would highly recommend this joint.

DEF. MY FAVORITE SUSHI PLACE IN THE CITY
author: Jessica S.

description:
I've been to this place many times but after today I'll never be back.  About half way through our lunch we saw a ROACH SURFING ON THE SUSHI BOAT.  The staff made no apologies, which is totally unacceptable.

If you can look past the roach, which I hope would be impossible, there are other reasons to steer clear of this place.  While the quality of the sushi is pretty lame (we came here for quantity, not quality) they've also recently raised their prices.
author: Max F.

description:
One of the most affordable sushi places around town. 

I went right as they opened for dinner at 5:30pm and I was one of the first to enter the restaurant. 

They always greet you as you come in. 

I wanted to come in for a snack, but ended up eating full. I just eat whatever looks good to me and everything I picked tasted good. 

The sushi starts getting boring after you notice that the same stuff keeps coming out. After waiting a while for something you like, I notice that I start feeling full. 

They even say bye when you leave. 

Sometimes hard to get service if you sit on the left side of the sushi bar.
author: Joseph F.

description: My friend introduced me to this place when I moved to SF several years ago.  They have inexpensive sushi.  The honey walnut shrimp is the best!  Great to go for lunch; it's busy, and there's a high turnover of sushi.
author: Richard Q.

description:
Dare I venture to give this place 5 stars? I do.

I am by no means a sushi snob, but I certainly have tried many a sushi place in my time, being that I *am* from San Francisco (and I'm not a San Francisco snob either, no siree). I was shocked that there was a local place that is even cheaper than Kitaro - which is where my pals and I usually go for inexpensive sushi, but there was. Only a 10 minute wait at 7pm on a weeknight for 3 at the sushi bar!

Fresh, yummy sushi and sashimi. Attentive, friendly, service. Filled up on 11 or so rolls/sashimi (no sake this time, folks) for a grand total of * $13.00 !!!! * Beat that Kitaro. I still love Kitaro, don't get me wrong, but wow. 

I either a) have low sushi standards (unlikely though) b) came on a good night c) all the other reviewers are insane or d) some combo of all of the above. 

Whatever the reason, I'm glad there was no wait, and I cruelly chuckled as I saw all the people waiting outside kitaro as I walked by. 

PS, Bad parking in the Richmond? You just don't know where to look! That's why I live here and you don't. :P MUHAHAHAHAHHAH
author: Kristi D.

description: Had a great time here for dinner last week. The boat experience is really fun and the prices are uber reasonable. The decor is lacking, but I didn't mind because I was so involved with the floating goodies. A guest next to us recommended the chirachi dish which was really flavorful and super cheap. We would come again to have a tasty gnosh.
author: Nathaniel M.

description: I cannot live without this place.  You get as much or as little as you want!  You can choose from the boats that pass by.  The staff is really nice, remember you, and I've been coming here for years.  There is never a rush to leave.  $10 will fill you up with great fresh sushi.  Cannot say enough about it!
author: Patrick S.

description: Eh... I've been here many, many times. The food selection is small and the place is small. It's not expensive. Overall, I have nothing bad, or good, to say about this place.
author: Stacy C.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE. They have sushi boats there with plates ranging from 1.50-5 dollars and additional rolls. Every time I eat here with my boyfriend we get SUPER full and our bill is only 30 dollars, which is great for sushi. I definitely recommend the dragon roll! I feel that everything is at a really great price and the service isn't bad, but I do wish they came around more. If you need to order something usually you have to try to wave someone over, they don't check on you if you're sitting at the bar, but they are really polite once you get their attention. Seating is pretty fast for a sushi place even though the place is small.
author: Enza P.

description: This is my favorite sushi place in the city. It's cheap and tons if selection of sushi. I just come for the sushi boat experience and during lunch time cause it's not so crowded. All the sushi is fresh and is really good. Great place!
author: Rachelle H.

description:
I only give them four because their prices have recently gone up. Not too long ago I heard about Sakana Bune while evesdropping on two guys sitting at the table next to me at a Thai restaurant downtown. They said "favorite sushi place" and my ears just perked right up. I told my girlfriend we had to go find the place and we did!
It's true, their fish is relatively fresh and their sushi boat prices are good, but they were great. A couple months ago they changed the boats to these plexiglas sparkly gold ones from the old wooden ones and then a month or so later the prices changed too. Oh well.
It's still well priced, relatively fresh and always yummy! Try the honey-walnut roll!

Another great thing about this place is that they have at least two FEMALE sushi chefs. For those of you who don't know, this is rare. Traditionally, I believe, women were not allowed to be sushi chefs because of the myth that women naturally had warmer hands than men. Women's hands were believed to be too warm to handle and prepare the fish for sushi. Obviously that is a load of crap but many sushi places still hold this sexist view. Sakana Bune is obviously a more progressive establishment for employing female sushi chefs and one caucasian sushi chef as well.
author: Jes M.

description:
good food 

cheapest prices i've ever paid for sushi..
author: jeannette L.

description: I cannot say enough great things about this place! Their prices are AMAZING, I always have great service, and their sushi is sooo fantastic! I love the boat also, so I can choose to pick what I want from the boat, or go from their menu. Drink prices are great also! I loooove sushi, and i LOVE this place!
author: Chrissy A.

description: I used to come here every week when I was in college with my friends lol.....you know why? Cuz we loved sushi, it was affordable, and sushi boats are fun when you have so much to chose from. However, it's not that fresh and delicious compared to other sushi places. What do you expect though right? I mean the prices aren't that pricey to begin with. I would always get the mussels....damn the plates do pile up at the end, but on average it's usually $20-$25 a person depending on how much you're planning to eat. My mom always orders take out from here. One time the waitress messed up on her bill and charged her extra $10 on tip or something....not cool! I think she thought my mom wouldn't notice either, but my mom went back in and told her wsup and she was like "oh sorry I'll take care of it", but my mom had already called bofa and took care of it.....watch out :P anyways I wish someone would take new ownership of this place and revamp their menu & look so that it's more appealing to customers.....until that happens you won't be seeing me there.
author: Diane L.

description:
I love this restaurant.  My husband, son, and I go here every Friday night for our "Sushi Family Night".  We are always treated with the best customer service (the waiters/waitresses know us on a first name basis).  They even save seats for us if we are running a little bit late since the wait is a little bit longer after 7:00 p.m.

The price can't be beat and I think the sushi is pretty good - and creative as well.  The Honey Walnut Roll is the best - but the Geary Roll is also quite tasty.  Highly Recommend!
author: Jennifer S.

description:
If you want to sit at the bar you will have to wait, but there is almost never a wait for a table.  Also the sushi is cheap, but doesnt taste like it.  So sit at a table and order there and everything will be made fresh for you.

the walnut roll = awesome
author: Dave P.

description: I like this place. I enjoy going to it and having the sushi I want float by on a boat. Its pretty fun. The sushi isn't the best but its pretty cheap. My mom love going to sushi boat restaurant so we come pretty often. The food here is just really cheap, especially their udon. I love udon and get it a lot when I come here. A line forms after 5pm so I would recommend coming early and putting your name down on the list.
author: Annie P.

description: I and a friend visited here a few days ago, and I have to say if it wasn't for the fact he loves their food I would have walked out!  The service, if you call it that, is the WORST~!  We arrived to find it fairly busy and stood there for a solid ten minutes with no one approaching us.  I saw several of the staff leaning against the wall, looking bored and ignoring us.  It wasn't until I had to aggressively approach a staff person as ask about a table.  I was then informed that I would have to sign in for a table - NOTE there is no sign to let you know this!  When I brought this to their attention, I was told that the staff was very busy which was the reason no one told us this.  I replied that they were not and that they were ignoring us.  No reply from the staff person.  Once we had signed in, we waited another 5 minutes before being seated.  I will say that the food is pretty good, but not of the level to endure being ignored.  This place isn't worth the effort and your money - they obviously don't really care about their customers or service.
author: Rodger R.

description: My favorite sushi boat place! It's pretty cheap and the food is very good.  My favorite are the oysters, they prepare them sooooo good. I could literally eat plates and plates of them.
