My top favorites are the salmon, white tuna & unagi. They also have a sea bass dish that is on their menu, it's cheap and very tasty. Service there is okay, not much to do really but they are good about refilling drinks and napkins.  Sometimes if you don't see things on the boat that you want, just place an order in.
author: Peggy C.

description:
Extremely poor and rude service.

I went with a group of 7 on a Wednesday night.  Everything was going pretty well.  We ordered and the food came slowly.  I ordered a roll and a sushi combo order.  The fish was okay but not great.  The rolls were decently sized.  The negative review comes from the rude service at the end of the meal.  

Our waitress asked if we wanted to split the bill into smaller checks.  It was a nice offer and we took her up on it.  For some reason, she proceeded to turn really rude as she tried to handle our bills.  She wouldn't let people pay with credit cards and talked back to us.  

The service wasn't great and the food wasn't great.  No reason to come back here when I can go to Little Tokyo or even Kitaro.
author: Scott L.

description: This place is OK if you want some fast, cheap sushi.  It will satisfy your sushi craving without you having to break your bank.  Don't expect high quality fish from the boat.  You're better off ordering something off the menu.  The prices are great, but you get what you pay for.
author: Bonnie L.

description: The sushi is decent & this place is as inexpensive as they come.  Music is good, ambience decent.  Patrons sit at a sushi bar with a moat and sushi chefs create sushi that they send around the bar on little boats, floating around the moat.  Fun, at the very least.  If you don't see something you want, you can always order from the many waitstaff around the tiny spot.  Also, it's good to note that sushi from the moat is priced on the basis of the kind of plate it's served on.  For example, a brown dish costs $3, or something like that.
author: Sarah S.

description: I really love this place.  It isn't the best sushi but it IS the best sushi for the price.  Plus, the boats are cool!
author: Jim S.

description: The prices here are pretty good but I had a horrid stomach ache after eating- I did have some of the sea bass so maybe that was the problem. The sushi pieces I had were reasonable.
author: John S.

description: The best sushi boat! Its soooooooo delicious. Did I mention fresh. Theyre certain times where the rolls are rolling out on the boats and it couldnt get any better. This is the ONLY sushi place I will go to. Must try.!
author: Lind G.

description: We've been going here for years. Have always been treated well by the staff, have always enjoyed our meal, and we keep coming back. It may not be the best sushi in SF, but it is a good value, and we love the "boat" motif as it gives us a chance to experiment. The selection is always good. We have a vegetarian, and a  hater of sashimi in our group, but we all always find enough to eat and make us happy. Off hours (like 3PM when we ate there today) may mean you want to avoid some items (the shrimp tasted a bit old) but that's the nature of the "boat" sushi places. They will make fresh anything on request. That might be a better way to go when things are slow.
author: Ranger A.

description: decided to try out the sushi boat. not bad, decently priced and they had a few interesting and fancy looking pieces! parking is a pain in this area though!
author: Linda L.

description: The floating sushi boat concept attracts many customers. However, that is also the downside to the quality of food. The sashimis turn dull and dry up as they are circling in a boat. I think the restaurant probably realizes this a problem so they don't have as many sashimis on the boat as before. Most of the sushis are made with processed food like imitation crab meat and frozen seaweed salad. I looked at the chef while he was making my tuna sushi. First, he sneezed on my sushi. Then he realized that I was watching him. The second time he sneezed, he covered his mouth with his hand, and he continued to make my sushi. Another chef was scratching his head while he was making sushi rolls. I was disgusted. But I was too scared to tell the waitress so I paid and left. My sister and my cousins have been there to eat as well. They had signs of food poisoning such as diarrhea, vomiting, and nausea after eating the unsanitary food.
author: Nicole T.

description: did the lunch time sushi boat...............was not impressed at all. it was the exact same rolls and sashimi that goes around on the boat the entire time. there isn't much variety and the sashimi doesn't look that fresh or maybe its because its been on the boat for a while. but yeah, i wouldn't come back here for their sushi, its almost all the same for each roll.
author: Stella J.

description:
i never should have looked this place up on the sf health dept website.  sakana bune used to be my happy place.
three stars for the memories.  minus two stars for their long list of violations.
author: Ariane R.

description: Prices went up, quality and service went down. I used to come here 1 and a half times a week for some cheap, low quality sushi. $10-11 would usually satisfy my sushi fix. After raising their price, I'm probably not going to come back anytime soon.
author: Stacie T.

description: Haven't been here in what feels like years, but their sushi is yummy & fresh! I use to come here a lot with my salmon loving girlfriend and just beast at the sushi boat. Haha. Reviewing about this place makes me hungry, I'll def have to make a visit here soon!
author: Jackie M.

description: This place definitely deserves 5 stars for being an amazing combination of service, quality of food, and value.  It is great for a few people to go that don't want to do fancy or expensive sushi.  The freshness of fish compares to some of the more expensive sushi restaurants I've been.  Bring a fun open minded friend!
author: Peter G.

description: Sushi lovers BEWARE!!!  My BF and I went out for an evening of sushi and while he was parking the car (right outside the place) they refused to seat me.  I explained that he was right outside and  he wanted me to get a start on the evening of sake, beer and sushi.   I was ignored and then told that they had another party waiting a long time!  Then a couple came in and they seated them without hesitation.  My BF came in a second after them and was upset that I was still sitting there waiting for a table.  Honestly, I have never been in a situation where I felt more ignored and spoken  to in such a rude manner.  The hostess was non responsive and most of the young ladies were scooping out men to flirt with..lol  These young ladies were disrespectful and rude...Never Again.   We left for KItaro next door and had a lovely experience and GREAT FOOD!!!!
author: lauren j.

description: I absolutely love this place. It has a great, no-frills, no-b-s approach to sushi. Just wait twenty minutes to sit at the bar (sometimes longer... always worth it), then enjoy mountains of excellent sushi. Some people say this place is 'gringo', but I say whatever. Try the walnut and cream roll, it is awesome. I would also highly recommend the oysters with hot sauce. Enjoy!
author: Sarah F.

description: So I haven't eaten here in months and I have discovered that this place has gone downhill since my last visit.  I used to think that this place was pretty decent for the price but I found myself still craving GOOD sushi after lunch the other day.  The choices coming by on the boats were limited to say the least, restricted to different types of califonia rolls (with either tuna or salmon on top and little to no avo inside) and old looking sashimi and oysters that looked like they could be breeding bacteria (the same ones passed me the entire time I was there).  I don't think that I will be returning here anytime soon.
author: Christina D.

description:
First, you would expect that the name would be written correctly.  What it shows in Kanji or Chinese characters is "Isari Bune" or fishing boat.  Not, "Sakana bune."  Its writing for revolving sushi or "kaiten sushi" is not Japanese.

So, it's no surprise that the food is mediocre at best.  It is just a pretender that attempts to serve sushi without knowing how to spell it correctly.  It doens't do the rest well either.

With so many good places in the city, it is surprising that such a place could still stay in business.  I guess it's just an indication of how clueless most people are of what sushi is supposed to be.
author: Anonymous M.

description: Went there at prime time, Sunday around 7pm.  The place was packed.  Even the tables surrounding the counter seats were full, with more people waiting at the door. For me, this is a good sign.  I'd still prefer Iso Bune in Japan Town for the wider variety and better taste.  And Iso Bune has a better mood because of the Japanese pop music they play.  That said, Sakana Bune ain't bad.
author: Warren L.

description:
i used to go to this place at least 2 times a week... negative 1 star for raising their prices .65  6 months ago... ive only been back there 2 times since then.

*secret tip*  grab an edamame or two everytime the moving boat passes you by... its an easy way to fill you up, without shelling out the dough
author: boston j.

description: I've given this place 3 shots and they've managed to disappoint all 3 times. Their sushi is mediocre as well as their service. The only nice thing I can say about this place is that I like the little sushi boats that float around the counter but what good is that when the sushi sucks?
author: Diane M.

description: We randomly ended up here for dinner last night and I didn't realize how much I missed my sushi boat spot.  It seemed as though it were meant to be since we found parking right across the street.  The salmon was completely on point last night and they had all my favorites floating by me.  It's like they knew I was coming.
author: Ruben P.

description:
my favorite sushi boat!!! 

in expensive.. good and plenty of choices! 

go here but parking is bad!
author: Jessica O.

description: The sushi here is not the best out there, but it's good and it's cheap.  It's a great place to go if you just have to get  a sushi fix and you only want to spend, say, $15 on sushi vs. $75 at the finer places.  It's a great place to take friends too. Ya'll can chow down on the combo platters they have and still not spend too much.
author: CK Y.

description: Good points about this place: CHEAP CHEAP sushi, perfect for late night snacks that doesn't require the best foods to fufill the stomach. I do warn you, the sashimi  doesn't taste that great; the mackerel tasted fishy, and the tuna's color looked like it was full out red dye. The kappa roll doesn't look too nice. The mini fish eggs--tobiko, tasted decent-- only $1 for two!  Soft Shell Crab was $4.50. Yum. THe rest of the stuff is okay. But I'm not complaining too much-- dishes starts out at $1! =)
author: Crystal K.

description:
The price for their sushi is super cheap and affordable.  
However, the food is just medicore.  Nothing special.  My friend and his gf likes this restaurant a lot. I just go just because i can hang out with my friend. Yes, they have a sushi boat counter where you can watch the sushi float around.. but it was the same type of sushi over and over again.. it was so hard to pick out which one was fresh and which one was there for awhile.  Everyone is eyeing for the fresh plate out and usually is taken asap.  The variety is not a lot.. crab sald roll with crab salad on top... umm.. sushi chef running out of sushi roll ideas? You can tell it was the same old sushi that float around for the last 40min if you see that seafood salad roll sushi is falling down on the side...  I don't know... i just feel the quality of the sushi there is just okay... I noticed that the salmon and tuna is all pre-sliced in a container and so the chef just roll the rice and slap the fish on top... I rather go elsewhere for good quality affortable sushi elsewhere instead...  This place is just not my cup of tea....
author: Selina L.

description: This place is good for their cheap prices in sushi boat, however, most of their sushi swimming in the boats are california rolls with a different design, sauce, or with an avocado or sashimi over it. If you're looking for a quick, cheap & pretty good sushi boat-- Sakana Bune is the place to be !
author: Jenny Y.

description: This sushi boat restaurant isn't bad for the price.  Their sushi is cheap, but edible.  The wait staff isn't all the great, but they aren't that bad either.  They need to work on looking around and seeing what the customers need, i.e. water refills, etc.  Overall, you get what you pay for.
author: Philip L.

description: Sakana Bune is fine, if you have low expectations for quality, authentic sushi.  However, since the prices are dirt cheap, you can expect that the quality isn't all that great.  But if all you want is a quick fix to satisy your sushi craving this place is fine.
author: Cass J.

description: If I could give negative stars... I would!  All I have to say is this... I was eating lunch there today... and what do I see floating on the sushi boats... no, not sashimi or some other yummy treat... I see a ROACH (a bit 3/4 in long)!!!!  A live roach creeping around on the sushi boat... as if it was on some great water adventure while on vacation... I WILL NEVER EAT THERE AGAIN!  And what was worse... after we pointed it out... along with other patrons... they did not even offer and apology... but they were real quick to tally up our plates and charge us. Horrible way to handle the situation!  I knew I should have just stuck with good old Kitaro.  I don't care how good the salmon was... never never never never again!
author: Amelia M.

description: This place just gets worse and worse every time. The workers are very rude and one started commenting on my name. The food is very cold and small, making you want to get lots of plates and then still be hungry. There are so mnay better boats places. It's also really crowded all the time, when the food and service really isn't that good.
author: Nikita K.

description: What this place lacks in quality, it makes up for in price. Dirt cheap sushi that's still pretty damn tasty. The cooked food is pretty good too, much better then Kotaro a block down, that's for damn sure. I recommend the eel, both as sushi, and fried.
author: Jason H.

description: When this place first opened, there was already Kitaro's on the block.  Who could beat that? But somehow, they decided to open on the corner.  I decided to try it cuz they had one of those 2 for 1 deals.  Bad idea!! Service was horrible, the pricing was bad for the amount of food you get.  They could've been more competitive w/Kitaro, but was not.  I never went back there.  I'm surprised it's survived almost 5+ years.  Now there's 3 sushi restaurants on the same block.
author: Christi S.

description:
the food was alright
it was edible
but the service was terrible
we sat at the bar and that does not require much service 
but still the waitress with the short hair managed to be unpleasant
we were just planning to have a cheap and quick lunch
but from the moment we stepped in, that waitress glared at us
and when she asked us if wanted tea
and said yes 
she rolled her eyes and brusquely said 'excuse me'
and grabbed my cup
my group and i were not loud or anything
when we asked for the bill, 
she counted plates incorrectly and acted as if it were our fault 
for her mistake
yep, she rolled her eyes the whole time
the food was nothing beyond average 
but the reason not to go to this place is the service
it will make you lose your appetite
author: Candy Y.

description: I love this place...I've been here over 50 times, in just about three years.  Super cheap, totally decent, fun sushi.  Gotta try the honey-walnut tempura prawn roll.  Ridiculous.
author: Alex T.

description: I honestly don't know what else to say besides; THIS PLACE IS FUCKING RAD. I love it. Actually I'm a addicted. Super white tuna?? why yes please...yellowtail...umm load it on....fried oysters...mmmhmmm...bring it baby. I leave this place happy and full for under 20 always. BOMB.
author: Summer C.

description: Next to Kitaros. This place has a sushi boat bar though. Less expensive.
author: Lucky N.

description: Look, if people come here expecting the best sushi they've had, they obviously haven't looked at the prices. When the most expensive sushi plate is $1.95, what are you expecting? That being said, the sushi isn't horrid. You just have to be picky with what you take off the boats. Some of the pieces have been going round and round for too long, so you avoid them. But if you take the fresh pieces, it's hard to go wrong here. $1.50 for two pieces of tuna or salmon? Find me a better price in San Francisco! You can't beat this place for the price. Does better sushi exist? Definitely, but not at this price.
author: Lance J.

description:
I watch them make the sushi, nd where they put it, nd how they handle it..
I kno fresh fish when i see nd eat it...the only thing they have fresh is oysters..the only thing they say is fresh in the restaurant...it's okay..service is pretty good..it could get busy on fri & sat nights..long list of names.. it's pretty cheap..which makes me wary coz its fish...i go back for oysters nd certain sushi's.
author: Janet W.

description:
This is a decent sushi-boat restaurant, and everything is a bit above what you'd expect from a sushi boat restaurant: relatively good sushi, some of it sitting around a little while, very quick service, nice staff, etc.

You can get a dozen plates of 2-3 pieces for around $25, which is great because you can try many things.

All in all, I'd give this a 3-4 star review, except...

They have a seared white tuna sushi with some type of sesame / garlic sauce and a bit of garlic on top.  This is, without a doubt, one of if not the best piece of fish I've ever had in my life.

For that alone we go back around once a week, and will continue to do so for some time to come.
author: Mark K.

description: Average sushi boat place, but what makes this place dope is the service from the waitresses and staff.  You know you are in a cool place when the sushi chef and the waitresses are chanting "Sake" "Bomb"  while you throw down your beverage.  I forgot what the dessert thing is called, they have like 2 versions,  I got them all and so should you.
author: Jason A.

description: Delicious, creative rolls. Serious and well hidden gem. A sushi menu as long as a roll of toilet paper, with every item a good one, and with pictures to help newbies. The reasonable prices allow one to endeavor trying out every item on the menu. I love the island in the center of the restaurant (the name escapes me) where cute wooden boats carrying tasty morsels float past eager patrons in an elliptical moat. Well, it's always full when I go, but I enjoy looking at it. And the service has always been good to me and my friends.
author: Clar L.

description:
this place needs a bigger variety for their sushi boats. my friends and i come here cause we're a bunch of cheap bastards, but in the end, all the little dishes you grab (you can play jenga with mine) add up to more than just going to a better sushi restaurant (perhaps kitaro down the block, or the millions of other japanese places lurking on Geary) restaurant and ordering up a few good dishes. most of their sushi on the sushi boats are made of imitation crab, and after a while it makes your stomach a little queasy. you can get 2 pieces of tamago or 6 little pieces of CA roll for only $1 here. after your few dishes, you'll be watching the boats pass by, praying for a something new to come out, and when something does (like the Honey Walnut Roll which isn't half bad), it's the most expensive one - the $2.50 plate! AHH!

pay a little more and go elsewhere for sushi boat.
author: Douglas F.

description: This place isn't bad but it isn't a place to rave about. For the price you pay it's not bad. The food is alright, don't expect anything fancy, and if you stick to basics such as sashimi or just regular rolls, it's actually pretty good. The prices have gone up in recent years but still stays one of the cheapest for something that is decent.
author: Rachel K.

description:
Sushi Boat/Bune places are great if you want a quick meal without waiting for for service and cooking time.  Getting a seat at the moat can take a while if you're with a group.  But the smaller the group, the more likely you'll be given a spot.  I went by myself tonight and they put me right into the only single open seat, even though others were waiting for more seats together.  I've gone on my own several times, and the staff have an annoying habit of asking "Only one?", like there's something wrong with that.

The boats bring a variety of food in front of me.  Going here when its busy is the best way to see turnover in the items available.  But after several trips here over the last few months, I'm learning that there are a pretty limited number of items in the repertoire.  Not that it's bad, just somewhat predictable.  Over a 20 minute sitting you'll see pretty much everything they're going to put on the boats.

I prefer Nigiri sushi or sashimi dishes, especially lighter fish like albacore.  But these are rare on the boats.  Translucent salmon and bright-pink unnatural looking tuna are somewhat more common.  Most of the plates are rolls with lots of rice and Krab/mayonnaise mix.  These are probably designed to fill you up and get you to leave.  They're tasty.  But you'll only get to try a few items if you eat too many of these.

I'll continue to go occasionally, but I wish they had an even greater variety on the boats.
author: Jon L.

description: I love this place because I never have to wait for a table.  This is the place my bff and I go when we don't feel adventurous and just want to have a nice, relaxing sit down dinner (with a side of Asahi).  Their service is excellent, and the place is clean.
author: Jenny L.

description: Sushi plates on the boat are $1-2. What damn more can I say? Actually, the parking situation also stinks and there are two other sushi joints on the same block, both of which are better but not cheaper, hence the allure of this place.
author: Ramon T.

description: The cheapest sushi place I've ever been to, and for the price it could have been worse.  Most of the items are OK, but stay the hell away from the sashimi - it had the texture of a stale gummi bear and my guess is had been out for at least 5 hours.  Unless you're hell-bent on the idea of conveyor belt style, I'd recommend Kitaro.
author: John H.

description: Their udon is a good deal. For about $7, you get tempura vegetables and shrimp accompanying your entre. I usually eat at the sushi boat, so I have the option of selecting an endless variety. You get to try more for less this way. The sushi isn't overpriced but sometimes they don't have what I want. Their tempura sushi and spicy crab are good. I'll also get the non-sushi items like their croquettes and gyoza. Their chicken teriyaki is good. I can't say the same for the chicken katsu. It was just dry and the sauce isn't as good as the Hawaiian BBQ places.
author: Armstrong B.

description: I used to come to this place a lot since my friend lives about 1 minute away. I love their little floating sushi boats. Their mochi is delicious, they make their own but I wished that the mochi would be more creamy and have less ice crystals in it since it cramps the flavor!! My friend and I usually sit at the sushi bar and eating whatever seems good.
author: Janet Z.

description: Love this place! The prices are low, the service is pleasant, the sushi is fresh! My favorite is the Honey Walnut Roll and the spicy crab.... and of course the gyoza. So good! We come here every chance we get.
author: R G.

description: Cheap and tasty!  My girlfriend and I saw the night going one of  two ways.  Either we were going to be stuffed and happy that we spent so little on good sushi, or we were going to spend the night weeping to each other about the terrible cheap shady sushi that made us sick....24 hours later, I'm happy to say that it is the former!  WOOOHOO!  I'm definitely coming back here when I want a massive amount of sushi and don't want to spend a pretty penny...My tummy and tongue were happy, and so am I!!  was it the best sushi?  no...but it was great for the price!
author: John K.

description: Everything I had here was ok...it was fun sitting at the bar and watching the boats go around. It's fun if you wanna have a chill afternoon or evening with a friend. The food tasted fresh & the portions for the price is just right. but dont come here at night for dinner. everything looks like its been floatin there all day.
author: Rosalynn D.

description: A few years back, I was here more often than I ate at home. When they started their $1.95 lunch menu, which then turned into $1.95 dinner menu, I almost cried with joy. The sushi was always good. The chefs were nice. I loved the boats and the bar. The Dragon Roll was always a fave, too.
author: Neely M.

description: The value of the sushi is adequate. the combo plates like chicken katsu is very fattening. I prefer kitaro, a few restaurants down.
author: Jen P.

description: Oh my friend, our relationship is definitely a testament to the theory that time apart can sometimes be a good thing. After getting a little too comfortable with each other, I can see we started taking each other for granted. But now that I've been away for a while, you've made some changes for the better I see. Yeah, you're charging a little more, but you've got some upgrades to show for it. Sashimi! (Even Butterfish....Mmmm) Oysters on the half shell with ponzu and green onions! Spider Rolls! All in the rotation now? You did this for me didn't you. Let's not break up again, OK!?
author: Jeffrey J.

description: I love how the restaurant has a sushi boat so you can take your time, take a look at what they have and eat as much as you're willing to spend. haha. The sushi is kinda cheap but it could use some variety. A lot of the times the same things keep circling forever and ever, but i guess that's how it is for the price you pay, but its good.
author: Lily K.

description: I know this place is run and owned by Chinese people, which I could care less about because I know Japanese people would totally have a high price range. They have lots of sushi that is very suitable for my taste because I'm afraid of the raw ones with sashimi fish eggs on them. The sushi are about a buck a plate, so if you're on a budget, get about 8 plates; 10 at most. However, do not order anything else if you plan to do the sushi boat.
author: Alex Y.

description: I've been coming to this place for years. Not the best sushi, not the worst but for the price it works just fine to get your fix of raw fish. Service is not great but it's not bad either. I give it 5 stars because it is what it is consistently over the 8 years I've been going.
author: armando r.

description:
This is definitely the best cheap sushi boat place I've been to!  Been coming here for years and it's always my pick if I get to choose the cheap sushi spot for the night. 

The rolls on the menu are small (the simple ones, like Philadelphia, rock n' roll, etc) and only I think $1.65, so you can order a whole bunch of different rolls for under $10 and get to eat a bigger variety of food than you normally would at a Japanese restaurant. The boats are fun too, although they do tend to have the same few items going around and around. Wish they would add some new stuff to the boat rotation sometimes.  

The service can be pretty bad if it's busy, but I think the servers mean well and just get flustered with the typical drunken cheap sushi fiends who tend to frequent the place and probably don't tip well. Otherwise they tend to be pretty nice.
author: Brandi C.

description: I've walked by here very often, and decided to stop in once. I didn't particularly like the sushi. It was a bit bland. The selection was wide, and it was considerably cheap.
author: Michael C.

description:
my dad usually calls me once a week and says... "lets go eat some cheap food" and we also go here.  this place is all about quantity.  the sashimi isnt always fresh but buckfifty for two pieces of nigiri is a deal.  and i actually eat soem of the dollar dishes.  their chicken katsu is good too, they use a thigh piece.  juicy as a mofo.  

its usualyl packed with families and just people eating.. ive seen some white people in hur sipping on house wine and eating like they be fancy, but really... this is place is more of a whambamthankyouma'am.  

WARNING.  if you've ever said "ilovesushi, ew but not raw fish" dont go hur.  the 99 rendition of the california roll isnt spectacular. but i never taught california roll as sushi though... is it even japanese food...

the service can be a little curt... my dad no speakie english good, but he always has to repeat his sake order..."where my sake? HOT!" theres also this one waitress thats always there... she's scary.
author: Doug ..

description: I'll make it short and sweet: What you pay is what you get. Cheap price, cheap-o sushi.  Perhaps it's been cheap for me because I never ordered that much anyway (not because I don't eat much; it's because of the taste and quality of the food). The sushi is not all that bad, but it's not that fresh or good either. Hard to find parking as it is located on Geary.
author: Poof S.

description: I've been here a few times, I don't consider this place the best sushi restaurant, but it can do when you're feeling the $1 specials (sarcasm). The food actually is not all that bad, but their service is not all that great. Seeing the waitress just throw plates on the table is rude IMO. Other than that, this place is mediocre at best.
author: Edgar G.

description: Went here for the first time last week with a friend after they suggested it. Sat at the bar so we could grab sushi as they pass us. I'm willing to try a lot of the different offerings, its part of the fun of sushi boats. We had a short wait because the seats were full, but there wasn't a wait if you wanted to sit at a table. I thought the offerings varied enough so that people who didn't want to try things other than the common spider or california roll would be satisfied just as much as people who prefer sashimi. The only thing that bothered me was when people would get up from their tables and walk up to grab trays from the belt out of nowhere. Kind of annoying to have someone walk up stand between you and the person sitting next to you as they wait for something to make its way around.
author: Cee D.

description:
I love sushi! One of my favorite dishes to eat =)

They raise the price over the years! So it's pretty expensive for a two piece sushi for around $2.25 depending on what you chose from the boat. I tried to get a plate for under $2.00 but they look so yummy I can't resist. 

I come here with my friends a lot - it's sort of our little joint to hang out on a Friday night! 

The staffs are nice, depending on how they are feeling that day! ha.
author: Jessica L.

description:
yuck. would not come back here, ya hear..

food is not fresh here. just look at one of the yelper pics: 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/JdHEVcbbZjr4GR2m-69-yA?select=3HsHAEZa9L9bFIUAyIRojw

the salad was not even fresh either - it was brown. 

the carpet was messy and i felt dirty and sick after leaving this place.
author: Bobby B.

description: not the best, not the worst. what i like best is that it is open late and there is always a place to sit. the sushi isn't "oh my god" good, but it is consistantly fresh. what i do not like is that the pieces are tiny. i mean tiny. i feel like the prices are right, but one needs to eat double the amount to fill up. therefore, A-OK.
author: S. G.

description:
First sushi-boat experience, a friend who is a big fan of this resturant brought me, I really enjoyed myself.

Parking was a hassle but we managed to get a spot across the street (30mins later) and we arrived a little after dinner rush (I swear, if we waiting 15minutes we would have gotten parking next to the entrance! bad timing on our part!)

Food was yummy, sashimi was great- melted in my mouth just the way i like it, I needed almost no soy sauce (and I DROWN my sashimi with that magical sauce). Being my first time my first dish was $4, but after my friend pointed out the pricing I stuck to the $2 plates. 

I ate two sashimi plates, and about five roll/gyoza/sushi plates costing me about $18. My friend- who has been here too many times to count, only racked up $8. (that and he only had four plates) 

One of my favorite things about sushi boats is that you really have to be confident in grabbing the food you either want or want to try, because if you're not fast enough it'll scoot on by and you have to hope a chef made another one or no one picked it up on it's way around. (I'm easily excited so it was thrilling!)
author: Hisaye K.

description:
the sushi boat selection is limited, but on the cheaper side compared to other sushi joints.  i ordered the tempura udon, which was a bit overly salty, but the portion was quite big.  this is not the best place to get authentic sushi, but you pay for what you get.

the waitresses are pretty nice.  while my family was waiting for seats at the sushi bar, we got to drink some tea.
author: Amy Z.

description: This place was alright. We were looking for a cheap sushi place to sit down and have a quick bite after a tennis match. We weren't dressed up at all (wearing tennis shorts and t shirts) and they were glad to seat us. We had to wait 5-10 minutes to get seated, but once we were the the sushi was a comin'! The different sushi boat dishes range from $1.25 to just about $2.50. And it ended up running me and my friend about $10 each for the meal. The sushi wasn't the best I had ever had, but it was good for the price. I will definitely be going back there again when I am in the mood for some quick easy sushi.
author: Nick R.

description:
oh god. what can I say?

This is a sushi boat restaurant, so expect sushi delivered on a plate, floating around a circular bar, on a boat. 

BUT, service is pretty bad, and the portions are really small. Yes, it's cheap, but no, it's not very good. Sometimes I have bones in my sushi, and that's really really really weird, considering it's just a salmon roll. REALLY WEIRD.

It is cheap, but for better plates, you pay exponentially more, and when you order something from the menu, it takes forever and a half for it to arrive. I remember on numerous occasions that the server forgot to give me an order or two, and waiting over half an hour for it to come to me. Or getting overcharged for some plates, and having them tell me I'm wrong, after pointing out the prices of each plate, etc, etc.

I dread coming here anytime someone wants to make us go. It just ruins the sushi experience for me.
author: Clinton L.

description: Solid three stars for instant sushi gratification.  Sushi floating around on a boat as you pluck off appetizing plates.  It's not gourmet sushi but it is what it is and they don't claim to be anything else.
author: Blu n.

description:
I have to say, I have been eating sushi for over 25 years and I have not found a place that is as affordable and good quality as sakana bune. The fish is fresh, service is prompt.  And I have never gotten sick in 25 years, another sushi lie.
   I didn't know what all the recent negative reviews are about in here, so I decided to try this sushi restaurant. Evidently, all you spoiled richmond san fransiscans must like to spend $100 for your sushi and feel good about yourselves, because you don't appreciate fair pricing and good product, or how to run a 
business. The sushi boat or private ordering system allows you to name your price or select what you like, not just eat a bento box! 
  I tried the eel (always a good test) for freshness,
  Ikura (large salmon roe for you non-affictianado's) and if you really want to be bold, go for the sea urchin..
 Apparently in S.F., unless your getting poisonous blowfish straight from japan, your not satisfied..
author: Antony S.

description: this sushi place is the best as it gets for its price. its super cheap and lots of choices. i go to eat all the time when i am at san francisco even though its far from downtown SF, its worth the drive. Their spicy kani rolls are the best and my favorite. i alway sit at the bar and not at the tables so i dig in fast. its got the sushi boat where they place all different types of sushi they have. the place is rather small but worth the wait for the sushi for the prices they have. All I have to say is that I love this place.
author: John P.

description: This used to be one of my favorite Japanese restaurants around the area, until I got lazy to make the trip all the way from the East Bay and on top of that circle the block like crazy trying to find a parking space. If you come here around lunch, you most likely will be able to land a seat at the sushi boat section but come dinner time, there will be a wait, unless you opt for sitting at a table. The service here is mediocre but the quality and prices of the choices on the sushi boat totally make up for any lack of attentiveness. I haven't been here in a while so I can't pinpoint the prices but a plate of California rolls is about less than $2 (I think). What I like about sitting at the sushi boat, too, is that you have the option of ordering from the menu. When you're done eating, it's cool to see how many plates of sushi you and your friends consumed. Each plate has a special design to determine their prices. For fresh and tasteful food, everything is very reasonably priced.
author: Gabby T.

description:
The food is cheap! Around $25 a couple and that's if you eat ALOT! The quality of the food is exactly what you pay for. The fast music on the background (makes people eat a lot faster so they can come, eat, pay and GO) irritates the crap out of me. The worst thing are the waitresses!!! Every time I asked for sugar (for my tea) they would bring me a tiny sauce dish w/ half a spoon of sugar, no spoon or anything... HELLO! are they mentally challenged or what?! Also, they tend to watch you so don't  steal anything and once you ask for the bill, they literally start cleaning up your are even if your not done. Once they bring you the bill they watch you like hawks to make sure you don't run away or something. This one time, I was signing the receipt (from VISA card) and this waitress began to literally pull it out from my hand while I was still signing it, I wanted to smak her.
- If you do go there, ask them for a menu where you can find a little section for the bar plate selection (the mini plates that float around on the boat), their avaque and alaska rolls are pretty ok and chap but they never put it out on the bar b/c it's not as profutable as the other S$%T they serve.
author: Mickail M.

description: Not bad place for Japanese food. The sushi to me is not that fresh, but inexpensive on the sushi boat. You get what you pay for. I like going there for lunch. They have an inexpensive lunch menu. The wait staff is pretty nice.
author: Leon C.

description:
Ok.  I'm a sushi snob so I can't honestly give this place ANY STARS for their sushi but I'm giving 2 stars for everything else.  

It's a neat place.  I definitely won't make a special trip or will I ever crave it (I think).  They have plenty of young waitresses so you'll never have trouble getting something.  Most of them are really nice and they sure do put up with the old man behind the sushi bar!

Their sushi primarily consists of their specialty rolls but they put out 2 pieces on a boat and you get to catch them as they float by.  They'll occasionally put out some fried oysters, gyozas, baked seafood thing, or potato croquettes.  The only raw items I saw were tuna, salmon, some white fish, fish eggs, and hamachi.  Other raw items on the menu that you can order include amaebi and scallop.  They have ebi and eel too but the quantity of those and other raw items are limited so better to just order it.

The only reason I would EVER come here again is the price.  It must be the cheapest Japanese meal I've ever had.  It was like a buffet.  The set meals were SUPER cheap and they all came with soup and salad - even if you get it to go!!

Overall, get there early.  They seem to really pack up fast.  It's fine for a quick fix of specialty rolls with lots of mayo.  Pass if you want authentic.
author: Angie C.

description: I love this sushi boat place, it's awesome. Just make sure you don't go near closing time or else you'll be limited in selection, and you'll never get a warm unagi (my FAVORITE) pop in the mouth choice. Prices increased but still cheaper then what I've seen in other places. The service is nice and you can order the rolls themselves or order personally if they're not floating on the boat. Highly recommend this place if you want a quick grab of some sushi!
author: Sean E.

description: Rude and bad food. It rhymes and it's the honest truth! The waitstaff are mean and just thinking about the sushi makes me feel queasy. The tempura rolls tasted like fried, fishy marshmallow Peeps. Ewww!!!
author: V R.

description: This place is almost always packed, with long waiting lists on Fri and Sat nights. I've been here several times, and found that the quality of the sushi on the floating boats is getting worse every time. There are some items on the boats which are good, such as the special rolls with wakame. But more often than not, the salmon and hamachi are not very fresh.
author: J K.

description: So this place is very affordable for sushi and the sushi quality is quite good for the price.  The place is nothing fancy, but it is fun.  You have the option of seated sushi or sushi-boat styled bar seating.  The sushi-boat seating seems to always involve a wait, but I recommend it over the standard table seating because in addition to being able to gorge yourself instant-demand style on sushi, you can also play the always fun "guess the sushi dish" game.
author: Kristin S.

description:
what can i say their prices are pretty damnned cheap, and i'm picky about my fish, so far i can't say it's been bad, and i go there too much.(the staff knows me on sight)

before the prices went up a bit the variety wasn't as good, but they now usually have oysters, and even sashimi plates on the boat, and more roll choices

and can i just say:HONEY WALNUT ROLL
author: Carol S.

description: Does this place have great sushi?? No. Is there a lot of  variety of the sushi on the boats? No. However, when I am in the mood for sitting at the bar for sushi boats at inexpensive prices, I come here. $10 is a lot of sushi and will get you full.
author: Kimberly N.

description: I'm a big fan of sushi boats because you can pick and choose what you want with with no minimum order. My boyfriend first went to this place, while waiting to go to another restaurant with his friends and he raved about it. When he took me, I absolutely loved it. I couldn't believe how cheap it was, the most expensive plate was 2.95 (usually 4 pieces of sashimi or 2 pieces of a specialty roll) Nigiri for 2.00, you cant beat that. They also include their appetizers which include calamari, potato croquette, deep fried oysters, all very good. The sushi is always very fresh here. My favorite roll that they serve here (like others) is the honey walnut prawn roll, its a must try. I get excited when I see them making it, lol. The staff is polite and attentive and the place itself is clean and in good condition. Depending on what time you go, the wait might be about 10-15 mins, but usually sooner than that. Overall for the price, this place hits the spot. They also serve regular sit down dinners which I haven't tried yet, but if they're sushi is pretty good, Im sure the other food is just as fine. Im always tempted to try it but I always just stick to the sushi boat :)
author: Jollieanne J.

description:
What can I say? I been to this place ever since i was 13 or 14!! (20 now) and I love this place! you know when you and your family and your friends find that special place where you go to all the time and people there know your faces? Well this one is MINE!! my friends LOVE this place! My family LOVES this place!! The only thing is that they yet don't know my name haha but its okay they know who I am who my friends are and who my family is and who my bf is---Shows how often I go there! At least once a month!! This place is THE BEST OF THE BEST!! 
Staff---they are very nice, you ask them, they bring it, and never bug you.You just gotta make sure you catch their attention, since you are sitting facing your back and they can't see what you need with out showing yourself.
FOOD- AMAZING
The Chefs that are in the middle - I love you guys!! You make the best sushi!! Fresh and always soo GOOD!
this is not a fancy place, but this is the place where you want to hang out with family and friends  with out wearing nice clothes.

All SAID!
author: Sean L.

description: This place is pretty good over all.  They have a good size sushi bar and some tables.  The wait was short.  The sushi are a bit smaller than other places but the prices are cheap.  The sushi are pretty fresh and service was good and fast.  Just a note, the sushi boats are going so fast you might be sea sick.  This is not a traditional Japanese restaurant, it is owned by Chinese people.
author: Keith N.

description: Sakana Bune is a fast place to eat and you don't have to wait for the food to come. Also they have many varieties of sushi but sometimes they don't make some kinds of sushi. Also, the sushi is very good and you are able to see the sushi chefs make the sushi in front of you. Also, how the sushi is on a boat moving around is very attractive because you can pick your selection of sushi, so you have a full control of your menu. The pricing isn't that bad but they organized their prices by the style of the plates. So depending on how many you eat and how exotic the food is the prices would be more costly. I recommend you eating at this place if you like to just sit down and start eating sushi.
author: Kai P.

description: The nigiri this time was ehhhhh...it just tasted fishy and the fish didn't adhere to the rice. How do you mess up nigiri at a sushi bar? Now that I've been there a second time it seems like they have more variations on the california rolls than they do on actual sushi.
author: Mike A.

description:
Food: Not bad. I've been here twice and the variety of sushi they offered on the sushi boat doesn't change at all. They should create more new stuff for returning customers. One suggestion: they should put something to cover those sushi, like the one in sushi-tei in singapore. I don't know if they do that in sushi-tei here.
Service: Twice I've been here and it's still the same kind of service.
Ambiance: I always like to seat on the stool while looking at the sushi boats going around. 
Note: A similar alternative sushi boat restaurant would be Fune-Ya on Clement, they are currently celebrating their anniversary, so everything on the sushi boat is only $1.95/plate. The service and the place is definitely way better than this place.
author: Jessica W.

description: This is not high class or gourmet sushi.  It is a staple in our diet and serves as our weekly fast food, quick, friendly and CHEAP!  My 5 yr. old son eats sushi like a vacuum cleaner; inhaling nigiri faster than I breathe.  He also loves that we sit high on the bar stools and watch with anticipation as the sushi boats float by.  He regularly requests that we go to "His sushi boat restaurant for dinner".  Its five minutes from home, easy to park nearby and we are filled to the gills for less than $25 including. tip.
author: Elise Yvonne R.

description:
If I wanted to eat salmon wrapped in lint, I'd do so on my own terms...

Keep in mind. If you are new to sushi restaurants in San Francisco, or sushi in general.. please, please, PLEASE, don't go to a bune. 

FYI: The fish isn't fresh unless you order it.. more times then not they splash some water on it to look that way after it has been floating around for more then 15 minutes..
author: Mic F.

description: Please read the other 1 Star Ratings and note that the servers here are extremely RUDE.  I've been to this place several times because the sushi is okay and reasonably priced, but I can NO longer go to this place because I can not stand the ATTITUDE.  The waitresses here are very pushy, unpleasant, and always seem to be rolling their eyes at you. If anyone needs a course in how to be rude or how to have no customer service/people skills, you simply need to eat at this place and observe the waitresses. I finally decided to confront one of the waitresses (Bree) today as to why she was being so rude to my mother and I from the moment I entered to the time I left. She literally kept yelling at me as if everything was my fault, and for me to get out of the way because she has customers. I told her I was a customer too, and do not deserve to be treated this way.  I asked to speak to the manager who was also trying to push me aside and avoid the situation.  I am thankful that another customer sitting next to me approached the manager and said that I was right, and that the staff here needs to calm down and treat us all better.  Please do not go to this place! You can find much better sushi and service elsewhere.
author: G T.

description: My husband and I come to this restaurant quite often. We always like the food but service is sporatic. Tonight, we sat through dinner without much help from the servers. We were practically doing jumpin-jacks to get a server's attention and still we were unnoticed. We finally had to interrupt the sushi chef to get served. Keep in mind that this was a wednesday night and the restaurant was not busy. We also had to remind our server that what we ordered did not come when she was calculating our tab. What sucky service. By the way, no tea was served after our first cup. We had to go buy ourselves drinks after we left the restaurant. WTF?!
author: Sandy N.

description: I think this was my third visit here. I usually sit at the bar, but we had a large party so we sat at a table. It was a bitch and a half getting up, walking over to the conveyor belt and balancing dishes in my hand. The nigiri was NOT fresh at all. The texture was wrinkly, and not smooth (fresh). They also need more variety on the belt. It was the same 5-6 dishes over and over again. I got sick before I got full. Parking is a hassle to. If you come after 8pm, park at the bus stop on Clement.
author: Simon S.

description: Great price fresh fish and a fun place to take a date
author: Jezus S.

description: Service was good and quick. Sushi itself was just okay... For our party of 7, total bill was $80, so not bad at all.  Yeah, we'd come again for the cheap sushi.
author: H c.

description: For good value for the money, this is definitely one of my favorite sushi places and has been for years.  It's cheap and quick and the fish is always fresh (though the portions sometimes leave for something to be desired). With dishes as low as $1.50 each, I can usually get a decent sushi lunch or dinner here for about $10-15.
author: Amy L.

description:
So, the only reason I finally made an account on Yelp was to review this restaurant. 

Basically, this restaurant has a few problems, 

1) Poor Service
2) Apparently they don't except pennies, so they round us to the nearest nickel
3) You're also required to give them a 15% tip

Here's the full story..


The prices here are relatively cheap compared to most sushi places, but the service is absolutely horrific. 

We were waiting inside of the restaurant for the final member of our party of five. My friend had called me telling me she was five blocks away from the restaurant, literally two minutes. The waitress asked us where our final guest was and I told her the guest was only two minutes away and I  asked if we could be seated. The waitress decided to seat the party of three that just walked into door, and literally as they sat down my friend arrived. This caused another good twenty minutes of waiting for five chairs to clear up at the bar. 

We weren't too stressed about wait for seating once we started eating, but the time the bill came around it was a whole different story. We asked the waitress politely to bill us separately (yes, this probably was a pain in the butt, but it's not that hard to do with a calculator). First she told us we couldn't, we made no argument about this, but she changed her mind and billed us all individually. We noticed that everyone's total had a few extra cents added to it, and mine had an extra $2 added to it. Along with that the complete total everyone's meal was calculated wrong. After much confusion and computing on cellphone calculators I told the waitress that the calculation seem to be incorrect. She ended up looking at the original receipt she gave me and my calculations and telling me that they were the same. I simply pointed out that they were not the same and she continued to look at the paper in confusion. I'm guessing the manager of the store saw her employee talking to us and came over and looked over the calculations. She then just stated that the restaurant does not deal with pennies therefore they round to the nearest nickel. But still the calculations were wrong and the manager just grabbed the papers and told us she'd calculate again. They gave us the new receipt with correct calculations(while rounding up to the nearest nickel). Not once apologizing or any sincere customer service. Honestly, it didn't seem like they wanted to be the ones who wronged. 

We ended up giving a poor percentage of tip and leaving, which brings me back to a previous time that I dined at the restaurant with a friend and was poorly customer serviced. We ended up only tipping 10% and the employee told us a 10% was unacceptable and we are required to tip 15%. Really now?

All in all I would not go back to the restaurant again in the future.
author: Shaina C.

description: it's just yesterday night that my honey and I went to this place to have some sushi grub.  We came in at a lil after 9pm so there's no line, but the bad thing is that not enough sushi varieties to eat.  We have to wait for 10 minutes to get a fresh new sushi another thing is, when you eat here dont give the sushi chef sake. they are going to lose their concentration and they will forget your order.  We asked specifically for salmon skin roll with no cucumber, it is legibly write on the order menu but somehow since this chinese sushi chef dude had 3 shots of sake, he forgot that he still have duty to make our salmon skin roll.  We waited at least 15 min and not until we asked for our order and he started to realize that our order was not being made.  On top of that, he messed up with our order ( he added cucumber).   Once again, sake don't mix with a working chinese sushi chef, because when their face turn red they just forget where they are and what they are doing at that moment.  So I'll give 'em 2 stars for the effort that they made until this guy got drunk. ^_^
author: Albert W.

description: great place to try sushi with friends for dinner... I always sit near the sushi boat table.. a boat that has different kinds of sushi on it goes around and around.. you choose the sushi you want to eat...the plate tells u how much the sushi costs.. ranges from $1 to $3.. very in expensive... but if U eat alot... it can add up.. I love their green tea... and mochi (ice cream in the middle).. wait can be long during weekends...
author: Lily T.

description: It's super cheap sushi.  The quality is hit or miss, but if you hust order vegi rolls, you will be very happy.  Great, friendly staff.
author: Jose S.

description: i love this place! i go just about every other weekend. i think it's fairly cheap & the service is great. never were the waitresses rude. most importantly, the food is deeeeelish!!! i always sit at the sushi bar! the only thing i hate is the wait is sometimes long and finding parking is a pain around dinner time. but it's surely worth the time! i don't think i can ever get sick of eating here!
author: Lynn H.

description: They have a wonderful sushi boat and very affordable prices. The staff can sometimes be attentive and sometimes not so much. The mussels here are delicious, not to mention my favorite! If you're into green tea ice cream, give theirs a try. It's not the best I've had, but it's pretty darn yummy. I've been coming back nonstop so I guess that has to say something good about the place. I find it interesting that although it is a Japanese restaurant, the chefs are Chinese...ha.
author: Katie N.

description: Food doesn't really taste that great, but lets be honest: it's pretty cheap. Lunch combo is ... I think under $5. Sushi boat gets kinda boring, though. There isn't much selection. But I find myself coming back for cheap sushi..
author: Judy L.

description:
i guess if i felt like sushi boat and i felt cheap and i didn't really feel like waiting for my food and i didn't feel like good sushi I'd go back again. or maybe it was the people in the place that made me not so happy to eat there. (disgusting teeth girl and screaming when they talk children. eck!) 
we got seated fairly quickly. i think it's gross that they have all their dirty dishes lined up in bins on the floor behind you. i dropped my sweater into one of the bins. they have the basics in sushi, but that's what i usually get anyways. they also have the fried stuff like the croquettes. like everyone else has said, everything was fairly cheap although I'm not sure how fresh, get what you pay for. i don't think i got sick so that's a plus. 
i also tried the fried ice cream. it comes with a green tea ice cream covered in some sort of cake then dipped in tempura batter and then fried. its served with a cherry and melted whip cream. 
really nothing to write home about.
author: Bee C.

description: after eating at fune-ya (see my review for that) i was kinda scared of sushi boat in general.. my friends sister really likes this place and i was freakin' hungry so hunger won the battle..  most of the sushi dishes are cheap but theres not much variety..   i think i had about 6 or 7 plates of sushi.. and at around 2 bucks a plate.. i wasn't as full as i would like to be..
author: JUDY L.

description: I've been here a few times and I think this is more of a hit or miss place . You can eat from the sushi boat , order from a menu , or do both . Yesterday my friend and I had the winter roll and some other heart shaped roll that had spicy tuna in it . The sushi didn't impress me at all .. it was just okay . The sashimi tasted okay .. but not super fresh . The fresh oysters were okay .. they were kind of on the small side . But I really really liked the sauce that came with it .. it was very yummy !! :) I had 4 oysters and 2 pcs of sashimi .. I think that was why I got a stomachache right after ]= . However , I do remember one time when I was really hungry .. my father bought me some take-out sushi . It was the freshest and most delicious sushi I've ever had in my whole life . I asked where he had gotten it and he told me it was this place . I was shocked !! So I guess this place really is a hit or miss . Overall , this place is not bad .. very affordable sushi .
author: Eileen L.

description: similar to fune-ya. i ate with a friend one time, and i asked for the bill THREE times!!! it wasn't that busy anyway! i rounded up on their bill so i think it was like what? 9 cents? HA. and.. it wasn't that good either!
author: Tina L.

description: Okay, basic sushi.  Randomly went in here because we were starving.  Got sushi off of boats.  It was filling, and not too pricey.  Nothing amazing, but not bad either.
author: Patrick P.

description: They recently slightly remodeled the place. So I thought I'd come by to check it out.  My last visit was around September 2007.  The wait is never too long at this restaurant.  So when we were seated at the sushi bar, I thought it was real pretty watching the glistening gold boats float by.  I think they need to put more variety on their boats though.  I usually like eating unagi but they didn't have it - and that's one of the most commonly ordered sushi's!  I had to ask for one and I didn't even get to pick it off the nice gold boat....lol just kidding.  But yeah, I think their entrees are shrinking too.  Coming here my first time around early 2006, I ordered a generous bowl of chicken teriyaki for less than 5 dollars at lunch.  This last visit after their remodeling, I ordered a beef teriyaki bowl and it had only 5 mini small pieces of beef, and 60% of the beef was made of chunks of fat!  Disgusting!  Other than that though, the sushi's a great way to go.  It's cheap and satisfactory.
author: Leslie Y.

description: one of the best toned down sushi places in SF, totally comparable to GO SUSHI 55 in little tokyo in LA.  the fish is FRESH, doesnt have the fishy smell.  lotsa of variety, yummy, tempura is crunchy, service is a what you would expect from a chinese owned restaurant. get dessert somewhere else, only come here for the sushi and the genmai cha. the prices for the sushi bar is awesome 30 bucks can fill up 2 people on a date. i wont recommend this place for a first date, but for anything else, go for it.
author: Hana ..

description: I do like this place for the fact that it is cheap and the food is ok... it's a great place to go to take care of that sushi craving I get every week without breaking any budgets...I always drag my sister along because I wouldn't be caught dead bringing a date to this place... I love their quasi california rolls and their beef teriyaki portions are generous and surprisingly good... two stars is for the service I've gotten the past two times I've been here... both times the only guy waiter in the place waited on us and it was faster to make our own sushi boat out of chopsticks than it was getting anything from him..drinks...orders...our check??? and to think, the food is freaking right in front of us...how hard can it be really??? the last time I was here we ordered as soon as we sat down we waited through two turns...yes two different set of people sat next to us, ate and paid..before we finally spoke up... luckly good conversation and passing sushi boat kept us busy before asking another waitress about our food... we were both servers and we understand that food sometime takes awhile to make...wasn't ordered...no apologises...we canceled it..got free edomane...woo hoo... now I have to find some other alternative for my sushi crave (it sucks to be japanese) or ask for a different server here...
author: Alex H.

description: This place have very fair prices, in fact, it's damn near dirt cheap.  unfortunatly almost everything that comes by on the boat is the same.  Deep friend items seem to be more common than the seaweed salad.  If you're lucky you'll catch a fish (literally).   Unfortunatly if you arn't fast enough someone else will get it.  The entree items arn't too bad (i havn't had anything bad anyways).  What the sushi bar lacks is veriety, everything else you can order off a menu smack in your face on the glass at the sushi bar.
author: Kevin C.

description: if you wanna complain about the food, then go to another restaurant, cheap asses! this place is for people on a budget who wanna get their sushi on. first time i came here i was amazed cuz i didnt understnad how the boats move. then when i took my friend, he put some plates in his pocket and threw them away in the bathroom trash. ahah he save himself maybe $5 at most. yea this place is "ok" . i like it better before they raised the price. they trying to be a real sushi place but its more for regular joe six pack. i always eat here. one time i had to wait freaking 1 hour for my food i literally sat their for about 40 minutes. they gave me free ice cream or peas or something. LAME. still i eat here. its a good restuarant. sure the boss looks like a bum but he aint making the food so whatever
author: Edward S.

description: If you want cheap sushi, relatively speaking, then this is the place to go. They do not have a wide selection as some more expensive joints, but the basics are there. After $25 including a large Sappolo beer, I am stuffed. I go there once a month.
author: Jason L.

description:
This is the best place to get Japanese food.  I try Japanese food like the way I try crepes, go in and try any restaurant I see until I find the best one.  So far, this is the best place, especially since they have sushi boats (which I heard is what the restaurant's name means in japanese).  You can grab any plate as it moves in front of you.  The plates' costs are $1.00 / $1.50 / $1.95 and we usually can get full in the range of $22.  It may sound little, but if you go there, see the plates, and do a little calculation, then it's not so damn cheap, even though it's quite reasonable.  You can also order other items than can't float around, like udon, from the menu.  The tea is delicious (they say i'ts green tea, but I doubt it because it's better than any green tea I've ever tasted) and they refill it as much as you want.  The waitress are all really nice and have good customer service.  The only down side is their bathroom.  This may be weird, but I take a restaurant's bathroom condition into consideration to know if they are sanitary or not.  Their bathroom is pretty dirty and it makes you feel like you don't want to be in there for more than 30 seconds.  

Tip: it's usually crowded on weekend nights and hard to find parking space.  If you come as a group, have one person go in the restaurant to reserve/ wait for a table/seats while everyone else circle the block to look for parking space.
author: Karen C.

description: I like this place.  It's not the best sushi I've ever had by all means.  But for the price, it's pretty damn good.  I can't remember the last time walking out of a sushi restaurant for $30 for 2 people.  I really like their super white tuna (maybe not tuna??).  The rest are regular/mediocre quality.  You just have to be selective.  That's why it's a sushi boat, you look first and you take.
author: gummy j.

description: If you are looking for cheap sushi then this is the place! I'm not a sushi connoisseur so I can't really tell the difference in sushi. Sushi is pretty good for the price. I haven't ordered anything off the menu. I just take sushi from the boat. If you have no self-control, do not sit at the sushi boat. You will not be wanting to leave until you are passed out from being too full. I can easily spend $10-$15 bucks there because I myself have no self-control.
author: David S.

description: Sakanabune is a great value for the money you pay.  We are avid sushi eaters, and definitely prefer more high-end day fresh fish, but with that comes high-end prices that are at least 3 times, if not more expensive than Sakanabune.  If you like sushi, but don't have to have the BEST, then this is a great place.  It's quick.  The servers are very polite.  I've read some negative comments on here about the staff, and I think what comes across as rudeness is more shyness and a language barrier.  Everytime we go, they are very friendly, and it's also kid-friendly.  Many kids go up to the waitresses and hug them.  If your kids like sushi and you don't want to spend $100, then go here!
author: Stacey F.

description: the place is jus wonderful! the first time i came..i loved it right away! the tea wa great n even though it was expensive the foo was great.
author: sARaH s.

description: A good place for basic sushi rolls going round and round the sushi boat pond.   Nothing very innovative, but familiar and inexpensive (as in very cheap).  If your are on Geary in the 20's and want a quick sushi fix with some sake (the nondescript hot kind - cheap, but does the job) this is  a pretty good  place to go.  By the way, I have to tip my cap to the creative ingenuity of the Japanese people.  They have given us many products that we incorporate in our lives (consumer electronics, reliable automobiles, etc.) but, for me, the sushi boat has opened my eyes.  You sit down and food starts floating past your plate - pick and eat.  Unlike many places  where a possibly unmotivated waitperson takes your order to a kitchen in the back where your food is prepared by unknown persons, with the sushi boat you can sit right in front of the sushi chef and watch him (or her) cut the fish, roll the rice and then you can snatch it before it has even settled in on its little boat for a ride - from hand to mouth to stomach in less time than a California roll can circumnavigate the sushi boat sea even once.
author: David P.
